sense.definition: used before countable or singular nouns referring to people or things that have not already been mentioned
examples: an FM radio.
a UN declaration.
a man/horse/unit
an aunt/egg/hour/X-ray
I can only carry two at a time.
There's a visitor for you.
She's a friend of my father's ( = one of my father's friends).

sense.definition: used before uncountable nouns when these have an adjective in front of them, or phrase following them
examples: a good knowledge of French
a sadness that won't go away

sense.definition: any; every
examples: A lion is a dangerous animal.

sense.definition: used to show that someone or something is a member of a group or profession
examples: Their new car's a BMW.
She's a Buddhist.
He's a teacher.
Is that a Monet ( = a painting by Monet)?

sense.definition: used in front of two nouns that are seen as a single unit
examples: a knife and fork

sense.definition: used instead of one before some numbers
examples: A thousand people were there.

sense.definition: used when talking about prices, quantities, and rates
examples: They cost 50 cents a pound.
I can type 50 words a minute.
He was driving at 50 miles an hour.

sense.definition: a person like someone
examples: He's a little Shaq.

sense.definition: used before someone's name to show that the speaker does not know the person
examples: There's a Mrs. Green here to see you.

sense.definition: used before the names of days of the week to talk about one particular day
examples: She died on a Tuesday.

sense.definition: to leave someone, especially someone you are responsible for, with no intention of returning
examples: The baby had been abandoned by its mother.
People often simply abandon their pets when they go on vacation.

sense.definition: to leave a thing or place, especially because it is impossible or dangerous to stay
examples: Snow forced many drivers to abandon their vehicles.
He gave the order to abandon ship ( = to leave the ship because it was sinking).
They had to abandon their lands to the invading forces.

sense.definition: to stop supporting or helping someone; to stop believing in something
examples: The country abandoned its political leaders after the war.
By 1930 he had abandoned his Marxist principles.

sense.definition: to stop doing something, especially before it is finished; to stop having something
examples: They abandoned the game because of rain.
She abandoned hope of any reconciliation.
We had to abandon any further attempt at negotiation.

sense.definition: to feel an emotion so strongly that you can feel nothing else
examples: He abandoned himself to despair.

sense.definition: left and not wanted, not used, or no longer needed
examples: an abandoned car/house
The child was found abandoned but unharmed.
There was an abandoned grocery cart in the middle of the road.

sense.definition: (of people or their behavior) wild; not following accepted standards
the fact that someone or something is able to do something
examples: The system has the ability to run more than one program at the same time.
Everyone has the right to good medical care regardless of their ability to pay.
A gentle form of exercise will increase your ability to relax.

sense.definition: a level of skill or intelligence
examples: Almost everyone has some musical ability.
He was a man of extraordinary abilities.
students of mixed abilities
A woman of her ability will easily find a job.
I try to do my job to the best of my ability ( = as well as I can).

sense.definition: to have the skill, intelligence, opportunity, etc. needed to do something
examples: You must be able to speak French for this job.
A viral illness left her barely able to walk.
I didn't feel able to disagree with him.
Will you be able to come?
Can you play the piano?
I can hear someone calling,
The DVD can be found online.
Can you/Are you able to come on Saturday?
You’ll be able to get a taxi outside the station.
I haven’t been able to get much work done today.
She’d love to be able to play the piano.
Our daughter could walk when she was nine months old.
I was able to/managed to find some useful books in the library.
We weren’t able to/didn’t manage to/couldn’t get there in time.
I could see there was something wrong.
I could have won the game but decided to let him win instead.

sense.definition: intelligent; good at something
examples: the ablest student in the class
We aim to help the less able in society to lead an independent life.

sense.definition: a little more or less than; a little before or after
examples: It costs about $10.
They waited (for) about an hour.
He arrived (at) about ten.

sense.definition: nearly; very close to
examples: I'm just about ready.
This is about the best we can hope for.

sense.definition: facing the opposite direction
examples: He brought the ship about.

sense.definition: almost; very nearly
examples: I've met just about everyone.
“Did you reach your sales target?” “Just about.”

sense.definition: approximately
examples: She should be arriving just about now.

sense.definition: able to go outside again after an illness
traveling around a place
examples: We've been out and about talking to people all over the country.

sense.definition: used to say that you have finished telling someone about something and there is nothing to add
examples: “Anything else?” “No, that's about it for now.”

sense.definition: at or to a higher place or position than something or someone
examples: The water came above our knees.
We were flying above the clouds.
the people in the apartment above mine
A captain in the navy ranks above a captain in the army.
They finished the year six places above their local rivals.

sense.definition: more than something; greater in number, level, or age than someone or something
examples: Inflation is above 6%.
Temperatures have been above average.
We cannot accept children above the age of 10.

sense.definition: of greater importance or of higher quality than someone or something
examples: I rate her above most other players of her age.

sense.definition: too good or too honest to do something
examples: She's not above lying when it gets her out of trouble.
He's above suspicion ( = he is completely trusted).

sense.definition: louder or clearer than another sound
examples: I couldn't hear her above the noise of the traffic.

sense.definition: most important of all; especially
examples: Above all, keep in touch.

sense.definition: in addition to something
examples: There are other factors over and above those we have discussed.

sense.definition: in or to a foreign country
examples: to be/go/travel/live abroad
She worked abroad for a year.
He was famous, both at home and abroad ( = in his own country and in other countries).

sense.definition: being talked about or felt by many people
examples: There was news abroad that a change was coming.

sense.definition: outside; outdoors
the fact of someone being away from a place where they are usually expected to be; the occasion or period of time when someone is away
examples: The decision was made in my absence ( = while I was not there).
We did not receive any news during his long absence.
absence from work
repeated absences from school

sense.definition: the fact of someone or something not existing or not being available; a lack of something
examples: The case was dismissed in the absence of any definite proof.
the absence of any women on the board of directors

sense.definition: used to say that when you are away from someone that you love, you love them even more
not present in a situation or place, when it is obvious that you should be there
examples: When it came to cleaning up afterward, Anne was conspicuous by her absence.

sense.definition: not in a place because of illness, etc.
examples: to be absent from school

sense.definition: not present in something
examples: Love was totally absent from his childhood.

sense.definition: showing that you are not really looking at or thinking about what is happening around you
examples: an absent expression

sense.definition: total and complete
examples: a class for absolute beginners
absolute confidence/trust/silence/truth
“You're wrong,” she said with absolute certainty.
Around them the darkness was absolute, the silence oppressive.

sense.definition: used, especially in spoken English, to give emphasis to what you are saying
examples: There's absolute garbage on television tonight.
He must earn an absolute fortune.
110 MB is the absolute minimum you need to install the program.
What an absolute idiot I've been!

sense.definition: definite and without any doubt or confusion
examples: There was no absolute proof.
He taught us that the laws of physics were absolute.
The divorce became absolute last week.

sense.definition: not limited or restricted
examples: absolute power/authority
an absolute ruler/monarchy ( = one with no limit to their power)

sense.definition: existing or measured independently and not in relation to something else
examples: Although prices are falling in absolute terms, energy is still expensive.
Beauty cannot be measured by any absolute standard.

sense.definition: used to emphasize that something is completely true
examples: You're absolutely right.
He made it absolutely clear.
I'm not absolutely certain I posted it.
It was absolutely pouring with rain.

sense.definition: used to emphasize something negative
examples: She did absolutely no work.
There's absolutely nothing more the doctors can do.

sense.definition: used with adjectives or verbs that express strong feelings or extreme qualities to mean “extremely”
examples: I was absolutely furious with him.
She absolutely adores you.
He's an absolutely fantastic cook.

sense.definition: used to emphasize that you agree with someone, or to give someone permission to do something
examples: “They could have told us, couldn't they?” “Absolutely!”
“Can we leave a little early?” “Absolutely!”

sense.definition: used to emphasize that you strongly disagree with someone, or to refuse permission
examples: “Was it any good?” “No, absolutely not.”

sense.definition: to take in a liquid, gas, or other substance from the surface or space around
examples: Plants absorb oxygen.
Let the rice cook until it has absorbed all the water.
The lotion is easily absorbed into the skin.

sense.definition: to make something smaller become part of something larger
examples: The country simply cannot absorb this influx of refugees.
The surrounding small towns have been absorbed into the city.

sense.definition: to take something into the mind and learn or understand it
examples: It's a lot of information to absorb all at once.
It took me several days to absorb the fact of her death.
They spent a week in Paris just absorbing the atmosphere.

sense.definition: to interest someone very much so that they pay no attention to anything else
examples: This work had absorbed him for several years.

sense.definition: to take in and keep heat, light, energy, etc. instead of reflecting it
examples: Black walls absorb a lot of heat during the day.

sense.definition: to reduce the effect of a blow, hit, etc.
examples: This tennis racket absorbs shock on impact.
The bats have graphite shafts that absorb the vibration.

sense.definition: to use up a large supply of something, especially money or time
examples: The new proposals would absorb $80 billion of the federal budget.

sense.definition: to deal with changes, effects, costs, etc.
examples: The company is unable to absorb such huge losses.

sense.definition: the use of something in a way that is wrong or harmful
examples: alcohol/drug abuse
The system of paying cash bonuses is open to abuse ( = might be used in the wrong way).
He was arrested on charges of corruption and abuse of power.
What she did was an abuse of her position as manager.

sense.definition: unfair, cruel, or violent treatment of someone
examples: child abuse
sexual abuse
reported abuses by the secret police
She suffered years of physical abuse.

sense.definition: rude and offensive remarks, usually made when someone is very angry
examples: to scream/hurl/shout abuse
a stream/torrent of abuse
The man burst into a torrent of foul-mouthed racist abuse.

sense.definition: connected with education, especially studying in colleges and universities
examples: The students return in October for the beginning of the new academic year.
high/low academic standards
an academic career
The enrollment criteria are geographical rather than academic.

sense.definition: involving a lot of reading and studying rather than practical or technical skills
examples: academic subjects

sense.definition: not connected to a real or practical situation and therefore not important
examples: It is a purely academic question.
The whole thing's academic now—we can't win anyway.
You have to do well academically to get into medical school.
He wasn't very well qualified academically but had a lot of experience.

sense.definition: a way of pronouncing the words of a language that shows which country, area, or social class a person comes from
examples: a Southern/New York/Greek/British accent
a heavy/thick accent ( = one that is very noticeable)
She spoke English with an accent.

sense.definition: a special importance that is given to something
examples: In all our products the accent is on quality.

sense.definition: the emphasis that you should give to part of a word when saying it
examples: In “today” the accent is on the second syllable.

sense.definition: a mark on a letter to show that it should be pronounced in a particular way
examples: Canapé has an accent on the “e.”

sense.definition: to willingly take something that is offered; to say “yes” to an offer, invitation, etc.
examples: He asked me to marry him and I accepted.
Please accept our sincere apologies.
It was pouring rain so I accepted his offer of a ride.
She decided not to accept the job.
Please accept this small token of my appreciation.
He was charged with accepting bribes from his suppliers.
She said she'd accept $15 for it.

sense.definition: to receive something as suitable or good enough
examples: This machine only accepts coins.
Will you accept a check?
My article has been accepted for publication.

sense.definition: to agree to or approve of something
examples: They accepted the court's decision.
He accepted all the changes we proposed.
Everything about the child's adoption was against accepted practice.
She won't accept advice from anyone.
He agreed to let me go early.
They accepted the court's decision.
The committee unanimously approved the plan.
He just goes along with everything she suggests.
She finally consented to be interviewed.

sense.definition: to admit that you are responsible or to blame for something
examples: He accepts full responsibility for what happened.
You have to accept the consequences of your actions.

sense.definition: to believe that something is true
examples: I don't accept his version of events.
Can we accept his account as the true version?
I accept that this will not be popular.
I am not prepared to accept that this decision is final.
It is generally accepted that people are motivated by success.
The Northeast is generally accepted to have some of the best colleges in the country.

sense.definition: to continue in a difficult situation without complaining, because you realize that you cannot change it
examples: You just have to accept the fact that we're never going to be rich.
Nothing will change as long as the workers continue to accept these terrible conditions.
They accept the risks as part of the job.
He just refused to accept that his father was no longer there.

sense.definition: to make someone feel welcome and part of a group
examples: It may take years to be completely accepted by the local community.
She had never been accepted into what was essentially a man's world.
He never really accepted her as his own child.

sense.definition: to allow someone to join an organization, attend an institution, use a service, etc.
examples: The college he applied to has accepted him.
She was disappointed not to be accepted into the club.
The landlord was willing to accept us as tenants.
She was accepted to study music.

sense.definition: agreed or approved of by most people in a society
examples: Children must learn socially acceptable behavior.

sense.definition: that someone agrees is of a good enough standard or allowed
examples: To take this course, the lowest acceptable test score is 90.
Air pollution in the city had reached four times the acceptable levels.
We want a political solution that is acceptable to all parties.

sense.definition: not very good, but good enough
examples: The food was acceptable, but no better than that.

sense.definition: a way of entering or reaching a place
examples: The police gained access through a broken window.
There is easy access by road.
The only access to the farmhouse is across the fields.
Disabled visitors are welcome; there is good wheelchair access to most facilities.

sense.definition: the opportunity or right to use something or to see someone or something
examples: Students must have access to good resources.
You need a password to get access to the computer system.
access to confidential information
Journalists were denied access to the president.

sense.definition: an unpleasant event, especially in a vehicle, that happens unexpectedly and causes injury or damage
examples: a car/highway/traffic accident
He was killed in an accident.
One in seven accidents is caused by sleepy drivers.
The accident happened at 3  p.m.
to have an accident
a serious/minor accident
a fatal accident ( = in which someone is killed)
accidents in the home
a climbing/riding accident
Take out accident insurance before you go on your trip.
I didn't mean to break it—it was an accident.

sense.definition: something that happens unexpectedly and is not planned in advance
examples: Their early arrival was just an accident.
It is no accident that men fill most of the high-paying jobs in finance.
an accident of birth/fate/history ( = describing facts and events that are due to chance or circumstances)
This ring has always brought me good luck.
The results could simply be due to chance.
They met through a series of strange coincidences.
I discovered the book by accident while shopping for a birthday present.
Fate decreed that she would not get married that day.
I believe there's some force guiding us—call it God, destiny, or fate.

sense.definition: a thing or person that is very likely to cause danger or a problem in the future because of the condition it is in or the way they behave
people say accidents (will) happen to tell someone who has had an accident, for example breaking something, that it does not matter and they should not worry
in a way that is not planned or organized
examples: We met by accident at the airport.
Helen got into acting purely by accident.
She broke the vase by accident.

sense.definition: happening by chance; not planned
examples: a verdict of accidental death
I didn't think our meeting was accidental—he must have known I would be there.
As I turned around, I accidentally hit him in the face.
The damage couldn't have been caused accidentally.

sense.definition: to travel or go somewhere with someone
examples: His wife accompanied him on the trip.
I'll have to ask you to accompany me to the police station.
Warships will accompany the convoy.

sense.definition: to happen or appear with something else
examples: strong winds accompanied by heavy rain
Each pack contains a book and accompanying CD.
Shouts of protest accompanied this announcement.
The text is accompanied by a series of stunning photographs.

sense.definition: to play a musical instrument, especially a piano, while someone else sings or plays the main tune
examples: The singer was accompanied on the piano by her sister.

sense.definition: as stated or reported by someone or something
examples: According to Mick, it's a great movie.
You've been absent six times, according to our records.
This bar chart illustrates how many journeys people made on public transportation over a three-month period.
This table compares bus, train, and taxi use between April and June.
The results are shown in the chart below.
In this pie chart, the survey results are broken down by age.
This pie chart breaks down the survey results by age.
As can be seen from these results, younger people use buses more than older people.
According to these figures, bus travel accounts for 60% of public transportation use.
From the data in the above graph, it is apparent that buses are the most widely used form of public transportation.

sense.definition: following, agreeing with, or depending on something
examples: The work was done according to her instructions.
Everything went according to plan.
The salary will be set according to qualifications and experience.

sense.definition: an arrangement that someone has with a bank, etc. to keep money there, take some out, etc.
examples: I don't have a bank account.
to have an account at/with a bank
to open/close an account
What's your account number please?
I deposited the check into my savings account.
a joint account ( = one that more than one person uses)

sense.definition: a written record of all the money that a business pays out and receives
examples: to do the accounts
to keep the accounts up to date
accounts payable/accounts receivable

sense.definition: an arrangement with a store or business to pay bills for goods or services at a later time, for example in regular amounts every month
examples: Put it on my store account please.
We have accounts with most of our suppliers.
the gas bill
Put it on my account please.
The contractor sent an invoice for $750.
Can I have the check, please?
Let's split the check ( = let's each pay half).

sense.definition: a regular customer
examples: The agency has lost several of its most important accounts.

sense.definition: an arrangement that someone has with a company that allows them to use the Internet, send, and receive messages by e-mail, etc.
examples: an Internet/e-mail account

sense.definition: a written or spoken description of something that has happened
examples: He gave the police a full account of the incident.
The diaries contained detailed accounts of the writer's experiences in China.
We're getting reports of fighting in the south of the country.
It was many years before the full story was made public.
the front-page story
He gave the police a full account of the incident.
She gave us her version of what had happened that day.

sense.definition: an explanation or a description of an idea, a theory, or a process
examples: the Biblical account of the creation of the world

sense.definition: a description of an event that gives you all the details in the order in which they happen
examples: He insisted on giving us a blow-by-blow account of what had happened.

sense.definition: according to what other people say
examples: I've never been there, but it's a beautiful place, by all accounts.

sense.definition: according to what you say yourself
examples: By his own account, he had an unhappy childhood.

sense.definition: to make someone explain a mistake, etc. because they are responsible for it
if you buy something or pay on account, you pay nothing or only a small amount immediately and the rest later
because of what you think someone wants
examples: Please don't change your plans on my account.

sense.definition: because of someone or something
examples: She retired early on account of ill health.
The marsh is an area of great scientific interest on account of its wild flowers.
The number of people with diabetes is growing, partly because of an increase in levels of obesity.
The number of overweight children has increased dramatically in recent years, largely as a result of changes in diet and lifestyle.
The increase in childhood obesity is largely due to/the result of changes in lifestyle and diet over the last twenty years.
Many obese children are bullied at school on account of their weight.
Part of the problem with treating childhood obesity stems from the fact that parents do not always recognize that their children are obese.
Childhood obesity may be caused by genetic factors as well as environmental ones.

sense.definition: not for any reason
examples: On no account should the house be left unlocked.

sense.definition: for yourself
examples: In 2006 Smith set up in business on his own account.

sense.definition: because you want to and you have decided, not someone else
examples: No one sent me, I am here on my own account.

sense.definition: because of the particular thing that has been mentioned
examples: Weather conditions were poor, but he did not delay his departure on that account.

sense.definition: to use something in a good or helpful way
examples: He turned his artistic talents to good account by teaching art to children.

sense.definition: to hurt or punish someone who has harmed or cheated you in the past
examples: “Who would do such a thing?” “Maybe someone with an old score to settle.”

sense.definition: to consider particular facts, circumstances, etc. when making a decision about something
examples: The company takes account of environmental issues wherever possible.
Coursework is taken into account as well as exam results.
The defendant asked for a number of other offenses to be taken into account.

sense.definition: correct and true in every detail
examples: an accurate description/account/calculation
accurate information/data
Accurate records must be kept.
The police are trying to obtain a more accurate picture of crime levels.

sense.definition: able to give completely correct information or to do something in an exact way
examples: a highly accurate electronic compass
accurate to within 3 mm
My watch is not very accurate.
Scientists have found a more accurate way of dating cave paintings.

sense.definition: an accurate throw, shot, weapon, etc. hits or reaches the thing that it was aimed at

examples: The article accurately reflects public opinion.
You need to hit the ball accurately.

sense.definition: to say that someone has done something wrong or is guilty of something
examples: to accuse someone of murder/theft
She accused him of lying.
The government was accused of incompetence.
They stand accused of crimes against humanity.

sense.definition: to succeed in reaching a particular goal, status, or standard, especially by making an effort for a long time
examples: He had finally achieved success.
They could not achieve their target of less than 3% inflation.

sense.definition: to succeed in doing something or causing something to happen
examples: I haven't achieved very much today.
All you've achieved is making my parents upset.

sense.definition: to be successful
examples: Their background gives them little chance of achieving in school.
Profits of $20 million look achievable.
achievable goals

sense.definition: a thing that someone has done successfully, especially using their own effort and skill
examples: the greatest scientific achievement of the decade
It was a remarkable achievement for such a young player.
They were proud of their children's achievements.
Leaders are truly effective in achieving organizational objectives only when they are motivated by a concern for others.
Woodward concludes that economic policy broadly failed to achieve its goals of low unemployment and low inflation.
An accurate estimate of their numbers is difficult to achieve.
No significant differences in academic achievement were found.
This agreement is a remarkable achievement from both a scientific and a social perspective.
Web-based simulations can generate insights not readily achievable by other means.
Self-esteem arises from reaching out for difficult but achievable goals.

sense.definition: the act or process of achieving something
examples: the need to raise standards of achievement in education
Even a small success gives you a sense of achievement ( = a feeling of pride).

sense.definition: a chemical, usually a liquid, that contains hydrogen and has a pH of less than seven. The hydrogen can be replaced by a metal to form a salt. Acids are usually sour and can often burn holes in or damage things they touch.
to accept that something is true
examples: She refuses to acknowledge the need for reform.
Are you prepared to acknowledge your responsibility?
The government acknowledged that the tax was unfair.
It is generally acknowledged to be true.
It was a stupid thing to do, I admit.
She refuses to acknowledge the need for reform.
They recognized the need to take the problem seriously.
He was forced to concede that there might be difficulties.
She was reluctant to confess her ignorance.

sense.definition: to accept that someone or something has a particular authority or status synonym recognize
examples: The country acknowledged his claim to the presidency.
He is widely acknowledged as the best player in the world.
He is widely acknowledged to be the best player in the world.

sense.definition: to tell someone that you have received something that they sent to you
examples: All applications will be acknowledged.
Please acknowledge receipt of this letter.

sense.definition: to show that you have noticed someone or something by smiling, waving, etc.
examples: I was standing right next to her, but she didn't even acknowledge me.
He waved, acknowledging the applause.

sense.definition: to publicly express thanks for help you have been given
examples: I gratefully acknowledge financial support from several local businesses.
He is always ready to acknowledge his debt to his teachers.
a generally acknowledged fact

sense.definition: to obtain something by buying or being given it
examples: The company has just acquired new premises.
How did the gallery come to acquire so many Picassos?
I've suddenly acquired a stepbrother.

sense.definition: to gain something by your own efforts, ability, or behavior
examples: She has acquired a good knowledge of English.
How long will it take to acquire the necessary skills?
He has acquired a reputation for dishonesty.
I have recently acquired a taste for ( = started to like) olives.

sense.definition: a thing that you do not like much at first but gradually learn to like
examples: Abstract art is an acquired taste.

sense.definition: from one side to the other side
examples: It's too wide. We can't swim across.
The yard measures about 50 feet across.

sense.definition: in a particular direction toward or at someone or something
examples: When my name was called, he looked across at me.

sense.definition: opposite
examples: There's a school just across from our house.

sense.definition: written from side to side
examples: I can't do 3 across.

sense.definition: a particular thing that someone does
examples: a criminal act
an act of kindness
acts of terrorism
The murder was the act of a psychopath.
Her quick action saved the child's life.
The government introduced tougher security measures last summer.
This work is a first step towards our eventual goal.
an act of kindness
a heroic act of bravery
her heroic actions/acts during the war.
We will take whatever action is necessary.
They are waiting for the results of the opinion polls before deciding their next move.

sense.definition: a law that has been passed by a government
examples: an act of Congress
the Civil Rights Act
A committee on Safety of Medicines was set up under the Act.

sense.definition: a way of behaving that is not sincere but is intended to have a particular effect on others
examples: Don't take her seriously—it's all an act.
You could tell she was just putting on an act.

sense.definition: one of the main divisions of a play, an opera, etc.
examples: a play in five acts
The hero dies in Act 5, Scene 3.

sense.definition: one of several short pieces of entertainment in a show
examples: a circus/comedy/magic act

sense.definition: a performer or group of musicians
examples: They were one of rock's most impressive live acts.

sense.definition: an event caused by natural forces beyond human control, such as a storm, a flood, or an earthquake
to be/become involved in an activity that someone else has started, especially to get something for yourself
examples: New companies want to get in on the act and provide cable services.

sense.definition: to start behaving in a moral or responsible way
examples: He cleaned up his act and got a job.

sense.definition: to go away or be impossible to find when people need or want you
to organize yourself and your activities in a more effective way in order to achieve something
examples: He needs to get his act together if he's going to pass.

sense.definition: a person who is so good or successful at something that it will be difficult for anyone else coming after them to be as good or successful
examples: She has been an excellent principal and will be a hard act to follow.

sense.definition: while you are doing something
examples: He was caught in the act of stealing a car.
It is often difficult to tell when someone is using drugs unless they are caught in the act.

sense.definition: to tell someone with force that they must not do something
the process of doing something in order to make something happen or to deal with a situation
examples: The time has come for action if these beautiful animals are to survive.
Firefighters took action immediately to stop the blaze from spreading.
What is the best course of action under these circumstances?
She began to explain her plan of action to the group.

sense.definition: a thing that someone does
examples: Her quick action saved the child's life.
Each of us must take responsibility for our own actions.

sense.definition: a legal process to stop a person or company from doing something, or to make them pay for a mistake, etc.
examples: An action is being brought against the magazine that published the article.
He is considering taking legal action against the hospital.

sense.definition: fighting in a battle or war
examples: missing in action
soldiers killed in action

sense.definition: the events in a story, play, etc.
examples: The action takes place in France.

sense.definition: exciting events
examples: I like movies with plenty of action.
New York is where the action is.

examples: He never made a will, to the best of my knowledge.

sense.definition: to feel certain that something is true or that someone is telling you the truth
examples: I don't believe you!
The man claimed to be a social worker and the old woman believed him.
Believe me, she's not right for you.
I believed his lies for years.
I find that hard to believe.
Don't believe a word of it ( = don't believe any part of what someone is saying).
People used to believe (that) the earth was flat.
He refused to believe (that) his son was taking drugs.
I do believe you're right ( = I think something is true, even though it is surprising).

sense.definition: to think that something is true or possible, although you are not completely certain
examples: “Where does she come from?” “Spain, I believe.”
“Does he still work there?” “I believe so/not.”
Police believe (that) the man may be armed.
It is believed that the couple has left the country.
The vases are believed to be worth over $20,000 each.
Three sailors are missing, believed drowned.
Do you think (that) they'll come?
What do you think about Matt's new girlfriend?
Police believe (that) the man may be armed.
Police believe…
I think…
We all felt (that) we had been cheated.
I was under the impression that the work had already been completed.

sense.definition: to have the opinion that something is right or true
examples: The candidate believes (that) education is the most important issue facing the government.
She believes that killing animals for food or fur is completely immoral.
Photography is, according to Vidal, the art form of untalented people.
For Vidal, photography is the art form of untalented people.
His view is that photography is not art but merely the mechanical reproduction of images.
Smith takes the view that photography is both an art and a science.
In Brown's view, photography should be treated as a legitimate art in its own right.
James is of the opinion that a good painter can always be a good photographer if he or she so decides.
Emerson believed that a photograph should reflect only what the human eye can see.
In my opinion, everyone should have some understanding of science.
Everyone should, in my opinion, have some understanding of science.
It seems to me that many people in this country have a flawed understanding of science.
This is, in my view, the result of a failure of the scientific community to get its message across.
Another reason why so many people have such a poor understanding of science is, I believe, the lack of adequate funding for science in schools.
Smith argues that science is separate from culture. My own view is that science belongs with literature, art, philosophy, and religion as an integral part of our culture.
In this writer's opinion, the more the public knows about science, the less they will fear and distrust it.

sense.definition: used to say that you are surprised or annoyed at something
examples: She couldn't believe (that) it was all happening again.
I don't believe I'm doing this!
I can't believe how much better I feel.

sense.definition: to have a religious faith
examples: The god appears only to those who believe.

sense.definition: used to introduce information that is true but that may surprise people
examples: Believe it or not, he asked me to marry him!

sense.definition: used to emphasize that you strongly believe what you are saying
examples: You haven't heard the last of this, believe you me!

sense.definition: used to tell someone that something is definitely not true
examples: “She wouldn't do a thing like that.” “Don't you believe it!”

sense.definition: to make someone believe/understand something
examples: I was given to understand that she had resigned.

sense.definition: used to say that you are surprised or annoyed about something
examples: I don't believe it! What are you doing here?

sense.definition: used to say that you think someone is stupid if they believe that something is true
examples: “He promised not to do it again.” “Sure, and if you believe that, you'll believe anything.”

sense.definition: to pretend that something is true
to be very surprised at something you hear/see
examples: I couldn't believe my eyes when she walked in.

sense.definition: used to say that someone will have to believe that something is true when they see it, although they do not think it is true now
used to show that you are surprised and annoyed about something
examples: And, would you believe, he didn't even apologize!

sense.definition: used to tell someone that something is definitely true
examples: “He's not a bad player, is he?” “You'd better believe it!”

sense.definition: a hollow metal object, often shaped like a cup, that makes a ringing sound when hit by a small piece of metal inside it; the sound that it makes
examples: A peal of church bells rang out in the distance.
a bicycle bell
His voice came down the line as clear as a bell.
the bell of a trumpet ( = the bell-shaped part at the end of it)
a bell tower
a bell-shaped flower
wedding bells
The dancers wore bells on their ankles.

sense.definition: an electrical device which makes a ringing sound when a button on it is pushed; the sound that it makes, used as a signal or a warning
examples: Ring the bell to see if they're in.
The bell's ringing!
The bell rang at the end of the class.
An alarm bell went off.
Warning bells started ringing in her head as she sensed that something was wrong.

sense.definition: if you say that alarm bells are ringing or that something sets off alarm bells, you mean that people are starting to feel worried and suspicious
examples: The government's proposal has set alarm bells ringing for people on low incomes.

sense.definition: to be hit very hard on the head
examples: Gonzales had his bell rung in the third round of the fight.

sense.definition: to sound familiar to you, as though you have heard it before
examples: His name rings a bell but I can't think where we met.

sense.definition: in perfect condition
examples: The doctor said I was as sound as a bell.

sense.definition: eager and full of enthusiasm about something
examples: Just tell me where the party is and I’ll be there with bells on.

sense.definition: to be in the right or suitable place
examples: Where do these plates belong ( = where are they kept)?
Are you sure these documents belong together?
Several of the points you raise do not belong in this discussion.
A person like that does not belong in teaching.

sense.definition: to feel comfortable and happy in a particular situation or with a particular group of people
examples: I don't feel as if I belong here.
to feel a sense of belonging

sense.definition: at or to a lower level or position than someone or something
examples: He dived below the surface of the water.
Please do not write below this line.
Skirts should be worn below ( = long enough to cover) the knee.

sense.definition: of a lower amount or standard than someone or something
examples: The temperature remained below freezing all day.
Her work was well below average for the class.

sense.definition: of a lower rank or of less importance than someone or something
examples: A police sergeant is below a lieutenant.

sense.definition: a long narrow piece of leather, cloth, etc. that you wear around the waist
examples: to buckle/fasten/tighten a belt
a belt buckle

sense.definition: a continuous band of material that moves around and is used to carry things along, or to drive machinery
an area with particular characteristics or where a particular group of people live
examples: the country's corn/sun belt
a belt of rain moving across the country

sense.definition: an act of hitting something or someone hard
examples: She gave the ball a huge belt.

sense.definition: unfair or cruel
examples: That really hit him below the belt!

sense.definition: to have already achieved or obtained something
examples: She already has a couple of good wins under her belt.

sense.definition: to spend less money because there is less available
examples: My parents really had to tighten their belts after my mother retired.

sense.definition: to lean, or make something lean, in a particular direction
examples: He bent and kissed her.
The doctor told me to avoid bending and stretching.
fields of poppies bending in the wind
His dark head bent over her.
She bent forward to pick up the newspaper.
Slowly bend from the waist and bring your head down to your knees.
He bent his head and kissed her.
She was bent over her desk writing a letter.

sense.definition: if you bend your arm, leg, etc. or if it bends, you move it so that it is no longer straight
examples: Bend your knees, keeping your back straight.
Lie flat and let your knees bend.

sense.definition: to force something that was straight into an angle or a curve
examples: Mark the pipe where you want to bend it.
The knives were bent out of shape.
He bent the wire into the shape of a square.

sense.definition: to change direction to form a curve or an angle; to make something change direction in this way
examples: The road bent sharply to the right.
Glass and water both bend light.

sense.definition: to talk to someone a lot about something, especially about a problem that you have
to think very hard about or put a lot of effort into one particular thing
to make a great effort, especially in order to be helpful or fair
examples: I've bent over backward to help him.

sense.definition: to change the rules to suit a particular person or situation
to say something that is not completely true
examples: I wasn't exactly lying when I said I hadn't seen her—I was just bending the truth a little.

sense.definition: if you ask for something on bended knee(s), you ask for it in a very anxious and/or humble way
examples: I'd go down on bended knee if I thought she'd change her mind.

sense.definition: in or to a lower position than someone or something; under someone or something
examples: They found the body buried beneath a pile of leaves.
The boat sank beneath the waves.

sense.definition: not good enough for someone
examples: He considers such jobs beneath him.
They thought she had married beneath her ( = married a man of lower social status).
Her careful makeup hid the signs of age beneath.

sense.definition: an advantage that something gives you; a helpful and useful effect that something has
examples: I've had the benefit of a good education.
The new regulations will be for the benefit of everyone concerned.
It will be to your benefit to arrive early.
He couldn't see the benefit of arguing any longer.
the benefits of modern medicine
It was good to see her finally reaping the benefits ( = enjoying the results) of all her hard work.
With the benefit of hindsight ( = knowing what we have learned since), we would do things differently.
For maximum benefit, take the pills before meals.

sense.definition: an advantage that you get from a company in addition to the money that you earn; money from an insurance company
examples: Your benefits package includes medical and dental insurance.
The insurance plan will provide a substantial cash benefit to your family in case of your death.

sense.definition: an event such as a performance, a dinner, etc., organized in order to raise money for a particular person or charity
examples: a benefit game/concert

sense.definition: especially in order to help or be useful to someone
examples: I have typed out some lecture notes for the benefit of those people who were absent last week.
Don't go to any trouble for my benefit!

sense.definition: to accept that someone has told the truth or has not done something wrong because you cannot prove that they have not
examples: She may have been lying, but I felt I had to give her the benefit of the doubt.

sense.definition: not straight
examples: a piece of bent wire
Do this exercise with your knees bent ( = not with your legs straight).

sense.definition: not able to stand up straight, usually as a result of being old or sick
examples: a small, bent, old woman
He was bent double with laughter.

sense.definition: determined to do something (usually something bad)
examples: She seems bent on making life difficult for me.

sense.definition: to become angry, anxious, or upset
examples: Don't get bent out of shape about it. It was just a mistake!

sense.definition: next to or at the side of someone or something
examples: He sat beside her all night.
a mill beside a stream

sense.definition: compared with someone or something
examples: My painting looks childish beside yours.

sense.definition: to not be important or closely related to the main thing you are talking about
examples: Yes, I know it was an accident, but that's beside the point.
They took my words out of context, but that's beside the point.

sense.definition: unable to control yourself because of the strength of emotion you are feeling
examples: He was beside himself with rage when I told him what I had done.
They were beside themselves with excitement.

sense.definition: of the most excellent type or quality
examples: That's the best movie I've ever seen!

She was one of the best tennis players of her generation.
Is that your best suit?
They've been best friends ( = closest friends) since they were children.
the company's best-ever results
We want the kids to have the best possible education.

sense.definition: most enjoyable; happiest
examples: Those were the best years of my life.

sense.definition: most suitable or appropriate
examples: What's the best way to cook steak?

He's the best man for the job.
It's best if you go now.
I'm not in the best position to advise you.

sense.definition: to risk money on a race or an event by trying to predict the result
examples: You have to be over 18 to bet.
I wouldn't bet on them winning the next election.
He bet $2,000 on the final score of the game.
She bet me $20 that I wouldn't do it.

sense.definition: used to say that you are almost certain that something is true or that something will happen
examples: I bet (that) we're too late.
You can bet (that) the minute I sit down, the phone will ring.
I'll bet you (that) he knows all about it.

sense.definition: used to show that you can understand what someone is feeling, describing, etc.
examples: “I almost died when he told me.” “I bet!”

sense.definition: used to tell someone that you do not believe what they have just said
examples: “I'm going to tell her what I think of her.” “Yeah, I bet!”

sense.definition: used to say that you do not think that something is very likely
examples: “She'll get used to the idea.” “I wouldn't bet on it.”

sense.definition: used to disagree with what someone has stated or claimed
examples: “The Giants are going to win the Super Bowl.” “Want to bet?”

sense.definition: used instead of “yes” to emphasize that someone has guessed something correctly or made a good suggestion
examples: “Are you nervous?” “You bet!”

sense.definition: used to say that you are certain that something will happen
examples: You can bet your bottom dollar that he'll be late.

sense.definition: of a higher standard or less poor quality; not as bad as something else
examples: We're hoping for better weather tomorrow.
Her work is getting better and better.
He is in a much better mood than usual.
The meal couldn't have been better.
There's nothing better than a long soak in a hot bath.
If you can only exercise once a week, that's better than nothing ( = better than doing no exercise at all).

sense.definition: more able or skilled
examples: She's far better at science than her brother.

sense.definition: more suitable or appropriate
examples: Can you think of a better word than “nice”?
It would be better for him to talk to his parents about his problems.

sense.definition: less sick or unhappy
examples: She's a lot better today.
His leg was getting better.

sense.definition: fully recovered after an illness; in good health again
examples: Don't go back to work until you are better.

sense.definition: used to say that something should be as big, small, etc. as possible
examples: As far as the hard disk is concerned, the bigger the better.

sense.definition: almost or just the same as; almost or just as bad as
examples: The dinner was no better than fast food.

sense.definition: used to give support to someone who has been upset and is trying to become calmer
examples: Dry your eyes now. That's better.

sense.definition: used to praise someone who has made an effort to improve
examples: That's much better—you played all the right notes this time.

sense.definition: in or into the space separating two or more points, objects, people, etc.

sense.definition: in the period of time that separates two days, years, events, etc.
examples: It's cheaper between 6  p.m. and 8  a.m.

Many changes took place between the two world wars.

sense.definition: at some point along a scale from one amount, weight, distance, etc. to another
examples: It weighed between nine and ten pounds.

sense.definition: separating one place from another
examples: the border between Oregon and Washington

sense.definition: from one place to another
examples: We fly between Chicago and Dallas twice daily.

sense.definition: used to show a connection or relationship
examples: a difference/distinction/contrast between two things
a link between unemployment and crime
There's a lot of bad feelings between them.
I had to choose between the two jobs.

sense.definition: shared by two or more people or things
examples: We ate a pizza between us.
This is just between you and me/between ourselves ( = it is a secret).

sense.definition: by putting together the efforts or actions of two or more people or groups
examples: We should be able to manage it between us.
China and India between them account for more than a third of the world's population.

sense.definition: used to show that several activities are involved
examples: Between working full-time and taking care of the kids, he didn't have much time for hobbies.

sense.definition: on or to the further side of something
examples: The road continues beyond the village up into the hills.

sense.definition: later than a particular time
examples: It won't go on beyond midnight.

sense.definition: more than something
examples: Our success was far beyond what we thought possible.

sense.definition: used to say that something is not possible
examples: The bicycle was beyond repair ( = is too badly damaged to repair).

sense.definition: too far or too advanced for someone or something
examples: The handle was just beyond my reach.

sense.definition: to be impossible for someone to imagine, understand, or do
examples: It's beyond me why she wants to marry Jeff.

sense.definition: a road vehicle with two wheels that you ride by pushing the pedals with your feet
examples: He got on his bicycle and rode off.

sense.definition: to offer to pay a particular price for something, especially at an auction

sense.definition: to offer to do work or provide a service for a particular price, in competition with other companies, etc.
examples: A French firm will be bidding for the contract.

sense.definition: to try to do, get, or achieve something
examples: The team is bidding to make the playoffs.

sense.definition: (in some card games) to say how many points you expect to win
examples: She bid four hearts.

sense.definition: large in size, degree, amount, etc.
examples: a big man/house/increase

sense.definition: older
examples: You're a big girl now.
my big brother

sense.definition: important; serious
examples: a big decision

sense.definition: needing a lot of effort, money, or time to succeed
examples: They're full of big ideas.

sense.definition: popular with the public; successful
examples: Orange is the big color this year.

sense.definition: enthusiastic about someone or something
examples: I'm a big fan of hers.

sense.definition: doing something often or to a large degree
examples: a big eater/drinker/spender

sense.definition: kind or generous
examples: He gave me an extra five dollars for two hours of work. I thought, “That's big of you.”

sense.definition: to be/become too proud of yourself; to behave as if you are more important than you really are
an important and powerful person, especially in an organization
the most important person or thing
an important person (in a small community)
the situation as a whole
examples: Right now, we need to forget the details and take a look at the big picture.

sense.definition: an important person
the use or threat of force or power
examples: The authorities used quiet persuasion instead of the big stick.

sense.definition: the three, four, etc. most important countries, people, companies, etc.
examples: She works for one of the Big Six.

sense.definition: used to say that someone has been greedy by taking more food than they can eat
to show your approval of someone by clapping; to be applauded in this way
examples: Ladies and gentlemen, let's give a big hand to our special guests tonight…

sense.definition: to have more important or more interesting things to do
on a large/small scale
examples: The new delivery service has taken off in a big way.

sense.definition: to make something seem more important than it really is
the most important man in a group, especially the leader of a group of criminals
a piece of paper that shows how much you owe someone for goods or services
examples: the telephone/electricity/gas bill

She always pays her bills on time.
I'll be sending you the bill for the dry cleaning!
The bills are piling up ( = there are more and more that have still not been paid).
The bill for the meal came to $35.
Let's ask for the bill.

sense.definition: a piece of paper money
examples: a ten-dollar bill
I counted the money carefully.
Where can I change my money into dollars?
paper money ( = money that is made of paper, not coins)
How much cash do you have on you?
Payments can be made by credit card or in cash.
How much money/cash do you have on you?
The ticket machine doesn't give change.
I don't have any small change ( = coins of low value).
The machine only accepts small bills ( = $20 or less).

sense.definition: a written suggestion for a new law that is presented to a country's government so that its members can discuss it
examples: to pass/approve/veto a bill
a civil rights bill

sense.definition: a program of entertainment at a theater, etc.
examples: a horror double bill ( = two horror movies shown one after the other)

sense.definition: a notice in a public place to advertise an event
examples: Post no bills ( = a notice warning people not to stick bills in a particular place).

sense.definition: the hard pointed or curved outer part of a bird's mouth
having the type of bill mentioned
examples: long-billed waders

sense.definition: the stiff front part of a cap that sticks out above your eyes
a report that says someone is healthy or that something is in good condition
examples: Doctors gave him a clean bill of health after a series of tests and examinations.

sense.definition: to be what is needed in a particular situation or for a particular purpose
examples: On paper, several of the applicants fit the bill.

sense.definition: to be responsible for paying the cost of something
examples: Once again it will be the taxpayer who has to foot the bill.

sense.definition: the scientific study of the life and structure of plants and animals
examples: a degree in biology

sense.definition: the way in which the body and cells of a living thing behave
examples: How far is human nature determined by biology?
the biology of marine animals

sense.definition: a creature that is covered with feathers and has two wings, and two legs. Most birds can fly
examples: a bird's nest with two eggs in it
a species of bird

sense.definition: a person of a particular type, especially someone who is strange or unusual in some way
examples: a wise old bird

sense.definition: to not be important or practical
it is better to keep something that you already have than to risk losing it by trying to get much more
the basic facts about sex, especially as told to children
a view of something from a high position looking down
examples: From the plane we had a bird's eye view of Manhattan.

sense.definition: people of the same sort (are found together)
a person who takes the opportunity to do something before other people will have an advantage over them
to make a rude sign at someone with your middle finger
to achieve two things at the same time with one action
used to say that someone told you something but you do not want to say who it was
the time when a baby is born; the process of being born
examples: The baby weighed 8 pounds at birth.

a hospital/home birth
Mark has been blind from birth.
Please state your date and place of birth.

sense.definition: the beginning of a new situation, idea, place, etc.
examples: the birth of a new society in South Africa

sense.definition: a person's origin or the social position of their family
examples: Anne was French by birth but lived most of her life in Italy.
a woman of noble birth

sense.definition: to produce a baby or young animal
examples: She died shortly after giving birth.

sense.definition: the day in each year that is the same date as the one on which you were born
examples: Happy Birthday!

a birthday card/party/present

sense.definition: not wearing any clothes
rather, slightly
examples: These pants are a little bit tight.

sense.definition: a short time or distance
examples: Wait a bit!

sense.definition: a small amount or piece of something
examples: some useful bits of information

bits of grass/paper

sense.definition: a large amount
examples: The new system will take a bit of getting used to ( = it will take a long time to get used to).

sense.definition: the smallest unit of information used by a computer
a metal bar that is put in a horse's mouth so that the rider can control it
a tool or part of a tool for drilling ( = making) holes
an amount of money equal to 12½ cents
behavior or ideas that are typical of a particular group, type of person, or activity
examples: She found the whole motherhood bit difficult.

sense.definition: a piece at a time; gradually
examples: He assembled the model aircraft bit by bit.

sense.definition: not fair or not reasonable
examples: Isn't it a bit much, calling me at three in the morning?

sense.definition: used when talking about unpleasant or negative things or ideas, to make what you are saying sound less strong

sense.definition: small objects or items of various kinds
examples: She stuffed all the bits and pieces into a bag and left.

sense.definition: impatient to do or start doing something
examples: Gerry's champing at the bit to go to college.

sense.definition: to do your share of a task
examples: We can finish this job on time if everyone does their bit.

sense.definition: just as good, bad, etc.; equally good, bad, etc.
examples: Rome is every bit as beautiful as Paris.

sense.definition: to become very enthusiastic about something that you have started to do so that you are unlikely to stop until you have finished
not at all; not in any way
examples: “Are you cold?” “Not a bit.”

sense.definition: a fairly large amount or degree
examples: “How much does he earn?” “Quite a bit, I’m told.”

sense.definition: into small pieces
examples: The car was blown to bits in the explosion.

sense.definition: very much
examples: I love my kids to bits.

sense.definition: to use your teeth to cut into or through something

sense.definition: to wound someone by making a small hole or mark in their skin

sense.definition: if a fish bites, it takes food from the hook of a fishing line and may get caught

examples: They tried to sell us a fake Picasso, but we didn’t bite.

sense.definition: to have an unpleasant effect
examples: The recession is beginning to bite.

sense.definition: used to say that something is very bad
examples: Let’s leave…this movie really bites!

sense.definition: to develop a strong interest in, or enthusiasm for, something
examples: He's been bitten by the travel bug.

sense.definition: to start to deal with an unpleasant or difficult situation which cannot be avoided
examples: I wasn't happy with the way my career was going, so I decided to bite the bullet and look for another job.

sense.definition: to fail, or to be defeated or destroyed
examples: Thousands of small businesses bite the dust every year.

sense.definition: to die
to harm someone who has helped you or supported you
to shout at someone in an angry way, especially without reason
to stop yourself from saying something or from showing an emotion
to try to do too much, or something that is too difficult
to stop yourself from saying something that might upset someone or cause an argument, although you want to speak
examples: I didn't believe her explanation, but I bit my tongue.

sense.definition: used when someone says something stupid or embarrassing and immediately wishes they had not said it
after an unpleasant experience you are careful to avoid something similar
very serious and unpleasant, with a lot of anger and hatred involved
examples: a long and bitter dispute

Certain people might disagree with this.
They refused to release their hostages unless certain conditions were met.

sense.definition: used with a person's name to show that the speaker does not know the person
examples: It was a certain Dr. Davis who performed the operation.

sense.definition: slight; noticeable, but difficult to describe
examples: That's true, to a certain extent.
I felt there was a certain coldness in her manner.

sense.definition: without doubt
examples: I can't say for certain when we'll arrive.

sense.definition: to find out whether something is definitely true
examples: I think there's a bus at 8 but you'd better call to make certain.

sense.definition: to do something in order to be sure that something else will happen
examples: You'll have to leave soon to make certain of getting there on time.

sense.definition: if you talk about a person being of a certain age, you mean that they are no longer young but not yet old
examples: The show appeals to an audience of a certain age.

sense.definition: without doubt
examples: Without treatment, she will almost certainly die.
Certainly, the early years are crucial to a child's development.
I'm certainly never going there again.
She was certainly attractive but you couldn't call her beautiful.
Surely this can’t be right?
Surely you’re not thinking of going, are you?
I’ll certainly remember this trip!
I’ll sure remember this trip!
She's certainly too busy to see you this week ( = there is no doubt about it)
Surely she's too busy to see you this week ( = that is my opinion. Don’t you agree?).
This will surely end in disaster.
While the movie is undoubtedly too long, it is nevertheless an intriguing work of art.
It can be argued that the movie is too long. It is nonetheless an intriguing work of art.
The movie is undoubtedly too long. Still, it is an intriguing work of art.
Of course, huge chunks of the book have been sacrificed in order to make a two-hour movie, but it is nevertheless a successful piece of storytelling.
Critics are wrong to argue that the movie's plot is too complicated. Certainly there are a couple of major twists, but audiences will have no difficulty following them.
It is true that you cannot make a good movie without a good script, but it is equally true that a talented director can make a good script into an excellent movie.
It remains to be seen whether these two movies herald a new era of westerns, but there is no doubt that they represent welcome additions to the genre.

sense.definition: of course
examples: “May I see your passport, Mr. Scott?” “Certainly.”
“Do you think all this money will change your life?” “Certainly not.”

sense.definition: an official document that may be used to prove that the facts it states are true
examples: a birth/marriage/death certificate

sense.definition: an official document proving that you have completed a course of study or passed an exam; a qualification obtained after a course of study or an exam
examples: an elementary teaching certificate

sense.definition: a series of connected metal rings, used for pulling or fastening things; a length of chain used for a particular purpose
examples: a short length of chain

a bicycle chain

sense.definition: a series of connected things or people
examples: to set in motion a chain of events
a chain of command ( = a system in an organization by which instructions are passed from one person to another)

sense.definition: a group of stores or hotels owned by the same company
examples: a chain of supermarkets/a supermarket chain

sense.definition: a thing that restricts someone's freedom or ability to do something
examples: the chains of fear/misery

sense.definition: a problem that prevents you from doing what you would like to do
one of the stages in a process or a line of argument
examples: Food production, processing and marketing are different links in the chain from farmer to consumer.

sense.definition: the point at which a system or an organization is most likely to fail
examples: She went straight for the one weak link in the chain of his argument.

sense.definition: a piece of furniture for one person to sit on, with a back, a seat, and four legs
examples: a table and chairs

an old man asleep in a chair ( = an armchair )
dining/kitchen chairs

sense.definition: the person in charge of a department in a university
examples: He is the chair of philosophy at Stanford.

sense.definition: the person in charge of a meeting, who tells people when they can speak, etc.
the person in charge of a committee, a company, etc.
examples: the chairman of the board of directors

They have a male nanny for their sons.
Everyone needs to feel he is loved.
Does everybody know what they want?
Somebody’s left their coat here.
I hope nobody’s forgotten to bring their passport with them.
Everyone knows what’s best for him or herself.
If in doubt, ask your doctor. He/she can give you more information.
A baby cries when he or she is tired,
Babies cry when they are tired.

sense.definition: a woman in charge of a meeting, a committee, or an organization
examples: My daughter prefers to see a female doctor.
They have a male nanny for their sons.
Everyone needs to feel he is loved.
Does everybody know what they want?
Somebody’s left their coat here.
I hope nobody’s forgotten to bring their passport with them.
Everyone knows what’s best for him or herself.
If in doubt, ask your doctor. He/she can give you more information.
A baby cries when he or she is tired,
Babies cry when they are tired.

sense.definition: a new or difficult task that tests someone's ability and skill

to face a challenge ( = to have to deal with one)
Destruction of the environment is one of the most serious challenges we face.

We rose to the challenge and figured out a way to do it.

sense.definition: an invitation or a suggestion to someone that they should enter a competition, fight, etc.
examples: to accept/take up a challenge

sense.definition: a statement or an action that shows that someone refuses to accept something and questions whether it is right, legal, etc.
examples: It was a direct challenge to the president's authority.

sense.definition: a demand that someone stop and provide proof of their identity
examples: The sentry's challenge forced them to stop and show their identification.

sense.definition: an occasion at the beginning of a court case when a lawyer formally questions whether a possible member of a jury is qualified or suitable for that position
a room used for the particular purpose that is mentioned
examples: a burial chamber

sense.definition: a space under the ground that is almost completely closed on all sides
examples: They found themselves in a vast underground chamber.

sense.definition: a space in the body, in a plant, or in a machine, that is separated from the rest
examples: the chambers of the heart
the rocket's combustion chamber
the chamber of a gun ( = the part that holds the bullets)

sense.definition: an office used by a judge
a room in a public building that is used for formal meetings
examples: the Senate/House chamber

sense.definition: one of the parts of a parliament
examples: the Chamber of Deputies in the Italian parliament

sense.definition: a bedroom or private room
examples: Lady Eleanor was found dead in her chamber.

sense.definition: a possibility of something happening, especially something that you want
examples: Is there any chance of getting tickets for tonight?
She has only a slim chance of passing the exam.
There's a slight chance that he'll be back in time.
There is no chance that he will change his mind.
What chance is there of anybody being found alive?
Nowadays a premature baby has a very good chance of survival.
The operation has a fifty-fifty chance of success.
an outside chance ( = a very small one)
The chances are a million to one against being struck by lightning.

sense.definition: a suitable time or situation when you have the opportunity to do something
examples: It was the chance she had been waiting for.
Jeff deceived me once already—I won't give him a second chance.
This is your big chance ( = opportunity for success).
I just had to accept the offer. It was the chance of a lifetime ( = an opportunity that you only get once).
We won't get another chance of a vacation this year.
Please give me a chance to explain.
Tonight is your last chance to catch the play at your local theater.
She jumped at the chance ( = eagerly took the chance) to play the role.
There will be a chance for parents to look around the school.

sense.definition: an unpleasant or dangerous possibility
examples: When installing electrical equipment don't take any chances. A mistake could kill.
The car might break down but that's a chance we'll have to take.

sense.definition: the way that some things happen without any cause that you can see or understand
examples: I met her by chance ( = without planning to) at the airport.
Chess is not a game of chance.
It was pure chance that we were both there.
We'll plan everything very carefully and leave nothing to chance.
This ring has always brought me good luck.
The results could simply be due to chance.
They met through a series of strange coincidences.
I discovered the book by accident while shopping for a birthday present.
Fate decreed that she would not get married that day.
I believe there's some force guiding us—call it God, destiny, or fate.

sense.definition: happening in a way that was lucky, although it was not planned
examples: As chance would have it, John was going to San Francisco too, so I went with him.

sense.definition: used especially in questions, to ask whether something is true, possible, etc.
examples: Are you in love with him, by any chance?

sense.definition: it is likely that…
examples: Chances are you won't have to pay.

sense.definition: used for saying that you do not believe something is likely to happen
examples: “They might let us in without tickets.” “Fat chance of that!”

sense.definition: a small chance of being successful if a great effort is made
examples: We still have a fighting chance of beating them and winning the tournament.

sense.definition: to give someone or something some opportunity to do something
examples: That dog will give you a nasty bite, given half a chance.

sense.definition: to be equally likely to do or not do something
examples: She has more than an even chance of winning tomorrow.
There's an even chance that the jury will find him guilty.

sense.definition: there is no possibility
examples: “Do you think he'll do it?” “No chance.”

sense.definition: to have no chance at all
because of the possibility of something happening, although it is unlikely
examples: I didn't think you'd be at home but I just stopped by on the off chance.

sense.definition: a reasonable chance of success
to have the possibility of succeeding or achieving something
examples: The driver didn't stand a chance of stopping in time.

sense.definition: to decide to do something, knowing that it might be the wrong choice
examples: We took a chance on the weather and planned to have the party outside.

sense.definition: to take a risk or to use the opportunities that you have and hope that things will happen in the way that you want
examples: He took his chances and jumped into the water.

sense.definition: to become different
examples: Rick hasn't changed. He looks exactly the same as he did at school.

sense.definition: to make someone or something different
examples: Fame hasn't really changed him.

sense.definition: to pass or make someone or something pass from one state or form into another
examples: Wait for the traffic lights to change.

sense.definition: to stop having one state, position, or direction and start having another
examples: Leaves change color in the fall.

sense.definition: to replace one thing, person, service, etc. with something new or different

sense.definition: to put clean sheets, etc. on a bed

sense.definition: to exchange money for the same amount in different coins or bills

sense.definition: to put a motor vehicle or a bicycle into a different gear

sense.definition: to pass to a different owner

sense.definition: to change to a different or new activity while you are in the middle of something else; to change from supporting one person or thing to another

sense.definition: to be in someone else's situation

sense.definition: to start to live or behave in a different way from before

sense.definition: a television station

sense.definition: a band of radio waves used for broadcasting television or radio programs

sense.definition: an interesting or unusual person

sense.definition: an idea or a principle that is connected with something abstract

concepts such as “civilization” and “government”

the concept that everyone should have equality of opportunity
a new concept in teaching

sense.definition: to affect someone; to involve someone
examples: Don't interfere in what doesn't concern you.
The loss was a tragedy for all concerned ( = all those affected by it).

The individuals concerned have some explaining to do.

Everyone who was directly concerned in ( = had some responsibility for) the incident has now resigned.

sense.definition: to be about something
examples: The story concerns the prince's efforts to rescue Pamina.
The book is primarily concerned with Soviet-American relations during the Cold War.

sense.definition: to worry someone
examples: What concerns me is our lack of preparation for the change.

sense.definition: to take an interest in something
examples: He didn't concern himself with the details.

sense.definition: to think it is important to do something
examples: She was concerned to write about situations that everyone could identify with.

sense.definition: used to give your personal opinion on something
examples: As far as I'm concerned, you can do whatever you want.

sense.definition: used to give facts or an opinion about a particular aspect of something
examples: She's doing fine as far as French is concerned, it's her German I'm worried about.

sense.definition: worried and feeling concern about something
examples: Concerned parents held a meeting.
The president is deeply concerned about this issue.
He didn't seem in the least concerned for her safety.
She was concerned that she might miss the turn and get lost.
a very nervous man
a worried man

sense.definition: interested in something
examples: They were more concerned with how the others had dressed than with what the speaker was saying.

sense.definition: used to give your personal opinion on something
examples: As far as I'm concerned, you can do whatever you want.

sense.definition: used to give facts or an opinion about a particular aspect of something
examples: She's doing fine as far as French is concerned, it's her German I'm worried about.

sense.definition: about something; involving someone or something
examples: He asked several questions concerning the future of the company.
All cases concerning children are dealt with in juvenile court.

sense.definition: a public performance of music
examples: a concert of music by Bach
a classical/rock concert
They're in concert at Madison Square Garden.
a concert hall/pianist

sense.definition: working together with someone or something
to decide or believe something as a result of what you have heard or seen
examples: What do you conclude from that?
The report concluded (that) the cheapest option was to close the laboratory.

“So it should be safe to continue,” he concluded.
