Based on this study, it can be concluded that the introduction of new street lighting did not reduce reported crime.
To sum up, no evidence can be found to support the view that improved street lighting reduces reported crime.
The available evidence clearly leads to the conclusion that the media do have an influence on the public perception of crime.
The main conclusion to be drawn from this study is that the public perception of crime is significantly influenced by crime news reporting.
This study has shown that people's fear of crime is out of all proportion to crime itself.
Fear of crime is out of all proportion to the actual level of crime, and the reasons for this can be summarized as follows. First…
Overall/In general, women are more likely than men to feel insecure walking alone after dark.

sense.definition: to come to an end; to bring something to an end
examples: Let me make just a few concluding remarks.
The program concluded with Stravinsky's “Rite of Spring.”
He concluded by wishing everyone a safe trip home.
The commission concluded its investigation last month.

“Anyway, she should be back soon,” he concluded.

sense.definition: to arrange and settle an agreement with someone formally and finally
examples: They concluded a treaty with Turkey.
A trade agreement was concluded between the two countries.

sense.definition: something that you decide when you have thought about all the information connected with the situation
examples: I've come to the conclusion that he's not the right person for the job.

The inconclusive findings of these studies indicate the need for additional research.

The virus most likely originated from animals, but evidence remains inconclusive.

sense.definition: the end of something such as a speech or a piece of writing
examples: The conclusion of the book was disappointing.
In conclusion, ( = finally) I would like to thank…

sense.definition: the formal and final arrangement of something official
examples: the successful conclusion of a trade treaty

sense.definition: if you say that something is a foregone conclusion, you mean that it is a result that is certain to happen
examples: The outcome of the vote is a foregone conclusion.

sense.definition: to make a decision about someone or something too quickly, before you know or have thought about all the facts
examples: There I go again—jumping to conclusions.

sense.definition: made of concrete
examples: a concrete floor

sense.definition: based on facts, not on ideas or guesses
examples: concrete evidence/proposals/proof

sense.definition: a concrete object is one that you can see and feel
the state that something is in
examples: to be in bad/good/excellent condition
a used car in perfect condition

sense.definition: the circumstances or situation in which people live, work, or do things

sense.definition: the physical situation that affects how something happens
examples: The plants grow best in cool, damp conditions.

sense.definition: the state of someone's health or how physically fit they are
examples: He is overweight and out of condition ( = not physically fit).

sense.definition: an illness or a medical problem that you have for a long time because it is not possible to cure it

a rare disorder of the liver
a sinus infection
an ear infection
a heart condition

sense.definition: a rule or decision that you must agree to, sometimes forming part of a contract or an official agreement

sense.definition: a situation that must exist in order for something else to happen

sense.definition: the state of a particular group of people because of their situation in life, their problems, etc.

sense.definition: new or as good as new; in perfect condition
not in any situation; never

sense.definition: to organize and/or do a particular activity
examples: to conduct an experiment/an investigation/a survey

sense.definition: to direct a group of people who are singing or playing music

sense.definition: to allow heat or electricity to pass along or through it
examples: Copper conducts electricity well.

sense.definition: to behave in a particular way

sense.definition: to lead or guide someone through or around a place

sense.definition: a large official meeting, usually lasting for a few days, at which people with the same work or interests come together to discuss their views

sense.definition: a meeting at which people have formal discussions
examples: Representatives from all four countries involved will meet at the conference table this week.

sense.definition: a group of sports teams that play against each other in a league
examples: Southeast Conference football champions

sense.definition: the feeling that you can trust, believe in, and be sure about the abilities or good qualities of someone or something
examples: The players all have confidence in their manager.

sense.definition: a belief in your own ability to do things and be successful
examples: He answered the questions with confidence.

sense.definition: the feeling that you are certain about something
examples: They could not say with confidence that he would be able to walk again after the accident.

sense.definition: a feeling of trust that someone will keep information private
examples: Eva told me about their relationship in confidence.

sense.definition: a secret that you tell someone

sense.definition: to be trusted with someone's secrets
examples: He is said to be very much in the President's confidence.

sense.definition: to tell someone secrets and personal information about yourself
examples: She took me into her confidence and told me about the problems she was facing.

sense.definition: feeling sure about your own ability to do things and be successful
examples: She was feeling relaxed and confident.

sense.definition: to make someone feel or believe something even more strongly

sense.definition: to make a position, an agreement, etc. more definite or official; to establish someone or something firmly

sense.definition: a situation in which there are opposing ideas, opinions, feelings, or wishes; a situation in which it is difficult to choose
examples: The story tells of a classic conflict between love and duty.

sense.definition: a situation in which there are two jobs, aims, roles, etc., and it is not possible for both of them to be treated equally and fairly at the same time

sense.definition: to appear and need to be dealt with by someone

sense.definition: to deal with a problem or difficult situation

sense.definition: to make a subject more difficult to understand

sense.definition: not clear or easy to understand

sense.definition: difficult to understand; not clear

sense.definition: the fact of making a mistake about who someone is or what something is

sense.definition: the way in which words, actions, statements, etc., are understood by someone synonym interpretation
examples: What construction do you put on this letter ( = what do you think it means)?

sense.definition: to go to someone for information or advice
examples: If the pain continues, consult your doctor.
Have you consulted your lawyer about this?
Consult with your physician about possible treatments.

sense.definition: to discuss something with someone to get their permission for something, or to help you make a decision
examples: You shouldn't have done it without consulting me.
I expect to be consulted about major issues.
I need to consult with my colleagues on the proposals.
We talked on the phone for over an hour.
Have you discussed the problem with anyone?
I've spoken to the manager about it.
“Can I speak with Susan?” “Speaking.” ( = at the beginning of a telephone conversation)
Have you talked to your parents about the problems you're having?
I've spoken to Ed about it and he's promised not to let it happen again.
We only communicate by e-mail.
Dolphins use sound to communicate with each other.
Politicians will be debating the bill later this week.
You shouldn't have changed your plans without consulting me.

sense.definition: to look in or at something to get information
examples: He consulted the manual.

sense.definition: a person who buys goods or uses services
examples: consumer demand/choice/rights
Health-conscious consumers want more information about the food they buy.
a consumer society ( = one where buying and selling is considered very important)
providers and consumers of public services
Tax cuts will boost consumer confidence after the recession.

sense.definition: the act of communicating with someone, especially regularly
examples: I don't have much contact with my uncle.
There is little contact between the two organizations.
Have you kept in contact with any of your friends from college ( = do you still see them or speak or write to them)?
She's lost contact with ( = no longer sees or writes to) her son.
I finally made contact with ( = succeeded in speaking to or meeting) her in Paris.
The organization put me in contact with other people in a similar position ( = gave me their addresses or telephone numbers).
two people avoiding eye contact ( = avoiding looking directly at each other)
Here's my contact number ( = temporary telephone number) while I'm away.

sense.definition: the state of touching something
examples: His fingers were briefly in contact with the ball.
This substance should not come into contact with food.
a fear of physical contact
She blushed at the sudden contact of his hand against her arm.
This pesticide kills insects on contact ( = as soon as it touches them).
This chemical is liable to explode on contact with water.

sense.definition: the state of meeting someone or having to deal with something
examples: In her job she often comes into contact with ( = meets) lawyers.
Children should be brought into contact with poetry at an early age.

sense.definition: an occasion on which you meet or communicate with someone; a relationship with someone
examples: We have good contacts with the local community.
The company has maintained trade contacts with India.

sense.definition: a person that you know, especially someone who can be helpful to you in your work
examples: social/personal contacts
I've made some useful contacts in journalism.
She has several contacts in New York.

sense.definition: an electrical connection
examples: The switches close the contacts and complete the circuit.

sense.definition: a person who may be infectious because he or she has recently been near to someone with a contagious disease
a place where you go or a person that you speak to when you are dealing with an organization
examples: The receptionist is the first point of contact most people have with the clinic.

sense.definition: if something contains something else, it has that thing inside it or as part of it
examples: This drink doesn't contain any alcohol.
Her statement contained one or two inaccuracies.
a brown envelope containing dollar bills
The bottle contains ( = can hold) two quarts.

sense.definition: to keep your feelings under control
examples: She was unable to contain her excitement.
I was so furious I just couldn't contain myself ( = I had to express my feelings).

sense.definition: to prevent something harmful from spreading or getting worse
examples: to contain an epidemic
Government forces have failed to contain the rebellion.

sense.definition: to be able to be divided exactly by a number
examples: Ten contains five and two, but not three.

sense.definition: a box, bottle, etc., in which something can be stored or transported
examples: Food will last longer if kept in an airtight container.

sense.definition: a large metal or wooden box of a standard size in which goods are packed so that they can easily be lifted onto a ship, train, etc., to be transported
examples: a container ship ( = one designed to transport such containers)

sense.definition: belonging to the present time synonym modern
examples: contemporary fiction/music/dance

sense.definition: belonging to the same time
examples: We have no contemporary account of the battle ( = written near the time that it happened).
He was contemporary with the dramatist Congreve.

sense.definition: the things that are contained in something
examples: He tipped the contents of the bag onto the table.
Fire has caused severe damage to the contents of the building.
She hadn't read the letter and so was unaware of its contents.

sense.definition: the different sections that are contained in a book
examples: a table of contents ( = the list at the front of a book)
a contents page

sense.definition: the subject matter of a book, speech, program, etc.
examples: Your tone of voice is as important as the content of what you have to say.
The content of the course depends on what the students would like to study.
Her poetry has a good deal of political content.

sense.definition: the amount of a substance that is contained in something else
examples: food with a high fat content
the alcohol content of a drink

sense.definition: the information or other material contained on a Web site or CD-ROM
examples: online content providers

sense.definition: a competition in which people try to win something
examples: a singing contest
a talent contest
to enter/win/lose a contest

sense.definition: a struggle to gain control or power
examples: a contest for the leadership of the party

sense.definition: used to say that one side in a competition is so much stronger or better than the other that it is sure to win easily
the situation in which something happens and that helps you to understand it
examples: This speech needs to be set in the context of the U.S. in the 1960s.
His decision can only be understood in context.
Such databases are being used in a wide range of contexts.

sense.definition: the words that come just before and after a word, phrase, or statement, and help you to understand its meaning
examples: You should be able to guess the meaning of the word from the context.
This quotation has been taken out of context ( = repeated without giving the circumstances in which it was said).

sense.definition: one of the large land masses of the earth such as Europe, Asia, or Africa
examples: the continent of Africa
the African continent

sense.definition: to keep existing or happening without stopping
examples: The exhibition continues until July 25th.
The trial is expected to continue for three months.
The rain will continue into the evening.
The rain continued to fall all afternoon.
The number of car accident deaths is continuing to decline.
The rain continued falling all afternoon.

sense.definition: to keep doing something without stopping
examples: She wanted to continue working until she was 60.
He vowed to continue fighting.
He continued to ignore everything I was saying.
Are you going to continue with the project?
The FBI is continuing its investigations.

sense.definition: to go or move further in the same direction
examples: The path continued over rough, rocky ground.
He continued on his way.

sense.definition: to remain in a particular job or condition
examples: I want you to continue as project manager.
She will continue in her present job until a replacement can be found.

sense.definition: to start or start something again after stopping for a time
examples: The story continues in our next issue.
The story will be continued in our next issue.

sense.definition: to start speaking again after stopping
examples: Please continue—I didn't mean to interrupt.
“In fact,” he continued, “I'd like to congratulate you.”

sense.definition: happening or existing for a period of time without interruption
examples: Recovery after the accident will be a continuous process that may take several months.
Stop smoking and you will see a continuous improvement in your health.
She was in continuous employment until the age of sixty-five.
The rain has been continuous since this morning.

sense.definition: spreading in a line or over an area without any spaces
examples: a continuous line of traffic
Rain was falling outside in a continuous silver curtain.

sense.definition: repeated many times
examples: For four days the town suffered continuous attacks.
the continuous tenses
He has lived and worked in France almost continuously since 1990.
the continuously changing situation
Heat the mixture until thickened, stirring continuously.

sense.definition: an official written agreement
examples: a contract of employment
a research contract
to enter into/make/sign a contract with the supplier
These clauses form part of the contract between buyer and seller.
a contract for the supply of vehicles
to win/be awarded a contract to build a new school
a contract worker ( = one employed on a contract for a fixed period of time)
I was on a three-year contract that expired last week.
Under the terms of the contract the job should have been finished yesterday.
She is under contract to ( = has a contract to work for) a major American computer firm.
The offer has been accepted, subject to contract ( = the agreement is not official until the contract is signed).
They were sued for breach of contract ( = not keeping to a contract).

sense.definition: an agreement to kill someone for money
examples: to take out a contract on someone

sense.definition: a difference between two or more people or things that you can see clearly when they are compared or put close together; the fact of comparing two or more things in order to show the differences between them
examples: There is an obvious contrast between the cultures of East and West.
The company lost $7 million this quarter in contrast to a profit of $6.2 million a year earlier.
The situation when we arrived was in marked contrast to the news reports.
The poverty of her childhood stands in total contrast to her life in Hollywood.
to show a sharp/stark/striking contrast with something
A wool jacket complements the silk shirt and provides an interesting contrast in texture.
When you look at their new system, ours seems very old-fashioned by contrast.
Careful contrast of the two plans shows some important differences.

sense.definition: a person or thing that is clearly different from someone or something else
examples: The work you did today is quite a contrast to ( = very much better/worse than) what you did last week.

sense.definition: differences in color or in light and dark, used in photographs and paintings to create a special effect
examples: The artist's use of contrast is masterly.

sense.definition: the amount of difference between light and dark in a picture on a television, computer, etc., screen
examples: Use this button to adjust the contrast.

sense.definition: very different in style, color, or attitude
examples: bright, contrasting colors
The book explores contrasting views of the poet's early work.

sense.definition: to give something, especially money or goods, to help someone or something
examples: We contributed $5,000 to the earthquake fund.
Would you like to contribute to our cause?
Do you want to contribute?

sense.definition: to be one of the causes of something
examples: Medical negligence could have contributed to her death.
Childhood obesity can cause/lead to long-term health problems.
Changes in lifestyle and diet over the last twenty years have caused/led to/resulted in a sharp increase in childhood obesity.
Several factors, including changes in diet and lifestyle, have contributed to the increase in childhood obesity.
Research suggests that fast food and soft drinks directly contribute to childhood obesity.
Genetics, lifestyle, and diet are all important factors in cases of childhood obesity.
Even small changes in lifestyle and diet can bring about significant weight loss.

sense.definition: to increase, improve, or add to something
examples: Immigrants have contributed to American culture in many ways.
This book does not contribute much to our understanding of the subject.

sense.definition: to write things for a newspaper, magazine, or a radio or television program; to speak during a meeting or conversation, especially to give your opinion
examples: She contributed a number of articles to the magazine.
He contributes regularly to the magazine “New Scientist.”
We hope everyone will contribute to the discussion.
Human error may have been a contributing factor

sense.definition: a sum of money that is given to a person or an organization in order to help pay for something
examples: to make a contribution to charity
a generous contribution
All contributions will be gratefully received.
valuable contributions toward the maintenance of the cathedral

sense.definition: a sum of money that you pay regularly, often to your employer or the government, for benefits such as health insurance, a retirement plan, etc.
examples: monthly contributions to the retirement account
unemployment insurance contributions
ten monthly payments of $50
payment in advance
an insurance premium
a premium for express delivery
You can increase your monthly contributions to your savings account.
a subscription to “Newsweek”
to set up a repayment plan
We've put down a 5% deposit on the house.
I made a $500 deposit into my checking account.
We paid for the car by/in installments.

sense.definition: an action or a service that helps to cause or increase something
examples: He made a very positive contribution to the success of the project.
a significant contribution to scientific knowledge
the car's contribution to the greenhouse effect
These measures would make a valuable contribution toward reducing industrial accidents.
Moreover, graduates can use their knowledge and skills in ways that contribute positively to their communities.
Relatively small areas of the city contribute disproportionately to the violent crime rate.
Coral reefs in the oceans significantly contribute to the removal of atmospheric carbon dioxide.
The authors suggest that low proficiency in academic language is a contributing factor to academic failure.
Irving Fisher made seminal contributions to modern financial economics.

sense.definition: an item that forms part of a book, magazine, broadcast, discussion, etc.
examples: an important contribution to the debate
All contributions for the May issue must be received by Friday.

sense.definition: the act of giving something, especially money, to help a person or an organization
the power to make decisions about how a country, an area, an organization, etc. is run
examples: The party is expecting to gain control of City Hall in the next election.
The Democrats will probably lose control of Congress.
A military junta took control of the country.
The city is in the control of enemy forces.
The city is under enemy control.

sense.definition: the ability to make someone or something do what you want
examples: The teacher had no control over the children.
She struggled to keep control of her voice.
She lost control of her car on the ice.
He got so angry he lost control ( = shouted and said or did things he would not normally do).
Due to circumstances beyond our control, the flight to Nashville has been canceled.
The coach made the team work hard on ball control ( = in a ball game).

sense.definition: the act of restricting, limiting, or managing something; a method of doing this
examples: traffic control
gun control
talks on arms control
government controls on business and industry
A new advance has been made in the control of malaria.
Price controls on food were ended.
a pest control officer
The government has set strict limits on spending.
the speed limit
There are no restrictions on the amount of money you can withdraw.
crowd control
The agency is operating under severe budget constraints.
The new law has imposed restraints on exports to Russia.
They would resist any limitation of their powers.
moral/social/cultural restraints.

sense.definition: the switches and buttons, etc. that you use to operate a machine or a vehicle
examples: the controls of an aircraft
the control panel
the volume control of a CD player
The co-pilot was at the controls when the plane landed.
a car with dual control(s) ( = one set of controls for the driver and one for the instructor ).

sense.definition: (on a computer keyboard) a key that you press when you want to perform a particular operation
a person, thing, or group used as a standard of comparison for checking the results of a scientific experiment; an experiment whose result is known, used for checking working methods
examples: The study showed that women with the disease have had fewer children than the controls.
One group was treated with the new drug, and the control group was given a sugar pill.

sense.definition: a place where orders are given or where checks are made; the people who work in this place
examples: air traffic control
We went through passport control and into the departure lounge.
This is Mission Control calling the space shuttle Discovery.

sense.definition: to direct or manage an organization, an area, or a situation
examples: He's reached retiring age, but he's still firmly in control.
There was some rioting, but the police are now in control.

sense.definition: to be able to organize your life well and keep calm
examples: In spite of all her family problems, she's really in control.

sense.definition: to be or become impossible to manage or to control
examples: The children are completely out of control since their father left.
A truck ran out of control on the hill.

sense.definition: to be being dealt with successfully
examples: Don't worry—everything's under control!

sense.definition: to succeed in dealing with something so that it does not cause any damage or hurt anyone
examples: It took two hours to bring the fire under control.
Please keep your dog under control!

sense.definition: done or arranged in a very careful way
examples: a controlled explosion
a controlled environment
He played very controlled tennis.

sense.definition: limited, or managed by law or by rules
examples: controlled airspace

sense.definition: managed by a particular group, or in a particular way
examples: a U.S.-controlled company
computer-controlled systems

sense.definition: remaining calm and not getting angry or upset
examples: She remained quiet and controlled.

sense.definition: useful, easy, or quick to do; not causing problems
examples: It is very convenient to pay by credit card.
You'll find these meals quick and convenient to prepare.
Fruit is a convenient source of vitamins and energy.
A bicycle is often more convenient than a car in cities.
I can't see him now—it isn't convenient.
I'll call back at a more convenient time.
He used his wife's birthday as a convenient excuse for not going to the meeting.

sense.definition: near to a particular place; easy to get to
examples: The hotel is convenient to downtown.
The report can be conveniently divided into three main sections.
The hotel is conveniently situated close to the beach.
She conveniently forgot to mention that her husband would be at the party, too ( = because it suited her not to say).

sense.definition: a large meeting of the members of a profession, a political party, etc. synonym conference
examples: to hold a convention
the Democratic Party Convention ( = to elect a candidate for President)

sense.definition: the way in which something is done that most people in a society expect and consider to be polite or the right way to do it
examples: social conventions
By convention the co-chair was always a woman.
She is a young woman who enjoys going against conventions.
Convention demands that a club member should resign in such a situation.

sense.definition: an official agreement between countries or leaders
examples: the Geneva convention
the United Nations convention on the rights of the child

sense.definition: a traditional method or style in literature, art, or the theater
examples: the conventions of Greek tragedy

sense.definition: tending to follow what is done or considered acceptable by society in general; normal and ordinary, and perhaps not very interesting
examples: conventional behavior/morality
She's very conventional in her views.

sense.definition: following what is traditional or the way something has been done for a long time
examples: conventional methods/approaches
It's not a hotel, in the conventional sense, but rather a whole village turned into a hotel.

sense.definition: not nuclear
examples: conventional forces/weapons
A conventional war would still cause unacceptable devastation.
a conventional power station ( = using oil or coal as fuel, rather than nuclear power)
conventionally dressed
conventionally grown food ( = grown according to conventional methods)
Though not conventionally pretty ( = not pretty according to generally accepted ideas of what is pretty), she dressed with flair.
Gross National Product (GNP) is conventionally used to indicate economic development.

sense.definition: the view or belief that most people hold
examples: Conventional wisdom has it that riots only ever happen in cities.

sense.definition: an informal talk involving a small group of people or only two; the activity of talking in this way
examples: a telephone conversation
I had a long conversation with her the other day.
The main topic of conversation was the probable outcome of the election.
Don was deep in conversation with the girl on his right.
to get into a conversation with someone
The conversation turned to gardening.
I tried to make conversation ( = to speak in order to appear polite).
He struggled to keep the conversation going.
I see no point in continuing this conversation.
She tried to steer the conversation away from the topic of marriage.
He felt a sudden alarm at the turn the conversation was taking.
Discussions are still taking place between the two countries.
a telephone conversation
The novel has long descriptions and not much dialogue.
The leaders engaged in a constructive dialogue about climate change.
I had a long talk with my boss about my career prospects.
a debate over prison reform
The proposal was based on extensive consultations with leading scientists.
Could I have a quick chat with you?
Office gossip can be nasty and cruel.

sense.definition: to change or make something change from one form, purpose, system, etc., to another
examples: The hotel is going to be converted into a nursing home.
The club is a converted warehouse.
What rate will I get if I convert my dollars into euros?
Hot water is converted to electricity by a turbine.
We converted from oil to gas central heating.

sense.definition: to be able to be changed from one form, purpose, or system to another
examples: a sofa that converts into a bed

sense.definition: to change or make someone change their religion or beliefs
examples: He converted from Christianity to Islam.
She was soon converted to the socialist cause.

sense.definition: to change an opinion, a habit, etc.
examples: I converted to organic food.
I didn't use to like opera but my husband has converted me.

sense.definition: to score extra points after a touchdown
to speak to people in support of views that they already hold
to make someone/yourself believe that something is true
examples: You'll need to convince them of your enthusiasm for the job.
I'd convinced myself (that) I was right.
The experience convinced him that the region was on the brink of a revolution.

sense.definition: to persuade someone to do something
examples: I've been trying to convince him to see a doctor.
I tried to persuade her to see a doctor.
He convinced me that he was right.
I persuaded/convinced her to see a doctor.

sense.definition: to prepare food by heating it, for example by boiling, baking, or frying it
examples: Where did you learn to cook?
What's the best way to cook trout?
Who's going to cook supper?
Add the onion and cook for three minutes.
He cooked lunch for me.
He cooked me lunch.

sense.definition: to be prepared by boiling, baking, frying, etc.
examples: While the pasta is cooking, prepare the sauce.

sense.definition: to be planned secretly
examples: Everyone is being very secretive—there's something cooking.

sense.definition: to change facts or figures dishonestly or illegally
examples: His accountant had been cooking the books for years.

sense.definition: to ruin someone's chances of success
a small flat sweet cake for one person, usually baked until crisp
examples: chocolate chip cookies
a cookie jar

sense.definition: a smart/tough person
a computer file with information in it that is sent to the central server each time a particular person uses a network or the Internet
that is the situation and we cannot change it, so we must accept it
to vomit
the process of preparing food
examples: My husband does all the cooking.
a book on Indian cooking

sense.definition: food that has been prepared in a particular way
examples: The restaurant offers traditional home cooking ( = food similar to that cooked at home).
They serve good French cooking.

sense.definition: fairly cold; not hot or warm
examples: a cool breeze/drink/climate
Cooler weather is forecast for the weekend.
Let's sit in the shade and keep cool.
Store lemons in a cool dry place.
I'm cold. Turn the heat up.
It was bitterly cold outside.
a cold wind
hot and cold water
I often have cold pizza for breakfast.
a long cool drink
We found a cool place to sit.
It's absolutely freezing outside.
I'm freezing!
Bring a coat. It might get chilly later.
Her coffee was now lukewarm.
a glass of tepid water

sense.definition: making you feel pleasantly cool
examples: a room painted in cool greens and blues

sense.definition: used to show that you admire or approve of something or someone because they are fashionable, attractive, and often different
examples: You look pretty cool with that new haircut.
Dave's a really cool guy.
It's a cool movie.
We had a great time in Madrid.
I think their new song's really cool.
I had a fantastic vacation in Mexico.
Jane's a fabulous cook.
She's doing a terrific job.
The show was just awesome.

sense.definition: people say Cool! or That's cool to show that they approve of something or agree to a suggestion
examples: “We're going to the beach this afternoon.” “Cool!”
“Can you come at 10:30 tomorrow?” “That's cool.”
I was surprised that she got the job, but I'm cool with it ( = it's not a problem for me).

sense.definition: calm; not excited, angry, or emotional
examples: Keep cool!
She tried to remain cool, calm and collected ( = calm).
He has a cool head ( = he stays calm in an emergency).

sense.definition: not friendly, interested, or enthusiastic
examples: She was decidedly cool about the proposal.
He has been cool toward me ever since we had that argument.
They gave the Ambassador a cool reception.
Her voice was cool and dismissive.

sense.definition: calm and confident in a way that lacks respect for other people, but makes people admire you as well as disapprove
examples: She just took his keys and walked out with them, cool as you please.
He was a cool customer. No one would think to look for him in a city where he'd been arrested for killing a cop.

sense.definition: used about a sum of money to emphasize how large it is
examples: The car cost a cool thirty thousand.

sense.definition: very calm and controlled, especially in a difficult situation
to deal with a situation in a calm way and not show what you are really feeling
the fact of doing something together or of working together toward a shared aim
examples: a report produced by the government in cooperation with the chemical industry
We would like to see closer cooperation between parents and schools.

sense.definition: willingness to be helpful and do as you are asked
examples: We would be grateful for your cooperation in vacating the theater as quickly as possible.

sense.definition: to deal successfully with something difficult
examples: I got to the stage where I wasn't coping any more.
He wasn't able to cope with the stresses and strains of the job.
Desert plants are adapted to cope with extreme heat.

sense.definition: a thing that is made to be the same as something else, especially a document or a work of art
examples: I will send you a copy of the report.
The thieves replaced the original painting with a copy.
You should make a copy of the disk as a backup.

sense.definition: a single example of a book, newspaper, etc., of which many have been made
examples: a copy of “The New York Times”
The book sold 20,000 copies within two weeks.

sense.definition: written material that is to be printed in a newspaper, magazine, etc.; news or information that can be used in a newspaper article or advertisement
examples: The copy editors prepare the reporters' copy for the paper and write the headlines.
He writes copy for an online travel guide.
This will make great copy for the advertisement.
Could I have ten copies of this page, please?

sense.definition: the hard central part of a fruit such as an apple, that contains the seeds
the central part of an object
examples: the earth's core
the core of a nuclear reactor
The standards of housing and education are often lower in the older urban cores ( = the centers of towns or cities).

sense.definition: the most important or central part of something
examples: the core of the argument
Concern for the environment is at the core of our policies.

sense.definition: a small group of people who take part in a particular activity
examples: He gathered a small core of advisers around him.

sense.definition: so that the whole of a thing or a person is affected
examples: She was shaken to the core by the news.
He's a politician to the core ( = in all his attitudes and actions).

sense.definition: a part of something where two or more sides, lines, or edges join
examples: the four corners of a square
Write your name on the top right-hand corner of the paper.
I hit my knee on the corner of the table.
A smile lifted the corner of his mouth.
a speck of dirt in the corner of her eye

sense.definition: with the number of corners mentioned; involving the number of groups mentioned
examples: a three-cornered hat
a three-cornered fight

sense.definition: the place inside a room or a box where two sides join; the area around this place
examples: There was a television in the far corner of the room.
a corner table/seat/cupboard

sense.definition: a place where two streets join
examples: There was a group of youths standing on the street corner.
Turn right at the corner of Sunset and Crescent Heights Boulevards.
There's a hotel on/at the corner of my street.
The wind hit him as he turned the corner.

sense.definition: a sharp bend in a road
examples: The car was taking the corners too fast.

sense.definition: a region or an area of a place (sometimes used for one that is far away or difficult to reach)
examples: She lives in a quiet corner of rural Pennsylvania.
Students come here from the four corners of the world.
He knew every corner of the old town.

sense.definition: a difficult situation
examples: to back/drive/force someone into a corner
They had her in a corner, and there wasn't much she could do about it.
He was used to talking his way out of tight corners.

sense.definition: a free kick or hit that you take from the corner of your opponent's end of the field
examples: to take a corner
The referee awarded a corner.

sense.definition: any of the four corners of a ring 1; the supporters who help in the corner
very near
examples: Her house is just around the corner.
There were good times around the corner ( = they would soon come).

sense.definition: to go across the corner of an area and not around the sides of it, because it is quicker
examples: There's a worn patch on the grass because everyone cuts the corner.

sense.definition: to do something in the easiest, cheapest, or quickest way, often by ignoring rules or leaving something out
examples: To be competitive, they paid low wages and cut corners on workplace safety.

sense.definition: to see something by accident or not very clearly because you see it from the side of your eye and are not looking straight at it
examples: Out of the corner of her eye, she saw him coming closer.

sense.definition: a very difficult or dangerous situation
examples: She'll always help if you're in a tight spot.

sense.definition: to pass a very important point in an illness or a difficult situation and begin to improve
accurate or true, without any mistakes synonym right
examples: Do you have the correct time?
the correct answer
Please check that this information is correct.
“Are you in charge here?” “That's correct.”
Am I correct in saying that you know a lot about wine?
Are the following statements true or false?
Is it true that she's leaving?
I got about half the answers right.
Only one of the answers is correct.
Check that all the details are correct.

sense.definition: right and suitable, so that something is done as it should be done
examples: Do you know the correct way to shut the machine down?
I think you've made the correct decision.
You're right to be cautious.
You made the right decision.
“It's not easy.” “Yes, you're right.”
What's the correct way to shut the machine down?
I don't think she's correct to say that he's incompetent.

sense.definition: taking care to speak or behave in a way that follows the accepted standards or rules
examples: a correct young lady
He is always very correct in his speech.
Have you spelled it correctly?

sense.definition: so sick that you may die
examples: I suppose you won't be coming to the party if you're at death's door!

sense.definition: to worry or upset someone very much
examples: Those kids will be the death of me.

sense.definition: to catch a very bad cold
to survive in a situation where you could have died
to do or perform something so often that people become tired of seeing or hearing it
examples: That joke's been done to death.

sense.definition: a terrible thing that could happen
examples: At the last minute the hero saves her from a fate worse than death.

sense.definition: to fight until one of the two people or groups is dead, or until one person or group defeats the other
an event that seems good, but is certain to make something else fail
the possibility or belief that people continue to exist in some form after they die
examples: Do you believe in life after death?

sense.definition: to look or feel very sick or tired
used to describe a situation that is very important or serious
to kill someone as a punishment
examples: The prisoner will be put to death at dawn.

sense.definition: to frighten someone very much
examples: Spiders scare him to death.

sense.definition: extremely; very much
examples: to be bored to death
I'm sick to death of your endless criticism.

sense.definition: until someone is dead
examples: a fight to the death

sense.definition: an argument or discussion expressing different opinions
examples: a heated/wide-ranging/lively debate
the current debate about taxes
There had been much debate on the issue of childcare.
Whether he deserves what has happened to him is open to debate/a matter of/for debate ( = cannot be certain or decided yet).

sense.definition: a formal discussion of an issue at a public meeting or in government. In a debate, two or more speakers express opposing views and then there is often a vote on the issue
examples: a debate on abortion
The senator opened the debate ( = was the first to speak).
The motion under debate ( = being discussed) was put to a vote.
After a long debate, Congress approved the proposal.
Discussions are still taking place between the two countries.
a telephone conversation
The novel has long descriptions and not much dialogue.

I had a long talk with my boss about my career prospects.
a debate over prison reform
The proposal was based on extensive consultations with leading scientists.
Could I have a quick chat with you?

sense.definition: a sum of money that someone owes
examples: I need to pay off all my debts before I leave the country.
an outstanding debt of $300

sense.definition: the situation of owing money, especially when you cannot pay
examples: He died heavily in debt.
The club is $4 million in debt.
We were poor but we never got into debt.
It's hard to stay out of debt when you are a student.
a country's foreign debt burden

sense.definition: the fact that you should feel grateful to someone because they have helped you or been kind to you
examples: to owe a debt of gratitude to someone

sense.definition: to feel grateful to someone for their help, kindness, etc.
used to say that someone is being punished for a crime, usually by being put in prison
examples: He paid his debt to society for his previous convictions and is now a free man.

sense.definition: a period of ten years, especially a period such as 1910–1919 or 1990–1999
the process or result of being destroyed by natural causes or by not being cared for ( = of decaying)
examples: tooth decay

The decay of the wood will spread if it is not removed.

sense.definition: the gradual destruction of a society, an institution, a system, etc.
examples: economic/moral/urban decay
the decay of the steel industry

sense.definition: the 12th and last month of the year
of a good enough standard or quality
examples: a decent meal/job/place to live

The movie was actually halfway decent ( = better than we expected it would be).

sense.definition: honest and fair; treating people with respect
examples: ordinary, decent, hard-working people

sense.definition: acceptable to people in a particular situation
examples: a decent burial
That dress isn't decent.

sense.definition: wearing enough clothes to allow someone to see you
examples: I can't go to the door—I'm not decent.

sense.definition: to do what people or society expect, especially in a difficult situation
examples: He did the decent thing and resigned.

sense.definition: to think carefully about the different possibilities that are available and choose one of them
examples: It's up to you to decide.

It was decided (that) the school should purchase new software.

Don't lie to me.

Just don't be fooled by these statistics.
I don't know how he deceived me so well.
She felt betrayed when she found out the truth about him.

sense.definition: to make an official or legal judgment
examples: The case will be decided by a jury.

sense.definition: to affect the result of something

sense.definition: to be the reason why someone does something

sense.definition: a choice or judgment that you make after thinking and talking about what is the best thing to do
examples: to make a decision ( = to decide)

a big ( = an important) decision

sense.definition: the ability to decide something clearly and quickly
examples: This is not a job for someone who lacks decision.

sense.definition: the process of deciding something
examples: The moment of decision had arrived.
The power of decision remained with the directors.

sense.definition: to say something officially or publicly
examples: The government has declared a state of emergency.

sense.definition: to tell the tax authorities how much money you have earned

sense.definition: to tell customs officers ( = at the border of a country) that you are carrying goods on which you should pay tax

sense.definition: a continuous decrease in the number, value, quality, etc. of something

sense.definition: to make something look more attractive by putting things on it

sense.definition: to be placed on something in order to make it look more attractive

sense.definition: a thing that makes something look more attractive on special occasions

sense.definition: a pattern, etc. that is added to something and that stops it from being plain

sense.definition: the style in which something is decorated

sense.definition: decorated in a way that makes it attractive; intended to look attractive or pretty

sense.definition: to become or make something become smaller in size, number, etc.

sense.definition: having a large distance from the top or surface to the bottom
examples: a deep hole/well/river
deep water/snow

sense.definition: having a large distance from the front edge to the farthest point inside
examples: a deep cut/wound

sense.definition: used to describe or ask about the depth of something

sense.definition: as far up or down as the point mentioned

sense.definition: in the number of rows mentioned, one behind the other

sense.definition: taking in or giving out a lot of air

sense.definition: low
examples: I heard his deep warm voice filling the room.

sense.definition: strong and dark

sense.definition: a person in a deep sleep is difficult to wake
examples: to be in a deep sleep/trance/coma

sense.definition: extreme or serious
examples: He's in deep trouble.

sense.definition: strongly felt

sense.definition: showing great knowledge or understanding

sense.definition: difficult to understand
examples: This discussion's getting too deep for me.

sense.definition: serious and thinking hard about complex issues

sense.definition: fully involved in an activity or a state

sense.definition: in a difficult situation where there are two equally unpleasant or unacceptable choices
to suddenly become very angry or emotional
in trouble or difficulty

sense.definition: very; very much

sense.definition: sure or certain; unlikely to change

sense.definition: easily or clearly seen or understood; obvious

sense.definition: sure that something is true or that something is going to happen and stating it to other people

sense.definition: an explanation of the meaning of a word or phrase, especially in a dictionary; the act of stating the meanings of words and phrases

It is important to clarify what is meant by climate change.
Climate change can/may be defined as “the long-term fluctuations in temperature, precipitation, wind, and other aspects of the earth's climate.”
A generally accepted definition of global warming is the gradual increase in the overall temperature of the earth's atmosphere due to the greenhouse effect.
The greenhouse effect is defined by the author as the process by which heat from the sun is trapped in the earth's atmosphere, causing the temperature of the earth to rise.
The author uses the term “climate change”to refer to any significant change in measures of climate lasting for an extended period.
The term “carbon footprint”refers to the amount of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere as a result of the activities of an individual or organization.
Scientists suggest that increased carbon dioxide in the atmosphere will result in an increase in global temperatures, and the term “global warming”is used to describe this phenomenon.

sense.definition: a section of a large store that sells a particular type of goods

sense.definition: to be something that someone is responsible for or knows a lot about
examples: Don't ask me about it—that's her department.

sense.definition: the act of leaving a place; an example of this
examples: His sudden departure threw the office into chaos.
Flights should be confirmed 48 hours before departure.

sense.definition: a plane, train, etc. leaving a place at a particular time
examples: arrivals and departures
All departures are from Terminal B.
the departure lounge/time/gate
the departures board

sense.definition: an action that is different from what is usual or expected
examples: It was a radical departure from tradition.
Their latest single represents a significant departure for the band.

sense.definition: a place where a trip starts
an idea, a theory, or an event that is used to start a discussion, an activity, etc.
according to
examples: Starting salary varies from $26,000 to $30,500, depending on experience.
He either resigned or was fired, depending on whom you talk to.

sense.definition: used to say that you are not certain about something because other things have to be considered
examples: “Is he coming?” “That depends. He may not have the time.”
I don't know if we can help—it all depends.
I might not go. It depends how tired I am.
“Your job sounds fun.” ” It depends what you mean by ‘fun.’”
I shouldn't be too late. But it depends if the traffic's bad.

sense.definition: to rely on someone or something and be able to trust them
examples: He was the sort of person you could depend on.
He knew he could depend upon her to deal with the situation.
You can trust me not to tell anyone.
Don't trust what you read in the newspapers!
He was the sort of person you could depend on.
I can't depend on my own strength ever since I got sick.
Can I rely on you to keep this secret?
You can't rely on any data you get from them.
You can't really rely on his judgment.
I'm counting on you to help me.
We can't count on the weather.
They need a leader they can believe in.

sense.definition: to be sure or expect that something will happen
examples: Depend on it ( = you can be sure) we won't give up.
Can we depend on you coming in on Sunday?
You can depend on him coming in on Sunday.
You can depend on her to be ( = she always is) late.

sense.definition: to need money, help, etc. from someone or something else for a particular purpose
examples: The community depends on the shipping industry for its survival.
I don't want to depend too much on my parents.

sense.definition: to be affected or decided by something
examples: Does the quality of teaching depend on class size?

sense.definition: a sum of money that is given as the first part of a larger payment
examples: We've put down a 5% deposit on the house.

ten monthly payments of $50
payment in advance
an insurance premium
a premium for express delivery

a subscription to “Newsweek”
to set up a repayment plan
We've put down a 5% deposit on the house.
I made a $500 deposit into my checking account.
We paid for the car by/in installments.

sense.definition: a sum of money that is paid by someone when they rent something and that is returned to them if they do not lose or damage the thing they are renting
examples: to pay a deposit
They'll probably ask you to leave a deposit.

sense.definition: a sum of money that is paid into a bank account
examples: Deposits can be made at any branch.

sense.definition: a layer of a substance that has formed naturally underground
examples: mineral/gold/coal deposits

sense.definition: a layer of a substance that has been left somewhere, especially by a river, flood, etc., or is found at the bottom of a liquid
examples: The rain left a deposit of mud on the windows.
fatty deposits in the arteries of the heart
glacial deposits

sense.definition: to make someone sad and without enthusiasm or hope
examples: Wet weather always depresses me.

sense.definition: to make trade, business, etc. less active
examples: The recession has depressed the housing market.

sense.definition: to make the value of prices or wages lower
examples: to depress wages/prices

sense.definition: to press or push something down, especially part of a machine
examples: to depress the gas pedal ( = when driving).

sense.definition: very sad and without hope
examples: She felt very depressed about the future.

sense.definition: suffering from the medical condition of depression
examples: The question is, was the woman insane when she committed the crime?
He was diagnosed as clinically depressed.
the treatment of anxiety in neurotic patients

He works with emotionally disturbed children.

sense.definition: without enough economic activity or jobs for people
examples: an attempt to bring jobs to depressed areas

sense.definition: having a lower amount or level than usual
examples: depressed prices

sense.definition: making you feel very sad and without enthusiasm
examples: a depressing sight/thought/experience
Looking for a job these days can be very depressing.
a depressingly familiar experience

sense.definition: the distance from the top or surface to the bottom of something
examples: What's the depth of the water here?
Water was found at a depth of 30 feet.
They dug down to a depth of 10 feet.
Many dolphins can dive to depths of 500 feet.
The oil well extended several hundreds of feet in depth.
the depth of a cut/wound/crack

sense.definition: the distance from the front to the back of something
examples: The depth of the shelves is 15 inches.

sense.definition: the strength and power of feelings
examples: the depth of her love

sense.definition: the quality of knowing or understanding a lot of details about something; the ability to provide and explain these details
examples: a writer of great wisdom and depth
a job that doesn't require any great depth of knowledge

sense.definition: the deepest, most extreme or serious part of something
examples: the depths of the ocean
to live in the depths of the country ( = a long way from a town)
in the depths of winter ( = when it is coldest)

He gazed into the depths of her eyes.
Her paintings reveal hidden depths ( = unknown and interesting things about her character).

sense.definition: the strength of a color
examples: Strong light will affect the depth of color of your carpets and curtains.

sense.definition: the quality in a work of art or a photograph that makes it appear not to be flat
to be unable to understand something because it is too difficult; to be in a situation that you cannot control
examples: He felt totally out of his depth in his new job.

sense.definition: in a detailed and thorough way
examples: I haven't looked at the report in depth yet.
an in-depth study

sense.definition: to be or to experience an extreme example of something unpleasant
examples: His latest novel plumbs the depths of horror and violence.

sense.definition: to come or develop from something
examples: The word “politics” is derived from a Greek word meaning “city.”

sense.definition: to get something from something
examples: He derived great pleasure from painting.

sense.definition: to obtain a substance from something
examples: The new drug is derived from fish oil.

sense.definition: to say what someone or something is like
examples: Can you describe him to me?

sense.definition: to make a movement that has a particular shape; to form a particular shape
examples: The shark described a circle around the shoal of fish.

sense.definition: a piece of writing or speech that says what someone or something is like; the act of writing or saying in words what someone or something is like
examples: to give a detailed/full description of the procedure
a brief/general description of the software

sense.definition: of some, etc. type
examples: boats of every description/all descriptions

medals, coins, and things of that description

sense.definition: to be like a particular person or thing
examples: A child answering the description of the missing boy was found safe and well in Chicago yesterday.

sense.definition: to be too extreme, shocking, etc. to believe/describe
examples: It beggars belief how things could have gotten this bad.

sense.definition: a large area of land that has very little water and very few plants growing on it. Many deserts are covered by sand
examples: the Sahara Desert

burning desert sands
a cultural desert ( = a place without any culture)

sense.definition: if someone or something deserves something, it is right that they should have it, because of the way they have behaved or because of what they are
examples: You deserve a rest after all that hard work.

What have I done to deserve this?

sense.definition: used to say that you admire someone because they have done something difficult or unpleasant
examples: She deserves a medal for teaching those 5-year-olds all day!

sense.definition: used to say that you think someone has earned the bad things that happen to them
you should help someone who has helped you
the general arrangement of the different parts of something that is made, such as a building, book, machine, etc.
examples: The basic design of the car is very similar to that of earlier models.
special new design features

sense.definition: the art or process of deciding how something will look, work, etc. by drawing plans, making models, etc.
examples: a course in art and design
a design studio
computer-aided design
the design and development of new products

sense.definition: a drawing or plan from which something may be made
examples: designs for aircraft
new and original designs

sense.definition: an arrangement of lines and shapes as a decoration
examples: floral/abstract/geometric designs

sense.definition: a plan or an intention
examples: It happened—whether by accident or design—that the two of them were left alone after all the others had gone.

sense.definition: to want to start a sexual relationship with someone
examples: He was quite aware of her marital designs on him.

sense.definition: to be planning to get something for yourself, often in a way that other people do not approve of
examples: Rumors spread that the Duke had designs on the crown ( = wanted to make himself king).

sense.definition: a person whose job is to decide how things such as clothes, furniture, tools, etc. will look or work by making drawings, plans, or patterns
examples: a fashion/jewelry, etc. designer

sense.definition: a strong wish to have or do something
examples: enough money to satisfy all your desires

sense.definition: a strong wish to have sex with someone
examples: She felt a surge of love and desire for him.

sense.definition: a person or thing that is wished for
examples: When she agreed to marry him he felt he had achieved his heart's desire.

sense.definition: a piece of furniture like a table, usually with drawers in it, that you sit at to read, write, work, etc.
examples: He used to be a pilot but now he has a desk job.

sense.definition: a place where you can get information or be served at an airport, a hotel, etc.
examples: the check-in desk
the reception desk

sense.definition: an office at a newspaper, television company, etc. that deals with a particular subject
examples: the sports desk

sense.definition: feeling or showing that you have little hope and are ready to do anything without worrying about danger to yourself or others
examples: The prisoners grew increasingly desperate.

sense.definition: giving little hope of success; tried when everything else has failed
examples: a desperate bid for freedom

sense.definition: needing or wanting something very much

sense.definition: extremely serious or dangerous
examples: The children are in desperate need of love and attention.

sense.definition: used to show that something happened or is true although something else might have happened to prevent it
examples: Her voice was shaking despite all her efforts to control it.

Despite/In spite of clear evidence from road safety studies, no new measures have been introduced.
Politicians have promised to improve road safety. In spite of this/Despite this, little has been achieved so far.
Although politicians have promised to improve road safety, little has been achieved so far.
Some politicians claim that the new transportation policy has been a success. In fact, it has been a total disaster.
Government campaigns have had a measure of success, but the fact remains that large numbers of accidents are still caused by careless drivers.

sense.definition: used to show that someone did not intend to do the thing mentioned

sense.definition: to damage something so badly that it no longer exists, works, etc.

sense.definition: to kill an animal deliberately, usually because it is sick or not wanted

sense.definition: to defeat someone completely

sense.definition: the act of destroying something; the process of being destroyed

sense.definition: a small individual fact or item; a less important fact or item

sense.definition: the small facts or features of something, when you consider them all together

sense.definition: a group of soldiers given special duties

sense.definition: giving many details and a lot of information; paying great attention to details

sense.definition: the quality that makes you continue trying to do something even when this is difficult

one of the four suits ( = sets) in a deck of cards. The cards are marked with red diamond shapes

sense.definition: the space inside the lines that connect the four bases; also used to mean the whole baseball field

sense.definition: a list of words in electronic form, for example stored in a computer's spell-checker

sense.definition: to stop existing; to disappear

sense.definition: to want something or want to do something very much

sense.definition: used to emphasize that you are telling the truth or will do what you promise

sense.definition: to die because you are old or sick

sense.definition: to die or fall down in very large numbers

sense.definition: do not stop hoping

sense.definition: the food that you eat and drink regularly

sense.definition: the way in which two people or things are not like each other; the way in which someone or something has changed
examples: There are no significant differences between the education systems of the two countries.

This survey highlights a number of differences in the way that teenage boys and girls in the U.S. spend their free time.
One of the main differences between the girls and the boys who took part in the research was the way in which they use the Internet.
Unlike the girls, who use the Internet mainly to keep in touch with friends, the boys questioned in this survey tend to use the Internet for playing computer games.
The girls differ from the boys in that they tend to spend more time keeping in touch with friends on the telephone or on social networking websites.
Compared with the boys, the girls spend much more time chatting to friends on the telephone.
On average, the girls spend four hours a week chatting to friends on the phone. In contrast, very few of the boys spend more than five minutes a day talking to their friends in this way.
The boys prefer competitive sports and computer games, whereas/while the girls seem to enjoy more cooperative activities, such as shopping with friends.
When the girls go shopping, they mainly buy clothes and cosmetics. The boys, on the other hand, tend to purchase computer games or gadgets.

sense.definition: the amount that something is greater or smaller than something else
examples: There's not much difference in price between the two computers.

sense.definition: a disagreement between people

sense.definition: to stop being unfriendly and become friends again

sense.definition: to have an important effect on someone or something; to make someone feel better

sense.definition: to have an effect/no effect on someone or something

sense.definition: used to say that you think the differences between two things are not important

sense.definition: to agree to forget about your disagreements

sense.definition: (when discussing a price, etc.) to agree on an amount that is at an equal distance between the two amounts that have been suggested
used to show that something is interesting or unusual

sense.definition: used to emphasize how much difference there is between two things
examples: There's a world of difference between liking someone and loving them.

sense.definition: not the same as someone or something; not like someone or something else

sense.definition: separate and individual
examples: She offered us five different kinds of cake.

sense.definition: unusual; not like other people or things

sense.definition: to be very different
examples: I know which neighborhood they live in, but whether I can find their house is a different matter.

sense.definition: a completely different situation or person from the one previously mentioned
a completely different situation or person from the one previously mentioned

examples: He says he doesn't care about what the critics write, but I know different.

sense.definition: to have different aims that cannot be achieved together without causing problems
to change the way that a situation appears
to change your opinion about someone or something or your attitude toward someone or something
to give some information that is different from what you expect or have been told

examples: Boys and girls may behave differently.

sense.definition: not easy; needing effort or skill to do or to understand

This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making. / This diagram shows how paper is made.
First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips.
Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine.
Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed.
Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities. /…is bleached so that impurities can be removed.
The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt.
As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away. This causes the solid material to sink to the bottom, forming a layer of paper.
At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper. / …dry the paper at the same time.
The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls. /Finally, the paper is wound onto large rolls.

sense.definition: to understand something, or realize what you should have done, only after something has happened
the birth of a baby
used to emphasize or show that something is true or will happen in spite of other circumstances
examples: I think she'll agree to do it, but in any event, all she can say is “no.”

sense.definition: if something happens
examples: In the event of an accident, call this number.
Sheila will inherit everything in the event of his death.

sense.definition: if that happens
examples: In that event, we will have to reconsider our offer.

sense.definition: at the end of a period of time or a series of events
examples: Our flight eventually left five hours late.
I'll get around to repairing it eventually.
She hopes to get a job on the local newspaper and eventually work for “The New York Times.”

sense.definition: used in negative sentences and questions, or sentences with if, to mean “at any time”
examples: Nothing ever happens here.
Don't you ever get tired?
If you're ever in Miami, come and see us.
“Have you ever thought of a career change?” “No, never/No I haven't.”
“Have you ever been to Rome?” “Yes, I have, actually. Not long ago.”
She hardly ever ( = almost never) goes out.
We see them very seldom, if ever.
I'll never ever do that again!

sense.definition: used for emphasis when you are comparing things
examples: It was raining harder than ever.
It's my best ever score.

sense.definition: all the time or every time; always
examples: Paul, ever the optimist, agreed to try again.
She married the prince and they lived happily ever after.
He said he would love her for ever and ever.
Their debts grew ever larger ( = kept increasing).
the ever-growing problem
an ever-present danger

sense.definition: used after when, why, etc. to show that you are surprised or shocked
examples: Why ever did you agree?

sense.definition: used to emphasize that someone does the same thing very often, usually in an annoying way
examples: All he ever does is grumble about things.

sense.definition: used to show that you are surprised or shocked
examples: Did you ever hear anything like it?

sense.definition: continuously since the time mentioned
examples: He's had a car ever since he was 18.
I was bitten by a dog once and I've been afraid of them ever since.

sense.definition: used to emphasize that something is certainly true
examples: That was a disaster if ever there was one!

sense.definition: used to emphasize something you are talking about
examples: “You must have been upset by that.” “Was I ever!”

sense.definition: used with singular nouns to refer to all the members of a group of things or people
examples: She knows every student in the school.
I could hear every word they said.
We enjoyed every minute of our stay.
Every day seemed the same to him.
Every single time he calls, I'm out.
I read every last article in the newspaper ( = all of them).
They were watching her every movement.
Every one of their CDs has been a hit.
Each book is labeled with a price.
Each student will be given their own e-mail address.
They each have their own e-mail address.
Every student in the class is capable of passing the exam.
Each (one) of the houses was slightly different.
I bought a dozen eggs and every one of them was bad.

sense.definition: all possible
examples: We wish you every success.
He had every reason to be angry.

sense.definition: used to say how often something happens or is done
examples: The buses go every 10 minutes.
We had to stop every few miles.
One in every three marriages ends in divorce.
He has every third day off ( = he works for two days, then has one day off, then works for two days, and so on).
We see each other every now and again.
Every now and then he regretted his decision.

sense.definition: each alternate one ( = the first, third, fifth, etc. one, but not the second, fourth, sixth, etc.)
examples: They visit us every other week.

sense.definition: every person; all people
examples: Everyone cheered and clapped.
Everyone has a chance to win.
Everyone brought their partner to the party.
Everyone brought his or her partner to the party.
The police questioned everyone in the room.
The teacher commented on everyone's work.
Everyone else was there.

sense.definition: all things
examples: Everything was gone.
When we confronted him, he denied everything.
Take this bag, and leave everything else to me.

sense.definition: the situation now; life generally
examples: Everything in the capital is now quiet.
“How's everything with you?” “Fine, thanks.”

sense.definition: the most important thing
examples: Money isn't everything.
My family means everything to me.

sense.definition: and so on; and other similar things
examples: Do you have his name and address and everything?
She told me about the baby and everything.

sense.definition: in, to, or at every place; all places
examples: I've looked everywhere.
He follows me everywhere.
We'll have to eat here—everywhere else is full.
Everywhere we went was full of tourists.

sense.definition: the facts, signs, or objects that make you believe that something is true
examples: There is convincing evidence of a link between exposure to sun and skin cancer.
The room bore evidence of a struggle.
We found further scientific evidence for this theory.
There is not a shred of evidence that the meeting actually took place.
Do you have any evidence to support this allegation?
The cave contained evidences of prehistoric settlement.
Several trends become evident from the results.
A regional pattern is clearly evident in the data.
There is extensive theoretical and empirical evidence.
This experimental evidence is based on clinical observations of patients.
These observations are based on the evidence provided by numerous surveys.
Evidence was gathered from a number of sources.
In this paper, I have provided evidence for two major assumptions of the theory.
Empirical evidence suggests that being married and being employed are frequently associated with better health.
As the body of scientific evidence grows, the speed of climatic change is proving greater than predicted.

sense.definition: the information that is used in court to try to prove something
examples: I was asked to give evidence ( = to say what I knew, describe what I had seen, etc.) at the trial.
He was released when the judge ruled there was no evidence against him.

sense.definition: present and clearly seen
examples: The police were much in evidence at today's demonstration.

sense.definition: enjoying harming others; morally bad and cruel
examples: an evil man
an evil grin

sense.definition: having a harmful effect on people; morally bad
examples: evil deeds
the evil effects of racism

sense.definition: connected with the devil and with what is bad in the world
examples: evil spirits

sense.definition: extremely unpleasant
examples: an evil smell

sense.definition: former
examples: ex-wife
ex-president

sense.definition: correct in every detail
examples: She gave an exact description of the attacker.
an exact copy/replica of the painting

What were his exact words?
She's in her mid-thirties—thirty-six to be exact.
The colors were an exact match.
He started to call me at the exact moment I started to call him ( = at the same time).

Her second husband was the exact opposite of her first ( = completely different).

sense.definition: very accurate and careful about details
using accurate measurements and following set rules
examples: Assessing insurance risk can never be an exact science.

sense.definition: used to emphasize that something is correct in every way or in every detail
examples: I know exactly how she felt.
Do exactly as I tell you.
It happened almost exactly a year ago.
It's exactly nine o'clock.
You haven't changed at all—you still look exactly the same.
His words had exactly the opposite effect.
Your answer is exactly right.

sense.definition: used to ask for more information about something
examples: Where exactly did you stay in France?

sense.definition: used as a reply, agreeing with what someone has just said, or emphasizing that it is correct
examples: “You mean someone in this room must be the murderer?” “Exactly.”

sense.definition: used when you are saying the opposite of what you really mean
examples: He wasn't exactly pleased to see us—in fact he refused to open the door.

sense.definition: used when you are correcting something that someone has said
examples: “So he told you you'd get the job?” “Not exactly, but he said they were impressed with me.”

sense.definition: to make something seem larger, better, worse, or more important than it really is
examples: The hotel was really filthy, and I'm not exaggerating.

I'm sure he exaggerates his British accent ( = tries to sound more British than he really is).

sense.definition: made to seem larger, better, worse, or more important than it really is or needs to be
examples: to make greatly/grossly/wildly exaggerated claims
She has an exaggerated sense of her own importance.

sense.definition: done in a way that makes people notice it
examples: an exaggerated laugh
He looked at me with exaggerated surprise.

sense.definition: a formal written, spoken, or practical test, especially in school or college, to see how much you know about a subject, or what you can do
examples: to take an exam
to pass/fail an exam
an exam paper
I got my exam results today.
A lot of students suffer from exam nerves.
to grade an exam
She did well on her exams.
I got an 86% on my chemistry exam.

sense.definition: a medical test of a particular part of the body
examples: an eye exam
to take an examination in mathematics
an entrance examination

sense.definition: the act of looking at or considering something very carefully
examples: Careful examination of the ruins revealed an even earlier temple.

sense.definition: a close look at something or someone, especially to see if there is anything wrong or to find the cause of a problem
examples: a complete physical examination
a postmortem examination

sense.definition: to consider or study an idea, a subject, etc. very carefully
examples: These ideas will be examined in more detail in Chapter 10.

sense.definition: to look at someone or something closely, to see if there is anything wrong or to find the cause of a problem
examples: The doctor examined her but could find nothing wrong.

sense.definition: to give someone a test to see how much they know about a subject or what they can do

sense.definition: to ask someone questions formally, especially in court

sense.definition: to be crazy
something such as an object, a fact, or a situation that shows, explains, or supports what you say
examples: Can you give me an example of what you mean?
