Wikis vary in how open they are. Some wikis, for example/for instance, allow anybody to edit content, while others only allow registered users to do this.

examples: This is a good example of the artist's early work.

sense.definition: a person or their behavior that is thought to be a good model for others to copy
examples: Her courage is an example to us all.

sense.definition: a person's behavior, either good or bad, that other people copy
examples: It would be a mistake to follow his example.

sense.definition: used to emphasize something that explains or supports what you are saying; used to give an example of what you are saying
examples: There is a similar word in many languages, for example in French and Italian.
The report is incomplete; it does not include sales in France, for example.

The Web site has a variety of interactive exercises (e.g., matching games, crosswords, and quizzes).
The Web site has a variety of interactive exercises, including matching games, crosswords, and quizzes.
Web 2.0 technologies, such as wikis, blogs, and social networking sites, have changed the way that people use the Internet.
Many Web sites now allow users to contribute information. A good example of this is the “wiki,” a type of Web site that anyone can edit.
Wikis vary in how open they are. For example, some wikis allow anybody to edit content, while others only allow registered users to do this.
Wikis vary in how open they are. Some wikis, for example/for instance, allow anybody to edit content, while others only allow registered users to do this.
More and more people read their news on the Internet. To take one example, over 18 million people visited the “New York Times” Web site in December.

Online newspapers are now more popular than paper ones. The “Los Angeles Times”is a case in point. Its print circulation has fallen in recent years, while its Web site attracts millions of users every month.

sense.definition: to punish someone as a warning to others not to do the same thing
examples: Can you give me an example of what you mean?
In some cases people have had to wait several weeks for an appointment.
The report highlights a number of instances of injustice.
The aquarium has some interesting specimens of tropical fish.
The statistics are a clear illustration of the point I am trying to make.

sense.definition: extremely good
examples: an excellent meal
excellent service

It was absolutely excellent.

sense.definition: used to show that you are very pleased about something or that you approve of something
examples: You can all come? Excellent!

sense.definition: used before you mention the only thing or person about which a statement is not true
examples: We work every day except Sunday.

What other sports do you like besides football?

What other sports do you like apart from football?
I like all sports apart from football.

sense.definition: a person or thing that is not included in a general statement
examples: Most of the buildings in the town are modern, but the church is an exception.

Apart from/Aside from the final track, all of the songs on the album were written by her.
The songwriting —with a few minor exceptions — is of a very high quality.
With only one or two exceptions, the songwriting is of a very high quality.
The majority of the compositions are less than three minutes long, with the notable exception of the title track.
With the exception of the title track, this album is a huge disappointment.
Here is a list of all the band's CDs, excluding unofficial “bootleg” recordings.

sense.definition: a thing that does not follow a rule
examples: Good writing is unfortunately the exception rather than the rule ( = it is unusual).

sense.definition: to allow someone not to follow the usual rule on one occasion
examples: Children are not usually allowed in, but I'm prepared to make an exception in this case.

sense.definition: to object strongly to something; to be angry about something
examples: I take great exception to the fact that you told my wife before you told me.

sense.definition: except; not including
examples: All his novels are set in Italy with the exception of his last.
She wrote all of the songs on the album except for the final track.
Apart from/Aside from the final track, all of the songs on the album were written by her.
The songwriting —with a few minor exceptions — is of a very high quality.
With only one or two exceptions, the songwriting is of a very high quality.
The majority of the compositions are less than three minutes long, with the notable exception of the title track.
With the exception of the title track, this album is a huge disappointment.
Here is a list of all the band's CDs, excluding unofficial “bootleg” recordings.

sense.definition: used to emphasize that the statement you are making is always true and everyone or everything is included

sense.definition: an act of giving something to someone or doing something for someone and receiving something in return

an exchange of fire ( = between enemy soldiers)

sense.definition: a conversation or an argument

sense.definition: the process of changing an amount of one currency ( = the money used in one country) for an equal value of another

sense.definition: a building where business people met in the past to buy and sell a particular type of goods

sense.definition: to make someone feel very pleased, interested, or enthusiastic, especially about something that is going to happen

sense.definition: to make someone nervous or upset and unable to relax

sense.definition: to make someone feel a particular emotion or react in a particular way synonym arouse

sense.definition: to make someone feel sexual desire synonym arouse
to make a part of the body or part of a physical system more active synonym stimulate
feeling or showing happiness and enthusiasm
examples: The kids were excited about opening their gifts.

sense.definition: nervous or upset and unable to relax

sense.definition: feeling sexual desire

examples: She waved excitedly as the car approached.

sense.definition: the state of feeling excited

to feel a surge/thrill/shiver of excitement

sense.definition: something that you find exciting

sense.definition: causing great interest or excitement
examples: This is just one of the many exciting projects we are working on.

an exciting prospect/possibility
an exciting story/discovery

sense.definition: to deliberately not include something in what you are doing or considering

sense.definition: to prevent someone or something from entering a place or taking part in something

sense.definition: to decide that something is not possible

sense.definition: not including
examples: Lunch costs $10 per person, excluding drinks.

Apart from/Aside from the final track, all of the songs on the album were written by her.

sense.definition: a reason, either true or invented, that you give to explain or defend your behavior
examples: Late again! What's your excuse this time?

His excuse for forgetting her birthday was that he had lost his calendar.
You don't have to make excuses for her ( = try to think of reasons for her behavior).

Late again! What's your excuse this time?
It gave me an excuse to drive instead of walking.
There seemed to be no motive for the murder.

sense.definition: a good reason that you give for doing something that you want to do for other reasons
examples: It's just an excuse for a party.

sense.definition: a very bad example of something
examples: Why get involved with that pathetic excuse for a human being?

sense.definition: a note written by a parent or doctor to explain why a student cannot go to school or someone cannot go to work
a person who has an important job as a manager of a company or an organization
examples: advertising/business/sales, etc. executives
a chief/senior executive in a computer company

sense.definition: a group of people who run a company or an organization

sense.definition: the part of a government responsible for putting laws into effect
physical or mental activity that you do to stay healthy or become stronger
examples: Swimming is good exercise.

vigorous/gentle exercise

sense.definition: a set of movements or activities that you do to stay healthy or develop a skill

exercises for the piano

sense.definition: a set of questions in a book that tests your knowledge or practices a skill

sense.definition: an activity that is designed to achieve a particular result

sense.definition: a set of activities for training soldiers

sense.definition: ceremonies

sense.definition: the act of showing a skill, a feeling, or a kind of behavior

sense.definition: to behave in a bad or stupid way in public

sense.definition: to live, especially in a difficult situation or with very little money

sense.definition: the state or fact of being real or living. or of being present
examples: I was unaware of his existence until today.

sense.definition: a way of living, especially when this is difficult or boring

sense.definition: a place where vehicles can leave a road to join another road

sense.definition: to talk more; to add details to what you are saying

sense.definition: to be waiting for someone or something to arrive, as this has been arranged

sense.definition: to see something by accident or not very clearly because you see it from the side of your eye and are not looking straight at it
examples: Out of the corner of her eye, she saw him coming closer.

sense.definition: to pretend that you have not noticed something so that you do not have to deal with it
examples: You can't just close your eyes to his violence.
They seem intent on shutting their eyes to the problems of pollution.

sense.definition: a person or thing that you are pleased to see
to stop giving your attention to what is most important
to pretend not to notice something bad that is happening, so you do not have to do anything about it
examples: The authorities were either unaware of the problem or turned a blind eye to it.

sense.definition: being watched carefully by someone
examples: The children played under the watchful eye of their father.

sense.definition: fully aware of the possible problems or results of a particular course of action
examples: I went into this with my eyes open so I guess I only have myself to blame.

sense.definition: having enough experience to be able to do something easily
examples: I've made this trip so often, I could do it with my eyes shut.

sense.definition: with the intention of doing something
examples: He bought the warehouse with an eye to converting it into a hotel.

sense.definition: the front part of the head between the forehead and the chin
examples: a pretty/round/freckled face
He buried his face in his hands.
You should have seen the look on her face when I told her!
The expression on his face never changed.
At that time, her face was on the covers of all the magazines.

sense.definition: an expression that is shown on someone's face
examples: a sad/happy/smiling face
Her face lit up ( = showed happiness) when she spoke of the past.
His face fell ( = showed disappointment, sadness, etc.) when he read the headlines.

sense.definition: having the type of face or expression mentioned
examples: pale-faced
grim-faced

sense.definition: used to refer to a person of the type mentioned
examples: She looked around for a familiar face.
a well-known face on our television screens
It's nice to see some new faces here this evening.
I'm tired of seeing the same old faces every time we go out!

sense.definition: a side or surface of something
examples: the north face of the mountain
The birds build their nests in the rock face.
Ivy covered the front face of the house.
How many faces does a cube have?

sense.definition: the front part of a clock or watch
the particular character of something
examples: the changing face of our city

sense.definition: a particular aspect of something
examples: the unacceptable face of capitalism

sense.definition: to be obvious or easy to see
examples: The answer was staring us in the face.

sense.definition: to be certain to happen
examples: Defeat was staring them in the face.

sense.definition: to be unable to avoid something
examples: They were staring defeat in the face.

sense.definition: to be very obvious to other people from the expression on someone's face
examples: Guilt was written all over his face.

sense.definition: if a plan, etc. blows up in your face, it goes wrong in a way that causes you damage, embarrassment, etc.
to do something when you are angry that is meant to harm someone else but that also harms you
to disappear completely
examples: Keep looking—they can't just have vanished off the face of the earth.

sense.definition: to try to do something as hard and as long as you possibly can but without success
examples: You can argue till you're blue in the face, but you won't change my mind.

sense.definition: close to and looking at someone
examples: The two have never met face to face before.
The room fell silent as she came face to face with the man who had tried to kill her.

sense.definition: in a situation where you have to accept that something is true and deal with it
examples: She was at an early age brought face to face with the horrors of war.

sense.definition: with your face and stomach facing upward/downward
examples: She lay face down on the bed.

sense.definition: with the front part or surface facing upward/downward
examples: Place the card face up on the pile.

sense.definition: to fall so that you are lying on your front
to fail completely, usually causing embarrassment
examples: His next television venture fell flat on its face.

sense.definition: to oppose or be the opposite of something that is usual or expected
examples: Such a proposal flies in the face of common sense.

sense.definition: to be made to look stupid
examples: They were left with egg on their faces when only ten people showed up.

sense.definition: annoying someone by criticizing them or telling them what to do all the time
despite problems, difficulties, etc.
examples: She showed great courage in the face of danger.
The campaign continued in the face of great opposition.

sense.definition: as a result of something
examples: He was unable to deny the charges in the face of new evidence.

sense.definition: to show in a very obvious way that you have no respect for someone
(to have) an unhappy or disappointed expression
examples: He took one look at her long face and said “What's wrong?”

sense.definition: to look straight at someone without feeling embarrassed or ashamed
examples: Can you look me in the eye and tell me you're not lying?
I'll never be able to look her in the face again!

sense.definition: to be less respected or look stupid because of something you have done
to produce an expression on your face to show that you do not like someone or something, or in order to make someone laugh
examples: Do you think it's funny to make faces behind my back?

sense.definition: used to emphasize that you have particular skills or qualities
examples: “I didn't know you could play the piano.” “I'm not just a pretty face, you know!”

sense.definition: used to say that something seems to be good, true, etc. but that this opinion may need to be changed when you know more about it
examples: On the face of it, it seems like a great deal.
What may, on the face of it, seem obvious often turns out to be far more complicated.

sense.definition: very obvious
to put on makeup
to pretend that you feel confident and happy when you do not
examples: I had to put on a brave face and try to show him that I wasn't worried.
She put a brave face on her illness.

sense.definition: to avoid or help someone avoid embarrassment
examples: She was fired, but she saved face by telling everyone she'd resigned.

sense.definition: to appear among your friends or in public
examples: She stayed at home, afraid to show her face.

sense.definition: to shut a door hard when someone is trying to come in
to refuse to talk to someone or meet them, in a rude way
a rude way of telling someone to be quiet or stop talking
an action that seems to be intended as a deliberate insult to someone
if you keep a straight face, you do not laugh or smile, although you find something funny
to eat a lot of food or too much food
if you say something to someone's face, you say it to them directly rather than to other people
examples: He's a liar, and I've told him so to his face many times.

sense.definition: used to refer to a person whose name you cannot remember
examples: Are you still working for what's her face?

sense.definition: to destroy or remove someone or something completely
buildings, services, equipment, etc. that are provided for a particular purpose
examples: sports/leisure facilities
conference facilities
shopping/banking/cooking facilities
The hotel has special facilities for disabled people.
All rooms have private facilities ( = a private bathroom).

sense.definition: a special feature of a machine, service, etc. that makes it possible to do something extra
examples: a bank account with an overdraft facility
a facility for checking spelling
This facility allows the user to input text in various forms onto the screen and thus create a true newspaper page.

sense.definition: a place, usually including buildings, used for a particular purpose or activity
examples: the world's largest nuclear waste facility
a new healthcare facility

sense.definition: a natural ability to learn or do something easily
examples: She has a facility for languages.
He plays the piano with surprising facility.

sense.definition: used to refer to a particular situation that exists
examples: I could no longer ignore the fact that he was deeply unhappy.
Despite the fact that she was wearing a seat belt, she was thrown sharply forward.
Due to the fact that they did not read English, the prisoners were unaware of what they were signing.
She was happy apart from the fact that she could not return home.
Voluntary work was particularly important in view of the fact that women were often forced to give up paid work on marriage.
How do you account for the fact that unemployment is still rising?
The fact remains that we are still two teachers short.
The mere fact of being poor makes such children criminals in the eyes of the police.
Politicians have promised to improve road safety. So far, however, little has been achieved.
Despite/In spite of clear evidence from road safety studies, no new measures have been introduced.
Politicians have promised to improve road safety. In spite of this/Despite this, little has been achieved so far.
Although politicians have promised to improve road safety, little has been achieved so far.
Some politicians claim that the new transportation policy has been a success. In fact, it has been a total disaster.
Government campaigns have had a measure of success, but the fact remains that large numbers of accidents are still caused by careless drivers.

sense.definition: a thing that is known to be true, especially when it can be proved
examples: Isn't it a fact that the company is losing money?
I haven't spoken to anyone in English for days and that's a fact.
I know for a fact ( = I am certain) that she's involved in something illegal.
The judge instructed both lawyers to stick to the facts of the case.
First, some basic facts about healthy eating!
The report is based on hard facts ( = information that can be proved to be true).
If you're going to make accusations, you'd better get your facts right ( = make sure your information is correct).
It's about time you learned to face (the) facts ( = accepted the truth about the situation).

sense.definition: things that are true rather than things that have been invented
examples: The story is based on fact.
It's important to distinguish fact from fiction.

sense.definition: after something has happened or been done when it is too late to prevent it or change it
examples: On some vital decisions employees were only informed after the fact.

sense.definition: used to add a comment on something that you have just said, usually adding something that you think the other person will be interested in
examples: It's a nice place. We've stayed there ourselves, as a matter of fact.

sense.definition: used to disagree with something that someone has just said
examples: “I suppose you'll be leaving soon, then?” “No, as a matter of fact I'll be staying for another two years.”

sense.definition: used to emphasize a statement, especially one that is the opposite of what has just been mentioned
examples: A new car would be wonderful, but the fact of the matter is that we can't afford one.

sense.definition: a situation that cannot be changed, especially one that is unpleasant
examples: It's a fact of life that some people will always be racist.

sense.definition: accurate and detailed information
examples: I've asked to see all the facts and figures before I make a decision.

sense.definition: the details about sex and about how babies are born, especially as told to children
it is not necessary to give any further explanation about something because the information that is available already proves that it is true
used to give extra details about something that has just been mentioned
examples: I used to live in France; in fact, not far from where you're going.

sense.definition: used to emphasize a statement, especially one that is the opposite of what has just been mentioned
examples: I thought the work would be difficult. In actual fact, it's very easy.
Politicians have promised to improve road safety. So far, however, little has been achieved.
Despite/In spite of clear evidence from road safety studies, no new measures have been introduced.
Politicians have promised to improve road safety. In spite of this/Despite this, little has been achieved so far.
Although politicians have promised to improve road safety, little has been achieved so far.
Some politicians claim that the new transportation policy has been a success. In fact, it has been a total disaster.
Government campaigns have had a measure of success, but the fact remains that large numbers of accidents are still caused by careless drivers.

sense.definition: used to say what is true in a situation
examples: In point of fact, she is their adopted daughter.

sense.definition: used to reply to a statement that you find interesting or surprising, or that you do not believe
examples: “She says I'm one of the best students she's ever taught.” “Is that a fact?”

sense.definition: one of several things that cause or influence something
examples: economic factors
The closure of the mine was the single most important factor in the town's decline.
the key/crucial/deciding factor
The result will depend on a number of different factors
Childhood obesity can cause/lead to long-term health problems.
Changes in lifestyle and diet over the last twenty years have caused/led to/resulted in a sharp increase in childhood obesity.
Several factors, including changes in diet and lifestyle, have contributed to the increase in childhood obesity.
Research suggests that fast food and soft drinks directly contribute to childhood obesity.
Genetics, lifestyle, and diet are all important factors in cases of childhood obesity.
Even small changes in lifestyle and diet can bring about significant weight loss.

sense.definition: a number that divides into another number exactly
examples: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 12 are the factors of 12.

sense.definition: the amount by which something increases or decreases
examples: The real wage of the average worker has increased by a factor of over ten in the last 70 years.

sense.definition: a particular level on a scale of measurement
examples: The wind chill factor will make it seem colder.
a sunblock with a sun protection factor of 30

sense.definition: a substance in the blood that helps the clotting process. There are several types of this substance
examples: Hemophiliacs have no factor 8 in their blood

sense.definition: a building or group of buildings where goods are made
examples: a car factory
factory workers

sense.definition: to not be successful in achieving something
examples: Many diets fail because they are boring.
a failing business
I failed in my attempt to persuade her.
She failed to get into law school.
The song can't fail to be a hit ( = definitely will be a hit).

sense.definition: to not do something
examples: He failed to keep the appointment.
She never fails to e-mail every week.
I fail to see ( = I don't understand) why you won't even try it.
He felt he would be failing in his duty if he did not report it.

sense.definition: to not pass a test or an exam; to decide that someone or something has not passed a test or an exam
examples: He failed his driving test.
She was disqualified after failing a drug test.
What will you do if you fail?
The professor failed several students last semester.

sense.definition: to stop working
examples: The brakes on my bike failed halfway down the hill.

sense.definition: to become weak
examples: Her eyesight is failing.
His last months in office were marred by failing health.

sense.definition: to disappoint someone; to be unable to help when needed
examples: When he lost his job, he felt he had failed his family.
She tried to be brave, but her courage failed her.
Words fail me ( = I cannot express how I feel).

sense.definition: to not be enough when needed or expected
examples: The crops failed again last summer.
The rains had failed and the rivers were dry.

sense.definition: to be unable to continue
examples: Several banks failed during the recession.

sense.definition: used to suggest something that someone can do if nothing else works
examples: If all else fails, you can always sell your motorcycle.

sense.definition: lack of success in doing or achieving something
examples: The success or failure of the plan depends on you.
The attempt was doomed to failure.
All my efforts ended in failure.
the problems of economic failure and increasing unemployment
She is still coming to terms with the failure of her marriage.

sense.definition: a person or thing that is not successful
examples: The whole thing was a complete failure.
He was a failure as a teacher.
A team learns from experience, both successes and failures.

sense.definition: an act of not doing something, especially something that you are expected to do
examples: the failure of the United Nations to maintain food supplies
Failure to comply with the regulations will result in prosecution.
His confession followed repeated failures to appear in court.

sense.definition: the state of not working correctly or as expected; an occasion when this happens
examples: patients suffering from heart/kidney, etc. failure
Production has been halted by mechanical failure.
A power failure plunged everything into darkness.
The cause of the crash was given as engine failure.

sense.definition: a situation in which a business or bank has to close because it is not successful
examples: an alarming increase in bank failures

sense.definition: a situation in which crops do not grow correctly and do not produce food
examples: Bad weather has resulted in crop failure.

sense.definition: that cannot be clearly seen, heard, or smelled
examples: a faint glow/glimmer/light
a faint smell of perfume
We saw the faint outline of the mountain through the mist.
We could hear their voices growing fainter as they walked down the road.
His breathing became faint.

sense.definition: very small; possible but unlikely
examples: There is still a faint hope that she may be cured.
They don't have the faintest chance of winning.

sense.definition: not enthusiastic
examples: a faint show of resistance
a faint smile

sense.definition: feeling weak and tired and likely to become unconscious
examples: She suddenly felt faint.
The walkers were faint from hunger.
She smiled faintly.
He looked faintly embarrassed.

sense.definition: to praise someone or something only a little, in order to show that you do not really like them/it
to not know anything at all about something
examples: I didn't have the faintest idea what you meant.
He didn't have the faintest idea how the others would react.

sense.definition: acceptable and appropriate in a particular situation
examples: a fair deal/price/question
The punishment was very fair.
In the end, a draw was a fair result.
I'm giving you fair warning, I'm not always this generous.
Was it really fair to him to ask him to do all the work?
It's only fair to add that they were not told about the problem until the last minute.
I think it is fair to say that they are pleased with the latest offer.
It seems only fair that they give us something in return.
To be fair, she behaved better than we expected.

sense.definition: treating everyone equally and according to the rules or law
examples: She has always been scrupulously fair.
demands for a fairer distribution of wealth
We have to be fair to both players.
to receive a fair trial
free and fair elections
It's not fair! He always gets more than me.
The new tax is fairer than the old system.
They are fair and decent employers.
his vision of a fairer, kinder society

sense.definition: fairly large in number, size, or amount
examples: A fair number of people came along.
a fair-sized town
We've still got a fair amount ( = some more things) to do.
My birthday's still a fair way off ( = it's still a long time until my birthday).

sense.definition: fairly good
examples: There's a fair chance that we might win this time.
It's a fair bet that they won't turn up.
I have a fair idea of what happened.
His knowledge of French is only fair.

sense.definition: pale in color
examples: a fair complexion
She has long, fair hair.
All her children are fair ( = they all have pale hair or skin).

sense.definition: bright and not raining
examples: a fair and breezy day

sense.definition: not too strong and blowing in the right direction
examples: They set sail with the first fair wind.

sense.definition: beautiful
examples: a fair maiden

sense.definition: in some situations any type of behavior is acceptable to get what you want
used to tell someone to be reasonable in their judgment of someone or something
examples: Be fair! She didn't know you were coming.

sense.definition: using dishonest methods if honest ones do not work
examples: She's determined to win, by fair means or foul.

sense.definition: used to say that an idea or a suggestion seems reasonable
examples: “We'll meet at 8.” “Fair enough.”
If you don't want to come, fair enough, but let Bill know.

sense.definition: used, especially as an exclamation, to say that you think that an action, a decision, etc. is acceptable and appropriate because it means that everyone will be treated fairly
examples: Fair's fair—you can't expect them to cancel everything just because you can't make it.

sense.definition: (to give somebody/get) fair treatment that gives you the same chance as someone else
examples: Are minority students getting a fair shake at college?

sense.definition: (more than) an amount of something that is considered to be reasonable or acceptable
examples: He has more than his fair share of problems.
I've had my fair share of success in the past.

sense.definition: not particularly good or bad
examples: “How are you feeling today?” “Oh, fair to middling.”

sense.definition: (to allow someone) the opportunity to give their opinion of something before deciding if they have done something wrong, often in court
examples: I'll make sure that you get a fair trial.

sense.definition: to some extent but not very
examples: a fairly easy book
a fairly typical reaction
I know him fairly well, but I wouldn't say we were really close friends.
I go jogging fairly regularly.
We'll have to leave fairly soon ( = before very long).
I'm fairly certain I can do the job.
I think you'll find it fairly difficult ( = you do not want to say that it is very difficult).

sense.definition: in a fair and reasonable way; honestly
examples: He has always treated me very fairly.
Her attitude could fairly be described as hostile.

sense.definition: used to emphasize something that you are saying
examples: The time fairly raced by.

sense.definition: trust in someone's ability or knowledge; trust that someone or something will do what has been promised
examples: I have great faith in you—I know you'll do well.
We've lost faith in the government's promises.
Her friend's kindness has restored her faith in human nature.
He has blind faith ( = unreasonable trust) in the doctor's ability to find a cure.

sense.definition: strong religious belief
examples: to lose your faith
Faith is stronger than reason.

sense.definition: a particular religion
examples: the Christian faith
The children are learning to understand people of different faiths.

sense.definition: the intention to do something right
examples: They handed over the weapons as a gesture of good faith.

sense.definition: to break/keep a promise that you have made to someone; to stop/continue being loyal to someone
knowing that what you are doing is wrong
believing that what you are doing is right; believing that something is correct
examples: We printed the report in good faith but have now learned that it was incorrect.
He bought the painting in good faith ( = he did not know that it had been stolen).

sense.definition: to rely on someone or something completely for success or help
examples: The company is pinning its hopes on the new project.

sense.definition: staying with or supporting a particular person, organization, or belief
examples: a faithful friend/dog/servant

I have been a faithful reader of your newspaper for many years.
He remained faithful to the ideals of the party.

sense.definition: people who believe in a religion; the loyal supporters of a political party
examples: The president will keep the support of the party faithful.

sense.definition: not having a sexual relationship with anyone else
true and accurate; not changing anything
examples: a faithful copy/account/description
His translation manages to be faithful to the spirit of the original.

sense.definition: able to be trusted; that you can rely on
examples: my faithful old car
faithfulness to tradition
She had doubts about his faithfulness.

sense.definition: accurately; carefully
examples: to follow instructions faithfully
The events were faithfully recorded in her diary.

sense.definition: in a loyal way; in a way that you can rely on
examples: He had supported the local team faithfully for 30 years.
She promised faithfully not to tell anyone my secret.

sense.definition: to drop down from a higher level to a lower level
examples: September had come and the leaves were starting to fall.
They were injured by falling rocks.
Several of the books had fallen onto the floor.
One of the kids fell into the river.
The handle had fallen off the drawer.
He fell 20 feet onto the rocks below.
The rain was falling steadily.

sense.definition: to suddenly stop standing
examples: She slipped on the ice and fell.
I fell down and cut my knee.
The house looked like it was about to fall down.

sense.definition: to hang down
examples: Her hair fell over her shoulders in a mass of curls.

sense.definition: to slope downward
examples: The land falls away sharply toward the river.

sense.definition: to decrease in amount, number, or strength
examples: Their profits have fallen by 30 percent.
Prices continued to fall on the stock market today.
The temperature fell sharply during the night.
falling birth rates
Her voice fell to a whisper.
The company's share price fell 30 cents.

sense.definition: to be defeated or captured
examples: The coup failed but the government fell shortly afterward.
Troy finally fell to the Greeks.

sense.definition: to die in battle; to be shot
examples: a memorial to those who fell in the two world wars

sense.definition: to pass into a particular state; to begin to be something
examples: He had fallen asleep on the sofa.
The book fell open at a page of illustrations.
The room had fallen silent.
She fell ill soon after and did not recover.
I had fallen into conversation with a man on the train.
The house had fallen into disrepair.
She knew she must not fall prey to his charm.

sense.definition: to come quickly and suddenly
examples: A sudden silence fell.
Darkness falls quickly in the tropics.

sense.definition: to happen or take place
examples: My birthday falls on a Monday this year.

sense.definition: to move in a particular direction or come in a particular position
examples: Which syllable does the stress fall on?
My eye fell on ( = I suddenly saw) a strange object.
A shadow fell across her face.

sense.definition: to belong to a particular class, group, or area of responsibility
examples: Out of more than 400 staff, there are just seven that fall into this category.
This case falls outside my jurisdiction.
This falls under the heading of scientific research.

sense.definition: wrong; not correct or true
examples: A whale is a fish. True or false?
Predictions of an early improvement in the housing market proved false.
She gave false information to the insurance company.
He used a false name to get the job.
I got all the answers wrong.
We were wrong to assume that she'd agree.
A whale is a fish. True or false?
She gave false information to the insurance company.
You're completely mistaken about Jane.
Many of the statistics were incorrect.
The report was badly researched and fairly inaccurate.
In her misguided attempts to help, she only made the situation worse.
These accusations are totally untrue.

sense.definition: not natural
examples: false teeth/eyelashes
a false beard
artificial flowers
artificial light
synthetic drugs
shoes made of synthetic material
a fake designer watch
a fake beard
a fake-fur jacket
man-made fibers such as nylon
a man-made lake
false teeth/eyelashes
a suitcase with a false bottom
chairs covered in faux leopard skin
She would never wear imitation pearls.

sense.definition: not genuine, but made to look real to cheat people
examples: a false passport

sense.definition: not real or sincere
examples: false modesty
She flashed him a false smile of congratulation.

sense.definition: wrong or mistaken, because it is based on something that is not true or correct
examples: a false argument/assumption/belief
to give a false impression of wealth
to lull someone into a false sense of security ( = make someone feel safe when they are really in danger)
They didn't want to raise any false hopes, but they believed her husband had escaped capture.
Buying a cheap computer is a false economy ( = will not actually save you money).

sense.definition: not faithful
examples: a false lover

sense.definition: by pretending to be something that you are not, in order to gain some advantage for yourself
examples: She was accused of obtaining money under false pretenses.

sense.definition: to give the impression of being sincere/true or not sincere/true
examples: It may seem like a strange story but it rings true to me.
to be falsely accused of something
She smiled falsely at his joke.

sense.definition: the state of being known and talked about by many people
examples: to achieve/win instant fame
to rise/shoot to fame overnight
Kelly Clarkson of “American Idol” fame ( = famous for “American Idol”)
The town's only claim to fame is that there was once a riot there.
She went to Hollywood in search of fame and fortune.

sense.definition: well known to you; often seen or heard and therefore easy to recognize
examples: to look/sound/taste familiar
He's a familiar figure in the neighborhood.
Something about her voice was vaguely familiar.
I couldn't see any familiar faces in the room.
The smell is very familiar to anyone who lives near a bakery.
Violent attacks are becoming all too familiar ( = sadly familiar).

sense.definition: knowing something very well
examples: an area I had been familiar with since childhood
By now you will be familiar with the one-way system in the center of town.
Are you familiar with the computer software they use?

sense.definition: very informal, sometimes in a way that is unpleasant
examples: You seem to be on very familiar terms with your teacher.

sense.definition: a group consisting of one or two parents and their children
examples: the other members of my family
Almost every family in the country owns a television.
My whole family enjoys skiing.
one-parent/single-parent families
a family of four
families with young children
He's a friend of the family ( = he is known and liked by the parents and the children).

sense.definition: a group consisting of one or two parents, their children and close relations
examples: The whole family came to Grandpa's eightieth birthday party.
The support of family and friends is vital.
We've only told the immediate family ( = the closest relations).
I always think of you as one of the family.
She's family ( = she is a relation).

sense.definition: all the people who are related to each other, including those who are now dead
examples: Some families have farmed in this area for hundreds of years.
This painting has been in our family for generations.

sense.definition: a couple's or a person's children, especially young children
examples: They have a large family.
I addressed it to Mr. and Mrs. Jones and family.
Do they plan to start a family ( = have children)?
to bring up/raise a family

sense.definition: a group of related animals and plants; a group of related things, especially languages
examples: Lions belong to the cat family.
the Germanic family of languages

sense.definition: (to be/become) pregnant
to be a common feature in a particular family
examples: Heart disease runs in the family.

sense.definition: known about by many people
examples: a famous artist/hotel
famous landmarks in San Francisco
One day, I'll be rich and famous.
So this is the famous dress! ( = the one we have heard a lot about but have not seen).

She was more famous as an actress than as a singer.

sense.definition: people sometimes say Famous last words! when they think someone is being too confident about something that is going to happen
examples: “Everything's under control.” “Famous last words!”

sense.definition: a person who admires someone or something or enjoys watching or listening to someone or something very much
examples: movie fans
crowds of football fans
a big fan of Madonna
fan mail ( = letters from fans to the person they admire)

sense.definition: a machine with blades that go around to create a current of air
examples: to switch on the electric fan
a ceiling fan

sense.definition: a flat object that you hold in your hand and wave to create a current of cool air
expensive or connected with an expensive way of life

This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making. / This diagram shows how paper is made.
First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips.
Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine.
Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed.
Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities. /…is bleached so that impurities can be removed.
The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt.
As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away. This causes the solid material to sink to the bottom, forming a layer of paper.
At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper. / …dry the paper at the same time.
The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls. /Finally, the paper is wound onto large rolls.

sense.definition: to aim light onto a particular point using a lens

sense.definition: to put your arms around someone and hold them against your body

sense.definition: near; in a place where someone or something can be reached easily

sense.definition: an influence that controls or restricts something

sense.definition: people who do not have enough to do often start to do wrong

sense.definition: to trust someone and be willing to do what they say

sense.definition: to become controlled by someone
examples: The town fell into enemy hands.

sense.definition: strong control or discipline

sense.definition: by experiencing, seeing, etc. something yourself rather than being told about it by someone else
examples: The President visited the area to see the devastation at first hand.

sense.definition: to bring or hold your hands together with the fingers bent
examples: She kept her hands folded in her lap.

sense.definition: to make someone do something that they do not want to do or make them do it sooner than they had intended
examples: They decided to strike to force the management's hand.

sense.definition: to get an advantage over someone so that you are in control of a particular situation
to do physical or difficult work

sense.definition: to get, have, etc. the opportunity to do what you want to do and to make your own decisions

sense.definition: to show your approval of someone by clapping; to be applauded in this way

sense.definition: to help someone
to ask someone for something, especially money, in a very polite way that makes you seem less important

sense.definition: permission to marry someone, especially a woman

sense.definition: working closely with someone, especially in a secret and/or illegal way

sense.definition: if two things go hand in hand, they are closely connected and one thing causes the other

sense.definition: easily and without any doubt

sense.definition: used to tell someone not to touch something or someone

sense.definition: used by someone who is threatening people with a gun to tell them to raise both hands in the air

sense.definition: to be very busy or too busy to do something else

sense.definition: to be unable to do what you want to do because of rules, promises, etc.

sense.definition: to have complete control or influence over someone

sense.definition: to have nothing to do or not be busy

sense.definition: a way of doing something or of treating people that is much stronger and less sensitive than it needs to be

sense.definition: to give someone support in a difficult situation

sense.definition: being taken care of or dealt with by someone that you think you can rely on

sense.definition: if you have money in hand, it is left and available to be used

sense.definition: if you have a particular situation in hand, you are in control of it

sense.definition: the job, question, etc. in hand is the one that you are dealing with

sense.definition: used to say that you are too busy to do anything else

sense.definition: if two people join hands, they hold each other's hands

sense.definition: to occasionally do something that you used to do a lot so that you do not lose your skill at it

sense.definition: to be very familiar with something

sense.definition: used to introduce different points of view, ideas, etc., especially when they are opposites
examples: On the one hand they'd love to have kids, but on the other, they don't want to give up their freedom.
This survey highlights a number of differences in the way that teenage boys and girls in the U.S. spend their free time.
One of the main differences between the girls and the boys who took part in the research was the way in which they use the Internet.
Unlike the girls, who use the Internet mainly to keep in touch with friends, the boys questioned in this survey tend to use the Internet for playing computer games.
The girls differ from the boys in that they tend to spend more time keeping in touch with friends on the telephone or on social networking websites.
Compared with the boys, the girls spend much more time chatting to friends on the telephone.
On average, the girls spend four hours a week chatting to friends on the phone. In contrast, very few of the boys spend more than five minutes a day talking to their friends in this way.
The boys prefer competitive sports and computer games, whereas/while the girls seem to enjoy more cooperative activities, such as shopping with friends.
When the girls go shopping, they mainly buy clothes and cosmetics. The boys, on the other hand, tend to purchase computer games or gadgets.

sense.definition: difficult or impossible to control
examples: Unemployment is getting out of hand.

sense.definition: if you reject, etc. something out of hand, you do so immediately without thinking about it fully or listening to other people's arguments
examples: All our suggestions were dismissed out of hand.

sense.definition: no longer your responsibility

sense.definition: to spoil your chance of success by judging your position to be stronger than it really is

sense.definition: easily controlled or influenced by another person

sense.definition: to hit, or threaten to hit, someone

sense.definition: to make your plans or intentions known
to stop yourself from doing something; to prevent you from doing something

sense.definition: to stop doing something or taking part in something, especially because you are not successful

sense.definition: to do something such as an activity or a sport for the first time

sense.definition: to take care of someone's needs so well that they do not have to do anything for themselves

sense.definition: to refuse to be responsible for or involved with someone or something

sense.definition: to win something very easily

sense.definition: to touch, hold, or move something with your hands

sense.definition: to be easy/difficult to drive or control

sense.definition: to buy or sell something
