sense.definition: to be in a position where you ought to do something
examples: We have a duty to care for the refugees.
You have to be home by 11 o’clock.
I have to wash the car tomorrow.
I have to collect the children from school at 3 o’clock.
All nurses must wear uniform.
Changes must be recorded in the log book.
I had to wait half an hour for a bus.
We’ll have to borrow the money we need.
I have to go to the dentist tomorrow.
Do the children have to wear uniforms?
Employees must not smoke in the building.
You mustn’t leave the gate open.
You don’t have to pay for the tickets in advance.
She doesn’t have to work on weekends.
He has (got) to be the worst actor on TV!
Your trip must have been fun!

sense.definition: to be in a position of needing to do something
examples: I have a lot of homework tonight.
I should go—I have a bus to catch.

sense.definition: to hold someone or something in the way mentioned
examples: She had him by the collar.
He had his head in his hands.

sense.definition: to place or keep something in a particular position
examples: Mary had her back to me.
I soon had the fish in a net.

sense.definition: to let a feeling or thought come into your mind
examples: He had the strong impression that someone was watching him.
We have a few ideas for the title.
I've got it! We'll call it “Word Magic.”

sense.definition: to suffer from an illness or a disease
examples: I have a headache.

sense.definition: to experience something
examples: I went to a few parties and had a good time.
I was having difficulty in staying awake.
She'll have an accident one day.

sense.definition: to organize or hold an event
examples: Let's have a party.

sense.definition: to eat, drink, or smoke something
examples: to have breakfast/lunch/dinner
I'll have the salmon ( = for example, in a restaurant).
I had a cigarette while I was waiting.

sense.definition: to perform a particular action
examples: I had a swim to cool down.

sense.definition: to give birth to someone or something
examples: She's going to have a baby.

sense.definition: to produce a particular effect
examples: His paintings had a strong influence on me as a student.
The color green has a restful effect.

sense.definition: to receive something from someone
examples: Can I have the check, please?

sense.definition: to be given something; to have something done to you
examples: I'm having physical therapy for my back problem.
How many driving lessons have you had so far?

sense.definition: to experience the effects of someone's actions
examples: We have orders coming in from all over the world.

sense.definition: to suffer the effects of what someone else does to you
examples: She had her purse stolen.

sense.definition: to cause something to be done for you by someone else
examples: You've had your hair cut!
We're having our car repaired.

sense.definition: to tell or arrange for someone to do something for you
examples: He had the bouncers throw them out of the club.
I'll have you know ( = I'm telling you) I'm a black belt in judo.
She's always having the handyman here to do something or other.

sense.definition: to allow something; to accept something without complaining
examples: I'm sick of your rudeness—I won't have it any longer!
We can't have people arriving late all the time.

sense.definition: to cause someone or something to be in a particular state; to make someone react in a particular way
examples: I want to have everything ready in good time.
He had his audience listening attentively.

sense.definition: to put someone at a disadvantage in an argument
examples: You've got me there. I hadn't thought of that.

sense.definition: to trick or cheat someone
examples: I'm afraid you've been had.

sense.definition: to take care of someone or something in your home, especially for a limited period
examples: We're having the kids for the weekend.

sense.definition: to entertain someone in your home
examples: We had some friends to dinner last night.

sense.definition: to be with someone
examples: She had some friends with her.

sense.definition: to take or accept someone for a particular role
examples: Who can we have as treasurer?

sense.definition: to be in a very bad condition; to be unable to be repaired
examples: The car had had it.

sense.definition: to be extremely tired
examples: I've had it! I'm going to bed.

sense.definition: to have lost all chance of surviving something
examples: When the truck smashed into me, I thought I'd had it.

sense.definition: to be going to experience something unpleasant
examples: Dad saw you scratch the car—you've had it now!

sense.definition: to be unable to accept a situation any longer
examples: I've had it (up to here) with him—he's done it once too often.

sense.definition: to claim that it is a fact that…
examples: Rumor has it that we'll have a new manager soon.

sense.definition: to be likely to suffer the unpleasant effects of your actions and to deserve to do so
examples: It was no surprise when she left him—everyone knew he had it coming to him.

sense.definition: to not like someone and be unpleasant to them
to be capable of doing something
examples: Everyone thinks he has it in him to produce a literary classic.
You were great. I didn't know you had it in you.
You spoke really well at that meeting, standing up for us all. I never knew you had it in you.

sense.definition: to be not nearly as good as someone or something
not willing to listen to or believe something
examples: I tried to persuade her to wait but she wasn't having any of it.

sense.definition: other things, people, etc. of the same kind
examples: There's room in the basement to store old furniture and what have you.

sense.definition: used to show that you must do something
examples: Sorry, I've got to go.
Did she have to pay a fine?
You don't have to knock—just walk in.
I've got to leave by seven.
First, you have to think logically about your fears.
I have to admit, the idea of marriage scares me.
Do you have to go?

sense.definition: used to give advice or recommend something
examples: You simply have to get a new job.
You've got to try this recipe—it's delicious.

sense.definition: used to say that something must be true or must happen
examples: There has to be a reason for his strange behavior.
This war has got to end soon.

sense.definition: used to suggest that an annoying event happens in order to annoy you, or that someone does something in order to annoy you
examples: Of course, it had to start raining as soon as we got to the beach.
Do you have to hum so loudly? ( = it is annoying)
He can speak three languages.
She will try and visit tomorrow.
You must find a job.
You ought to stop smoking.
I used to smoke, but I quit two years ago.
Can I invite Mary?
Should I have invited Mary?
You shouldn't invite Mary.
The error will not have affected our results.
You have to be home by 11 o’clock.
I have to wash the car tomorrow.
I have to collect the children from school at 3 o’clock.
All nurses must wear uniform.
Changes must be recorded in the log book.
I had to wait half an hour for a bus.
We’ll have to borrow the money we need.
I have to go to the dentist tomorrow.
Do the children have to wear uniforms?
Employees must not smoke in the building.
You mustn’t leave the gate open.
You don’t have to pay for the tickets in advance.
She doesn’t have to work on weekends.
He has (got) to be the worst actor on TV!
Your trip must have been fun!

sense.definition: a male person or animal that has already been mentioned or is easily identified
examples: Everyone liked my father—he was the perfect gentleman.
He ( = the man we are watching) went through that door.

sense.definition: a person, male or female, whose sex is not stated or known, especially when referring to someone mentioned earlier or to a group in general
examples: Every child needs to know that he is loved.
He who ( = anyone who) hesitates is lost.
My daughter prefers to see a female doctor.
They have a male nanny for their sons.
Everyone needs to feel he is loved.
Does everybody know what they want?
Somebody’s left their coat here.
I hope nobody’s forgotten to bring their passport with them.
Everyone knows what’s best for him or herself.
If in doubt, ask your doctor. He/she can give you more information.
A baby cries when he or she is tired,
Babies cry when they are tired.

sense.definition: used when referring to God
the part of the body on top of the neck containing the eyes, nose, mouth, and brain
examples: She nodded her head in agreement.
He shook his head in disbelief.
The boys hung their heads in shame.
The driver suffered head injuries.
She always has her head in a book ( = is always reading).
He still has a good head of hair ( = a lot of hair).

sense.definition: the mind or brain
examples: I sometimes wonder what goes on in that head of yours.
I wish you'd use your head ( = think carefully before doing or saying something).
The thought never entered my head.
I can't work it out in my head—I need a calculator.
I can't get that tune out of my head.
When will you get it into your head ( = understand) that I don't want to discuss this anymore!
For some reason, she's got it into her head ( = believes) that the others don't like her.
Who's been putting such weird ideas into your head ( = making you believe that)?
Try to put the exams out of your head ( = stop thinking about them) for tonight.

sense.definition: the size of a person's or animal's head, used as a measurement of distance or height
examples: She's a good head taller than her sister.
The favorite won by a short head ( = a distance slightly less than the length of a horse's head).

sense.definition: a continuous pain in your head
examples: I woke up with a really bad head this morning.

sense.definition: the person in charge of a group of people or an organization
examples: the heads of government/state
the crowned heads ( = the kings and queens) of Europe
the head gardener/waiter, etc.

sense.definition: the side of a coin that has a picture of the head of a person on it, used as one choice when a coin is tossed to decide something
the end of a long narrow object that is larger or wider than the rest of it
examples: the head of a nail

sense.definition: the top or highest part of something
examples: at the head of the page
They finished the season at the head of their league.

sense.definition: the place where a river begins
the most important seat at a table
examples: The President sat at the head of the table.

sense.definition: the position at the front of a line of people
examples: The prince rode at the head of his regiment.

sense.definition: the mass of leaves or flowers at the end of a stem
examples: Remove the dead heads to encourage new growth.

sense.definition: the mass of small bubbles on the top of a glass of beer
the part of a spot on your skin that contains a thick yellow liquid ( = pus )
the part of a tape recorder or video cassette recorder that touches the tape and changes the electrical signals into sounds and/or pictures
used to say how many animals of a particular type are on a farm, in a herd, etc.
examples: 200 head of sheep

sense.definition: the pressure produced by steam in a limited space
examples: The old engine still manages to build up a good head of steam.

sense.definition: the central part of a phrase, which has the same grammatical function as the whole phrase. In the phrase “the tall man in a suit,”man is the head.
to force people to stop arguing and behave in a sensible way
to keep trying to do something that will never be successful
examples: Trying to reason with them was like banging my head against a (brick) wall.

sense.definition: to be much better than other people or things
examples: His performance stood head and shoulders above the rest.

sense.definition: to shout at someone in an angry way, especially without reason
if you bring a situation to a head or if a situation comes to a head, you are forced to deal with it quickly because it suddenly becomes very bad
to refuse to admit that a problem exists or refuse to deal with it
to be unable to understand something
examples: I couldn't make heads or tails of what he was saying.

sense.definition: to be able to do something very easily and without having to think too much
covering your whole body
examples: We were covered from head to foot in mud.
She was dressed from head to toe in red.

sense.definition: to be a sensible person
to give someone hopes about something that may not be possible or likely; to make someone act or think in an unreasonable way
examples: Who's been putting ideas into his head?

sense.definition: to deal with someone in a very direct and determined way
examples: The company will be going head to head with the giant of the pharmaceuticals market.

sense.definition: to make you feel drunk
examples: That glass of wine has gone straight to my head.

sense.definition: to make you feel too proud of yourself in a way that other people find annoying
to be aware of everything that is happening around you, even things that seem difficult or impossible to see
examples: You can't get away with anything in her class. She has eyes in the back of her head.

sense.definition: to be a sensible person
to be good at something
examples: to have a head for figures/business

sense.definition: to be thinking about something that is not connected with what you are doing
to have ideas, plans, etc. that are not realistic
to be a sensible person
examples: I kept my head on straight and did what I had to.

sense.definition: to have somewhere to live
examples: Thanks to Bob's generosity, I still have a roof over my head.

sense.definition: for each person
examples: The meal worked out at $20 a head.

sense.definition: moving forward or downward with your head in front of the rest of your body
examples: He fell head first down the stairs.

sense.definition: without thinking carefully about something before acting
examples: She got divorced and rushed head first into another marriage.

sense.definition: loving someone very much
examples: He's fallen head over heels in love with his boss.

sense.definition: used to ask someone which side of a coin they think will be facing upward when it is tossed in order to decide something by chance
used to say that some people will be punished because of something that has happened
to say something that is exactly right
to force someone to do something that they do not want to do, by making threats
to be proud of or not feel ashamed about something that you have done
examples: She managed to hold her head high and ignore what people were saying.

sense.definition: involved in something that is too difficult for you to deal with
examples: After a week in the new job, I soon realized that I was in over my head.

sense.definition: to remain calm in a difficult situation
to deal with a difficult situation, especially one in which you have financial problems, and just manage to survive
examples: I'm not sure how much longer we'll be able to keep our heads above water.

sense.definition: to avoid attracting attention to yourself
examples: If I were you, I'd keep your head down for a couple of weeks.

sense.definition: to laugh very loudly and for a long time
to laugh, etc. a lot and very loudly
to act according to what you feel rather than to what you think is sensible
to become unable to act in a calm or sensible way
to have no need or desire for something
to not hurt someone physically in any way
just guessing or using your memory, without taking time to think carefully or check the facts
examples: I can't remember the name off the top of my head, but I can look it up for you.

sense.definition: too difficult or complicated for someone to understand
examples: A lot of the jokes went ( = were) right over my head.

sense.definition: to a higher position of authority than someone
examples: I couldn't help feeling jealous when she was promoted over my head.
I'm not happy that you went over my head to ask for this time off.

sense.definition: an amount of money that is offered for capturing or killing someone
examples: Ever since he killed the gang's leader, there has been a price on his head.

sense.definition: to risk losing your job, damaging your reputation, etc. by doing or saying something
examples: It's not a matter that I'm prepared to put my head on the block for.

sense.definition: to think about or discuss something as a group
if something unpleasant rears its head or rears its ugly head, it appears or happens
to think hard in order to find an answer to something
examples: Experts have been scratching their heads over the increase in teenage crime.

sense.definition: to make people think about something in a completely different way
to suddenly decide to do something, especially something that other people think is stupid
used to show that you are annoyed that someone does not understand something
examples: When will you get it into your thick head that I don't want to see you again!

sense.definition: to make a person feel too proud in a way that other people find annoying
used to say that two people can achieve more than one person working alone
a continuous pain in the head
examples: to suffer from headaches
Red wine gives me a headache.
I have a splitting headache ( = a very bad one).
a tension headache

sense.definition: a person or thing that causes worry or trouble
examples: The real headache will be getting the bank to lend you the money.

sense.definition: to become healthy again; to make something healthy again
examples: It took a long time for the wounds to heal.
The cut healed up without leaving a scar.
This will help to heal your cuts and scratches.
It was a chance to heal the wounds in the party ( = to repair the damage that had been done).

sense.definition: to cure someone who is sick; to make someone feel happy again
examples: the story of Jesus healing ten lepers of their disease
I felt healed by his love.

sense.definition: to put an end to something or make something easier to bear; to end or become easier to bear
examples: She was never able to heal the rift between herself and her father.
The breach between them never really healed.

sense.definition: the condition of a person's body or mind
examples: Exhaust fumes are bad for your health.
to be in poor/good/excellent/the best of health
Smoking can seriously damage your health.
mental health
She can't travel in her condition.
My condition requires me to watch what I eat.
My parents have had a lot of health problems this year.
Many of the patients at the clinic are dealing with serious mental health issues.
His disability does not keep him from living a full and active life.

sense.definition: the state of being physically and mentally healthy
examples: He was nursed back to health by his wife.
She was glowing with health and clearly enjoying life.
As long as you have your health, nothing else matters.

sense.definition: the work of providing medical services
examples: All parties are promising to increase spending on health.
the Department of Health
health insurance
health and safety regulations ( = laws that protect the health of people at work)

sense.definition: how successful something is
examples: the health of your marriage/finances

sense.definition: a report that says someone is healthy or that something is in good condition
examples: Doctors gave him a clean bill of health after a series of tests and examinations.
The building was given a clean bill of health by the surveyor.

sense.definition: to wish someone good health as you lift your glass, and then drink from it
having good health and not likely to become sick
examples: a healthy child/animal/tree
Stay healthy by eating well and exercising regularly.
Is he well enough to travel?
I don't feel good.
She's looking much better these days.
Are you feeling all right?
She says that she's OK now, and will be back at work tomorrow.
“How are you?” “Fine, thanks.”
Stay healthy by exercising regularly.
After a few weeks, she was feeling stronger.
I go swimming every day in order to stay in shape.

sense.definition: good for your health
examples: a healthy diet/climate/lifestyle

sense.definition: showing that you are in good health
examples: to have a healthy appetite
a shampoo that keeps hair looking healthy

sense.definition: normal and sensible
examples: The child showed a healthy curiosity.
She has a healthy respect for her rival's talents.
It's not healthy the way she clings to the past.

sense.definition: successful and working well
examples: a healthy economy
Your car doesn't sound very healthy.

sense.definition: large and showing success
examples: a healthy bank balance
a healthy profit
to eat healthily

sense.definition: to be aware of sounds with your ears
examples: I can't hear very well.
She heard footsteps behind her.
I couldn't hear anything.
He could hear a dog barking.
Did you hear him go out?
I heard a car drive off.
Didn't you hear what I said?
She has been heard to make threats to her former lover.

sense.definition: to listen or pay attention to someone or something
examples: Did you hear that interview on the radio last night?
a chance to hear the first movement again
to hear both sides of the argument
Be quiet—I can't hear myself think! ( = it is so noisy that I can't think clearly)
Have you ever heard him lecture?
We'd better hear what they have to say.
I hear what you're saying ( = I have listened to your opinion), but you're wrong.

sense.definition: to be told about something
examples: Haven't you heard? She resigned.
“I'm getting married.” “So I've heard.”
Things are going well from what I hear.
I was sorry to hear about your accident.
Wait till he hears about this.
I've heard about people like you.
We had heard nothing for weeks.
I was delighted to hear your good news.
I was surprised to hear (that) he was married.
I hear you've been away this weekend.
I've heard it said (that) they met in Italy.
Did you hear what happened?

sense.definition: to listen to and judge a case in court
examples: The appeal was heard in private.
Today the jury began to hear the evidence.

sense.definition: to imagine that you can see or hear something that is in fact not there
used to ask someone if they have heard a particular joke before
used to show that you agree with or approve of what someone has just said, especially during a speech
to hear/see someone or something for the last time
examples: That was the last I ever saw of her.
Unfortunately, I don't think we've heard the last of this affair.

sense.definition: to hear people talking about something
examples: I've often heard tell of such things.

sense.definition: used to say that you do not really believe someone's promises or excuses because they are the same ones you have heard before
used to say that someone or something deserves praise
examples: Let's hear it for the teachers, for a change.

sense.definition: to express your feelings, opinions, etc. in a way that makes people notice and consider them
examples: The program gives ordinary viewers a chance to make their voices heard.

sense.definition: to keep being reminded of something because someone is always talking to you about it
examples: If we don't get her a dog we'll never hear the end of it.

sense.definition: it was extremely quiet
examples: The audience was so quiet you could have heard a pin drop.

sense.definition: used to tell someone in an angry way to pay attention and obey you
examples: You can't go—do you hear me?

sense.definition: to receive a letter, e-mail, phone call, etc. from someone
examples: I look forward to hearing from you.
I haven't heard anything from her for months.
It was good to hear from him again.

sense.definition: the ability to hear
examples: Her hearing is poor.
He's hearing-impaired ( = not able to hear well).
The explosion damaged his hearing.

sense.definition: an official meeting at which the facts about a crime, complaint, etc. are presented to the person or group of people who will have to decide what action to take
examples: a court/disciplinary hearing

sense.definition: an opportunity to explain your actions, ideas, or opinions
examples: to get/give someone a fair hearing
His views may be extreme but he deserves a hearing.

sense.definition: (to allow someone) the opportunity to give their opinion of something before deciding if they have done something wrong, often in court
examples: I'll make sure that you get a fair trial.

sense.definition: near enough to someone so that they can hear what is said
examples: She shouldn't have said such things in your hearing.
I had no reason to believe there was anyone within hearing.

sense.definition: too far away to hear someone or something or to be heard
examples: She had moved out of hearing.

sense.definition: to know about someone or something because you have been told about them
examples: I've never heard of the place.
I was so sorry to hear of your father's death.
She disappeared and was never heard of again.
The last I heard of him he was living in St. Louis.
This is the first I've heard of it!

sense.definition: the organ in the chest that sends blood around the body, usually on the left in humans
examples: The patient's heart stopped beating for a few seconds.
heart trouble/failure/disease
to have a weak heart
I could feel my heart pounding in my chest ( = because of excitement etc.).

sense.definition: the outside part of the chest where the heart is
examples: She clasped the photo to her heart.

sense.definition: the place in a person where the feelings and emotions are thought to be, especially those connected with love
examples: She has a kind heart.
Have you no heart?
He returned with a heavy heart ( = sad).
Her novels tend to deal with affairs of the heart.
The story captured the hearts and minds of a generation.

sense.definition: having the type of character or personality mentioned
examples: cold-hearted
kind-hearted

sense.definition: the most important part of something
examples: the heart of the matter/problem
The committee's report went to the heart of the government's dilemma.
The distinction between right and wrong lies at the heart of all questions of morality.

sense.definition: the part that is in the center of something
examples: a quiet hotel in the very heart of the city

sense.definition: the smaller leaves in the middle of a cabbage, lettuce, etc.
a thing shaped like a heart, often red and used as a symbol of love; a symbol shaped like a heart used to mean the verb “love”
examples: The words “I love you” were written inside a big red heart.
I ♥ New York.

sense.definition: one of the four sets of cards (called suits ) in a deck of cards, with red heart symbols on them
examples: the queen of hearts
Hearts are trumps.

sense.definition: one card from the set of hearts
examples: Who played that heart?

sense.definition: used to say that when you are away from someone that you love, you love them even more
used to say what someone is really like even though they may seem to be something different
examples: He's still a socialist at heart.

sense.definition: if something is etched on your memory, you remember it because it has made a strong impression on you
to make someone feel very unhappy
examples: She broke his heart when she called off the engagement.
It breaks my heart to see you like this.

sense.definition: using only your memory
examples: I've dialed the number so many times I know it by heart.

sense.definition: if you have a change of heart, your attitude toward something changes, usually making you feel more friendly, helpful, etc.
examples: Dan did not want to get married but recently he's had a change of heart.

sense.definition: having a lot of importance and interest for someone
used to emphasize that you are telling the truth or will do what you promise
examples: I saw him do it—cross my heart.

sense.definition: to feel very unhappy, especially because you want someone or something you cannot have
examples: I'm not going to mope at home, eating my heart out for some man.

sense.definition: to be able or willing to do something
examples: Can you find it in your heart to forgive her?
He couldn't find it in himself to trust anyone again.

sense.definition: in a way that is sincere
examples: I beg you, from the bottom of my heart, to spare his life.
It was clearly an offer that came from the heart.

sense.definition: to make someone feel positive, especially when they thought that they had no chance of achieving something
to give your love to one person
used to ask someone to be kind and/or reasonable
examples: Have a heart! I've nowhere else to stay!

sense.definition: to be a very kind person
to be a person who does not show others sympathy
to want someone to be happy and successful even though your actions may not show this
with a lot of energy and enthusiasm
examples: They threw themselves heart and soul into the project.

sense.definition: used to say that you do not feel sympathy for someone
examples: “I have to go to Brazil on business.” “My heart bleeds for you!”

sense.definition: used to say that you feel a lot of sympathy for someone
examples: Our hearts go out to the families of the victims.

sense.definition: someone feels nervous or frightened about something
examples: My heart was in my mouth as she opened the envelope.

sense.definition: used to say that someone's intentions are kind and sincere even though they sometimes do the wrong thing
used to say that you are not very interested in or enthusiastic about something
used to say that someone has a sudden feeling of happiness or excitement
examples: My heart leapt at the news.

sense.definition: used to say that someone suddenly feels sad or depressed about something
examples: My heart sank when I saw how much work there was left.
She watched him go with a sinking heart.

sense.definition: used to say that someone has a sudden feeling of fear, excitement, etc.
examples: My heart skipped a beat when I saw who it was.

sense.definition: a home is where the people you love are
if you know something in your heart, you have a strong feeling that it is true
examples: She knew in her heart of hearts that she was making the wrong decision.

sense.definition: it makes someone feel happy when they see or hear something
examples: It does my heart good to see the old place being taken care of so well.

sense.definition: to act according to what you feel rather than to what you think is sensible
to stop hoping for something or trying to do something because you no longer feel confident
to fall in love with someone or something
a man/woman who likes the same things or has the same opinions as you
to be unable to do something because you know that it will make someone sad or upset
from feelings of kindness, without thinking about what advantage there will be for you
examples: You're not telling me he offered to lend you the money out of the goodness of his heart?

sense.definition: to tell someone all your problems, feelings, etc.
to want something very much
examples: They've set their heart on a house in the country.

sense.definition: very unhappy or disappointed
to cry noisily for a long time because you are very sad
to make someone fall in love with you
to make someone be afraid, etc.
to feel more positive about something, especially when you thought that you had no chance of achieving something
examples: The government can take heart from the latest opinion polls.

sense.definition: to be very upset by something that someone says or does
examples: You shouldn't take everything he says to heart.

sense.definition: to strongly affect you in an emotional way
to destroy the most important part or aspect of something
examples: Closing the factory tore the heart out of the community.

sense.definition: as much as you want
examples: a supervised play area where children can run around to their heart's content

sense.definition: the way to make someone like or love you
examples: The way to a man's heart is through his stomach ( = by giving him good food).

sense.definition: to allow your feelings to be seen by other people
examples: He's not one to wear his heart on his sleeve.

sense.definition: to make someone love you
completely
examples: I hope with all my heart that things work out for you.

sense.definition: thinking and behaving like a young person even when you are old
examples: My father is 76 but he's still young at heart.

sense.definition: the quality of being hot
examples: He could feel the heat of the sun on his back.
Heat rises.
The fire gave off intense heat.

This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making. / This diagram shows how paper is made.
First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips.
Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine.
Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed.
Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities. /…is bleached so that impurities can be removed.
The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt.
As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away. This causes the solid material to sink to the bottom, forming a layer of paper.
At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper. / …dry the paper at the same time.
The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls. /Finally, the paper is wound onto large rolls.

sense.definition: to become or to make something greater in amount, number, value, etc.

sense.definition: used to emphasize a positive statement or answer

sense.definition: used to show that you are surprised at something or that you find something ridiculous

sense.definition: used when you are repeating a question that someone has just asked and showing that you do not know the answer

sense.definition: a sign or measure that something else can be judged by

sense.definition: the small number written above a larger number to show how many times that number must be multiplied by itself. In the equation 42 = 16, the number 2 is an index.

sense.definition: to be a sign of something; to show that something is possible or likely

sense.definition: kind; friendly
examples: Our new neighbors are very nice.

sense.definition: bad or unpleasant
examples: That's a nice thing to say!

sense.definition: involving a very small detail or difference
examples: a nice point of law ( = one that is difficult to decide)

sense.definition: very kind and friendly, especially when you are not expecting it
a friendly way of saying goodbye, especially to customers
a way of describing a man who is very honest and thinks about the wishes and feelings of other people
examples: I was tired of helping other people. From now on it was no more Mr. Nice Guy ( = I would stop being pleasant and kind).

sense.definition: used when you wish that you had someone's success or good luck and think they have achieved it with little effort
examples: He was paid $200 for a ten-minute speech? Nice work if you can get it.

sense.definition: in an attractive or acceptable way; well
examples: The room was nicely furnished.

sense.definition: in a kind, friendly, or polite way
examples: If you ask her nicely she might say yes.

sense.definition: carefully; exactly
examples: His novels nicely describe life in Britain between the wars.

sense.definition: to be making good progress
examples: Her new business is doing very nicely.

sense.definition: to be acceptable
examples: Tomorrow at ten will do nicely ( = will be a good time).

sense.definition: the daughter of your brother or sister; the daughter of your husband's or wife's brother or sister
the time between one day and the next when it is dark, when people usually sleep
examples: These animals only come out at night.

on the night of January 10

Where did you spend the night?
You're welcome to stay the night here.
What is he doing calling at this time of night?
You'll feel better after you've had a good night's sleep.
The trip was for ten nights.
The hotel costs $65 per person per night.
the night train/boat/flight

sense.definition: the evening until you go to bed
examples: Let's go out on Saturday night.
Bill's parents came for dinner last night.
She doesn't like to walk home late at night.
I saw her in town the other night ( = a few nights ago).

sense.definition: an evening when a special event happens
examples: the first/opening night ( = of a play, movie, etc.)
a karaoke night
an Irish/a Scandinavian, etc. night ( = with Irish/Scandinavian music, entertainment, etc.)

sense.definition: to dance for the whole evening or night
to go to bed earlier or later than usual
examples: I've had a lot of late nights recently.

sense.definition: to sleep well/badly during the night
in the quietest part of the night
examples: I crept out of bed in the dead of night and sneaked downstairs.

sense.definition: used to say that a performance, an event, etc. will be successful even if the preparations for it have not gone well
if two people or things are like night and day, they are completely different from each other
at all times of the day and night (used to emphasize that something happens very often or that it happens continuously)
examples: She talks about him morning, noon, and night.

sense.definition: all the time; continuously
examples: The machines are kept running night and day.

sense.definition: an evening that you spend enjoying yourself away from home
examples: They enjoy a night out occasionally.

sense.definition: used by children or to children, to mean “Good night”
examples: “Nighty night, sleep tight!”

sense.definition: to stay with someone for a night
examples: My daughter's spending the night with a friend.

sense.definition: to stay with someone for a night and have sex with them
the time during the night when it is quiet and calm
used to refer to ghosts and other supernatural things that cannot be explained
examples: There are mysterious lights in the sky and things that go bump in the night.
He can't get used to working nights ( = at night).

sense.definition: used to give a negative reply or statement
examples: Just say yes or no.
“Are you ready?” “No, I'm not.”
Sorry, the answer's no.
“Another drink?” “No, thanks.”
It's about 70—no, I'm wrong—80 miles from Rome.
No! Don't touch it! It's hot.
“It was Tony.” “No, you're wrong. It was Ted.”
“It's not very good, is it?” “No, you're right, it isn't ( = I agree).”

sense.definition: used to express shock or surprise at what someone has said
examples: “She's had an accident.” “Oh, no!”

sense.definition: to refuse to accept that someone does not want something, will not do something, etc.
examples: You're coming and I won't take no for an answer!

sense.definition: used when you cannot give a clear answer to a question
examples: “Are you enjoying it?” “Yes and no.”

sense.definition: if you nod or nod your head or if your head nods, you move your head up and down to show agreement, understanding, etc.
examples: I asked him if he would help me and he nodded.

sense.definition: to move your head down and up once to say hello to someone or to give them a sign to do something
examples: The president nodded to the crowd as he passed in the motorcade.

to nod a greeting

sense.definition: to move your head in the direction of someone or something to show that you are talking about them/it
examples: I asked where Steve was and she nodded in the direction of the kitchen.

sense.definition: to let your head fall forward when you are sleeping in a chair
examples: He sat nodding in front of the fire.

sense.definition: to only know someone or something slightly
a sound, especially when it is loud, unpleasant, or disturbing
examples: a rattling noise
What's that noise?
Don't make a noise.
They were making too much noise.
I was woken by the noise of a car starting up.
We had to shout above the noise of the traffic.
to reduce noise levels

sense.definition: extra electrical or electronic signals that are not part of the signal that is being broadcast or transmitted and that may damage it
information that is not wanted and that can make it difficult for the important or useful information to be seen clearly
examples: There is some noise in the data that needs to be reduced.

sense.definition: to complain loudly
to talk in an indirect way about something that you think you might do
examples: The company has been making noises about closing several factories.

sense.definition: to complain about something
to make remarks of the kind mentioned, even when that is not what you really think
examples: He made all the right noises at the meeting yesterday ( = he said what people wanted to hear).

sense.definition: making a lot of noise
examples: noisy children/traffic/crowds
a noisy protest ( = when people shout)

sense.definition: full of noise
examples: a noisy classroom

sense.definition: not
examples: nonsense
nonfiction
nonalcoholic
nonprofit
noncommittally

sense.definition: not one of a group of people or things; not any
examples: None of these pens work.

sense.definition: to refuse to accept something
examples: I offered to pay but he was having none of it.

sense.definition: only
examples: None but he knew the truth.

sense.definition: used to emphasize who or what someone or something is, when this is surprising
examples: Her first customer was none other than Mrs. Obama.

sense.definition: ideas, statements, or beliefs that you think are ridiculous or not true
examples: Reports that he has resigned are nonsense.

sense.definition: silly or unacceptable behavior
examples: The new teacher won't stand for any nonsense.

sense.definition: spoken or written words that have no meaning or make no sense
examples: Most of the translation he did for me was complete nonsense.

sense.definition: to reduce the value of something by a lot; to make something seem ridiculous
examples: If people can bribe police officers, it makes complete nonsense of the legal system.

sense.definition: used by some people to say that they think that something is stupid or not true
not anyone; no person
examples: No one was at home.

sense.definition: and not

sense.definition: used before a positive verb to agree with something negative that has just been said
examples: She doesn't like them, nor does Jeff.

sense.definition: typical, usual, or ordinary; what you would expect
examples: perfectly ( = completely) normal

sense.definition: not suffering from any mental disorder
examples: People who commit such crimes aren't normal.

sense.definition: in the way that is normal or usual; as often happens
examples: Everyone blamed me, as per usual.

sense.definition: usually; in normal circumstances
examples: I'm not normally allowed to stay out late.

sense.definition: in the usual or ordinary way
examples: Her heart is beating normally.

sense.definition: the direction that is on your left when you watch the sun rise; one of the four main points of the compass
examples: Which way is north?

sense.definition: the northern part of a country, a region, or the world
examples: birds migrating from the north

sense.definition: the northeastern states of the U.S. that fought against the South in the American Civil War
the richer and more developed countries of the world, especially in N. America and Europe
located in the north or facing north; connected with or typical of the north part of the world or a region
examples: the northern slopes of the mountains
northern New York State

sense.definition: the part of the face that sticks out above the mouth, used for breathing and smelling things
examples: He broke his nose in the fight.

sense.definition: having the type of nose mentioned
examples: red-nosed
large-nosed

sense.definition: the front part of a plane, spacecraft, etc.
examples: Heat detectors are fitted in the nose of the missile.

sense.definition: a special ability for finding or recognizing something
examples: As a journalist, she has always had a nose for a good story.

sense.definition: a sense of smell
examples: a dog with a good nose

sense.definition: a characteristic smell
to do something when you are angry that is meant to harm someone else but that also harms you
to be guided by your sense of smell
to go straight forward
examples: The garage is a mile ahead up the hill—just follow your nose.

sense.definition: to act according to what seems right or reasonable, rather than following any particular rules
to be reading something and giving it all your attention
examples: Peter always has his nose in a book.

sense.definition: used to say that someone is not upset or annoyed about something because it does not affect them in a bad way
to avoid doing anything wrong or illegal
examples: Since leaving prison, he's managed to keep his nose clean.

sense.definition: to try not to become involved in things that do not concern you
to work hard for a long period of time without stopping
to make someone do everything you want; to control someone completely
to behave in a way that suggests that you think that you are better than someone or that something is not good enough for you
exactly

sense.definition: to pay much too much money for something
very obvious
to try to become involved in something that does not concern you
examples: He's always poking his nose into other people's business.

sense.definition: a polite way of referring to the fact that a woman is going to the bathroom
examples: I'm just going to powder my nose.

sense.definition: to upset or annoy someone, especially by not giving them enough attention
to keep reminding someone in an unkind way of their past mistakes
to make a rude sign with your thumb on your nose; to show that you have no respect for someone or something
examples: The company just thumbs its nose at the legislation on pollution.

sense.definition: to refuse something, especially because you do not think that it is good enough for you
if something is under someone's nose, it is very close to them but they cannot see it

sense.definition: if something happens under someone's nose, they do not notice it even though it is not being done secretly

sense.definition: in a way that is unfriendly and suggests that you think that you are better than other people

examples: She did not/didn't see him.

I can't see from here.

sense.definition: used after hope, expect, believe, etc. to give a negative reply

sense.definition: used to show a negative possibility

sense.definition: used to say that you do not want something or will not allow something

sense.definition: used for emphasis to mean “no thing or person”

sense.definition: used to politely accept thanks or to agree to something

sense.definition: used to emphasize that something else is also true

sense.definition: used to state that you are not suggesting something

sense.definition: of importance or of great interest

sense.definition: (it's) very easy

sense.definition: used to say that you enjoy something very much

sense.definition: a short announcement made at the beginning or end of a meeting, a church service, etc.

sense.definition: not long in advance; without warning or time for preparation

sense.definition: the 11th month of the year, between October and December

He'll be home by now.

sense.definition: at or from this moment, but not before

sense.definition: used to show that you are annoyed about something
examples: Now they want to tax food!

sense.definition: from time to time; occasionally

sense.definition: used when turning to a fresh activity or subject

sense.definition: used to show in a mild way that you do not approve of something

sense.definition: at one time… at another time…

sense.definition: this is the only opportunity someone will have to do something

sense.definition: used when you are annoyed because someone is always asking questions or interrupting you

sense.definition: far from; not at all

sense.definition: impossible for anyone to find or see

sense.definition: of the nucleus ( = central part) of an atom

sense.definition: a word or symbol that represents an amount or a quantity

even numbers ( = 2, 4, 6, etc.)
odd numbers ( = 1, 3, 5, etc.)

sense.definition: used before a figure to show the position of something in a series

sense.definition: a number used to identify something or communicate by telephone, fax, etc.

sense.definition: information that is given in the form of numbers
examples: Tell Tommy to run the numbers for the annual report.

sense.definition: a song or dance, especially one of several in a performance
examples: They sang a slow romantic number.

sense.definition: a thing, such as a dress or a car, that is admired
examples: She was wearing a black velvet number.

sense.definition: a group or quantity of people
examples: one of our number ( = one of us)

sense.definition: the form of a word, showing whether one or more than one person or thing is being talked about
examples: The word “men” is plural in number.

sense.definition: following a set of simple instructions identified by numbers

sense.definition: following closely the accepted rules for doing something
to hurt someone or damage something, either emotionally or physically
examples: The divorce really did a number on her ability to trust people.

sense.definition: to know what someone is really like and what they plan to do
examples: He thinks he can fool me, but I've got his number.

sense.definition: the time has come when you will die or lose everything
a way of considering an activity, etc. that is concerned only with the number of people doing something, things achieved, etc., not with who or what they are
examples: Candidates were playing the numbers game as the crucial vote drew closer.

sense.definition: a person who does the same job as you in another organization

sense.definition: being in a group makes you safer and makes you feel more confident

examples: They won the argument by sheer weight of numbers.

sense.definition: existing in large numbers synonym many
examples: He has been late on numerous occasions.

This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making. / This diagram shows how paper is made.
First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips.
Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine.
Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed.
Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities. /…is bleached so that impurities can be removed.
The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt.
As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away. This causes the solid material to sink to the bottom, forming a layer of paper.
At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper. / …dry the paper at the same time.
The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls. /Finally, the paper is wound onto large rolls.

sense.definition: to make someone believe something that is not true
an easy life that is full of pleasure but that causes you harm in the end
an easy life that is full of pleasure but that causes you harm in the end
to make it easier for someone or something to develop or make progress
examples: These negotiations are intended to smooth the path to a peace treaty.
We're trying to smooth the way for women who want to resume their careers.

sense.definition: to behave or think in ways that are not acceptable to the people around you
examples: He's an artist who chose to stray from the path.

sense.definition: the ability to stay calm and accept a delay or something annoying without complaining
examples: She has little patience with ( = will not accept or consider) such views.
People have lost patience with ( = have become annoyed about) the slow pace of reform.
My patience is wearing thin.
Teaching children with special needs requires patience and understanding.
You'd try the patience of a saint!

sense.definition: the ability to spend a lot of time doing something difficult that needs a lot of attention and effort
examples: It takes time and patience to photograph wildlife.
I don't have the patience to do jigsaw puzzles.

sense.definition: the fact of being extremely patient and not complaining
examples: You need the patience of Job to deal with some of our customers.

sense.definition: to make someone feel impatient
examples: His stubbornness would try the patience of a saint.

sense.definition: a person who is receiving medical treatment, especially in a hospital
examples: cancer patients

sense.definition: a person who receives treatment from a particular doctor, dentist, etc.
examples: He's one of Dr. Shaw's patients.

sense.definition: the person or thing that is affected by the action of the verb. In the sentence “I started the car,” the patient is car. compare agent
the regular way in which something happens or is done
examples: changing patterns of behavior
an irregular sleeping pattern
The murders all seem to follow a (similar) pattern ( = happen in the same way).

sense.definition: an excellent example to copy
examples: This system sets the pattern for others to follow.

sense.definition: a regular arrangement of lines, shapes, colors, etc. as a design on material, carpets, etc.
examples: a pattern of diamonds and squares
a shirt with a floral pattern

sense.definition: a design, set of instructions, or shape to cut around that you use in order to make something
examples: a knitting pattern
She bought a dress pattern and some material.

sense.definition: a small piece of material, paper, etc. that helps you choose the design of something synonym sample
examples: wallpaper patterns

sense.definition: to stop talking or doing something for a short time before continuing
examples: Anita paused for a moment, then said, “All right.”
The woman spoke almost without pausing for breath ( = very quickly).
I paused at the door and looked back.
Pausing only to pull on a sweater, he ran out of the house.

sense.definition: to stop a tape, CD, etc. for a short time using the pause button
examples: She paused the DVD and went to answer the phone.

sense.definition: to give someone money for work, goods, services, etc.
examples: I'll pay for the tickets.
Are you paying in cash or by credit card?
My company pays well ( = pays high salaries).
Her parents paid for her to go to Jamaica.
to pay cash
She pays $875 a month for this apartment.
Would you mind paying the taxi driver?
He still hasn't paid me the money he owes me.
I'm paid $100 a day.
I don't pay you to sit around all day doing nothing!

sense.definition: to give someone money that you owe them
examples: to pay a bill/debt/fine/ransom, etc.
Membership fees should be paid to the secretary.
Have you paid him the rent yet?

sense.definition: to produce a profit
examples: It's hard to make farming pay.

sense.definition: to result in some advantage or profit for someone
examples: Crime doesn't pay.
It pays to keep up to date with your work.
It would probably pay you to hire an accountant.

sense.definition: to suffer or be punished for your beliefs or actions
examples: You'll pay for that remark!
Many people paid with their lives ( = they died).

sense.definition: used with some nouns to show that you are giving or doing the thing mentioned
examples: I didn't pay attention to what she was saying.
The director paid tribute to all she had done for the charity.
I'll pay a call on ( = visit) my friends.
I'll pay you a call when I'm in town.
He's always paying me compliments.

sense.definition: to cost/pay a lot of money
a lot of trouble
examples: There'll be hell to pay when he finds out.

sense.definition: to pay careful attention to someone or something
examples: They gave little heed to the rumors.
I paid no heed at the time but later I had cause to remember what he'd said.
Small businesses would be wise to take heed of the warnings contained in the Secretary's speech.

sense.definition: the person who provides the money for something can also control how it is spent
to treat someone with great respect in order to gain favor with them
to produce great advantages or profits
examples: Exercising regularly will pay dividends in the end.

sense.definition: to work hard and experience difficulties before achieving success
examples: She paid her dues singing in the chorus for very little money before becoming a star.

sense.definition: to save as much money as it cost
examples: The rail pass will pay for itself after about two trips.

sense.definition: used to emphasize that something cost(s) a lot of money, especially if the money is wasted
examples: I paid good money for this jacket, and now look at it—it's ruined!

sense.definition: to suffer because of bad luck, a mistake, or something you have done
examples: He looked terrible this morning. I think he's paying the penalty for all those late nights.
They're now paying the price for past mistakes.
She thinks that any inconvenience is a price worth paying for living in such a beautiful place.

sense.definition: to visit someone or to send a message of good wishes as a sign of respect for them
examples: Many came to pay their last respects ( = by attending someone's funeral).

sense.definition: used to say that someone is being punished for a crime, usually by being put in prison
examples: He paid his debt to society for his previous convictions and is now a free man.

sense.definition: to pay much too much money for something
to make enough money to pay what it costs to keep it going
examples: The bridge is still not paying its way.

sense.definition: to pay for everything yourself without having to rely on anyone else's money
to do the same thing to someone as they have done to you, but with more force, enthusiasm, etc.
to borrow money from one person to pay back what you owe to another person; to take money from one thing to use for something else
to return money that you borrowed from someone
examples: I'll pay you back next week.
You can pay back the loan over a period of three years.
Did he ever pay you back that $100 he owes you?

sense.definition: to punish someone for making you or someone else suffer
examples: I'll pay him back for making me look like a fool in front of everyone.

sense.definition: the act of paying someone or something or of being paid
examples: payment in installments/in advance/by check/in cash
There will be a penalty for late payment of bills.
What method of payment do you prefer?

sense.definition: a sum of money paid or expected to be paid
examples: a cash payment
They are finding it difficult to meet the payments on their car.
He agreed to make ten monthly payments of $150.

sense.definition: a reward or an act of thanks for something you have done
examples: We'd like you to accept this gift in payment for your kindness.
Is this all the payment I get for my efforts?

sense.definition: when something has been paid
examples: Attendance is only allowed on payment of the full registration fee.
ten monthly payments of $50
payment in advance
an insurance premium
a premium for express delivery
You can increase your monthly contributions to your savings account.
a subscription to “Newsweek”
to set up a repayment plan
We've put down a 5% deposit on the house.
I made a $500 deposit into my checking account.
We paid for the car by/in installments.

sense.definition: a situation or a period of time in which there is no war or violence in a country or an area
examples: war and peace
peace talks/negotiations
The negotiators are trying to make peace between the warring factions.
A UN force has been sent to keep the peace ( = to prevent people from fighting).
After years of war, the people long for a lasting peace.
the Peace of Utrecht, 1713 ( = the agreement ending the war)
The two communities live together in peace.
The countries have been at peace for more than a century.
the peace movement ( = that tries to prevent war by protesting, persuading politicians, etc.)

sense.definition: the state of being calm or quiet
examples: She lay back and enjoyed the peace of the summer evening.
I would work better if I had some peace and quiet.
He just wants to be left in peace ( = not to be disturbed).
I need to check that she is all right, just for my own peace of mind ( = so that I do not have to worry).
He never felt really at peace with himself.
They were charged with disturbing the peace ( = behaving in a noisy and violent way).

sense.definition: the state of living in friendship with someone without arguing
examples: They simply can't seem to live in peace with each other.
She felt at peace with the world.

sense.definition: to say nothing although you would like to give your opinion
to end an argument with someone, usually by saying you are sorry
examples: He made peace with his brother when their father was dying.

sense.definition: used when someone is complaining that they have a lot of work to do
not involving a war, violence, or argument
examples: a peaceful protest/demonstration/solution
They hope for a peaceful settlement of the dispute.
people of different religions living in peaceful coexistence

sense.definition: quiet and calm; not worried or disturbed in any way
examples: a peaceful atmosphere
peaceful sleep
It's so peaceful out here in the country.
He had a peaceful life.

sense.definition: trying to create peace or to live in peace; not liking violence or disagreement
examples: a peaceful society
The aims of the organization are wholly peaceful.
The siege has ended peacefully.
The baby slept peacefully.
He died peacefully in her arms.
world peace
I just need some peace and quiet.
a sense of calm and inner peacefulness

sense.definition: the point when someone or something is best, most successful, strongest, etc.
examples: Traffic reaches its peak between 8 and 9 in the morning.
She's at the peak of her career.
a boxer well past his peak
the peaks and valleys of married life
Membership of the club has fallen from a peak of 600 people in 2006.

sense.definition: the pointed top of a mountain; a mountain with a pointed top
examples: a mountain peak
snow-capped/jagged peaks
The climbers made camp halfway up the peak.

sense.definition: any narrow and pointed shape, edge, etc.
examples: Whisk the egg whites into stiff peaks.
He combed his hair into a peak.

sense.definition: an instrument made of plastic or metal used for writing with ink
examples: pen and ink
a new book from the pen of John Grisham

sense.definition: a small piece of land surrounded by a fence in which farm animals are kept
examples: a sheep pen

sense.definition: people who write books, poems, etc. have a greater effect on history and human affairs than soldiers and wars
to write or start to write something
a small mistake in something that you write or say
examples: Did I call you Richard? Sorry, Robert, just a slip of the tongue.

sense.definition: a punishment for breaking a law, rule, or contract
examples: to impose a penalty
Assault carries a maximum penalty of seven years' imprisonment.
The penalty for traveling without a ticket is $200.
Contractors who fall behind schedule incur heavy financial penalties.
a penalty clause in a contract
You can withdraw money from the account at any time without penalty.
Harsher penalties are being imposed for crimes involving firearms.

sense.definition: a disadvantage suffered as a result of something
examples: One of the penalties of fame is the loss of privacy.

sense.definition: a disadvantage given to a player or a team when they break a rule
examples: He incurred a ten-second penalty in the first round.

sense.definition: a chance to score a goal or point without any defending players, except the goalkeeper, trying to stop it. This chance is given because the other team has broken the rules; the goal or point that is given if it is successful
examples: We were awarded a penalty after a late tackle.
I volunteered to take the penalty ( = be the person who tries to score the goal/point).
He missed a penalty in the last minute of the game.

sense.definition: to suffer because of bad luck, a mistake, or something you have done
examples: He looked terrible this morning. I think he's paying the penalty for all those late nights.
They're now paying the price for past mistakes.
She thinks that any inconvenience is a price worth paying for living in such a beautiful place.

sense.definition: a narrow piece of wood, or a metal or plastic case, containing a black or colored substance, used for drawing or writing
examples: a pencil drawing
I'll get a pencil and paper.
She scribbled a note in pencil.
colored pencils

sense.definition: persons; men, women, and children
examples: At least ten people were killed in the crash.
There were a lot of people at the party.
Many young people are out of work.

sense.definition: persons in general or everyone
examples: He doesn't care what people think of him.
She tends to annoy people.

sense.definition: all the persons who live in a particular place or belong to a particular country, race, etc.
examples: the American people
the native peoples of the Great Plains

sense.definition: the ordinary men and women of a country rather than those who govern or have a special position in society
examples: the life of the common people
It was felt that the government was no longer in touch with the people.

sense.definition: men and women who work in a particular type of job or are involved in a particular area of activity
examples: a meeting with business people and bankers
These garments are intended for professional sports people.

sense.definition: the men, women, and children that a person leads
examples: The king urged his people to prepare for war.
the story of the Zulu leader who died while attempting to free his people

sense.definition: the men and women who work for you or support you
examples: I've had my people watching the house for a few days.
Our people are all highly trained and motivated.

sense.definition: guests or friends
examples: I'm having people to dinner this evening.

sense.definition: the men, women, and children that you are closely related to, especially your parents, grandparents, etc.
examples: She's spending the holidays with her people.

sense.definition: used when trying to get a group of people to listen to you
examples: Look, people, you’ve got to quiet down or we’ll be here all night.

sense.definition: to please everyone by changing your attitudes or opinions to suit different people
to be understood or used in different ways by different people
a man who understands and is sympathetic to ordinary people
examples: He is not only a statesman, but also a man of the people.

sense.definition: when you say of all people, you are emphasizing that someone is the person you would most or least expect to do something
examples: She of all people should know the answer to that.

sense.definition: you should not criticize other people, because they will easily find ways of criticizing you
used when addressing a group of people
examples: Would you people please move on?

sense.definition: a powder made from dried berries (calledpeppercorn), used to give a hot flavor to food
examples: Season with salt and pepper
freshly ground pepper

sense.definition: a hollow fruit, usually red, green, or yellow, with a sweet or spicy flavor, eaten as a vegetable or used to give flavor to food
used to express the cost or amount of something for each person, number used, distance traveled, etc.
examples: Rooms cost $50 per person, per night.
60 miles per hour
This country has a higher crime rate per 100,000 of the population than most other industrialized countries.

sense.definition: following something that has been decided
examples: The work was carried out as per instructions.

sense.definition: in the way that is normal or usual; as often happens
examples: Everyone blamed me, as per usual.

sense.definition: one part in every hundred
examples: Poor families spend about 80 to 90 percent of their income on food.
It is often stated that we use only 10 percent of our brain.

sense.definition: the number, amount, or rate of something, expressed as if it is part of a total which is 100; a part or share of a whole
examples: What percentage of the population is overweight?
A high percentage of the female staff works part-time.
Interest rates are expected to rise by one percentage point ( = one percent).
The figure is expressed as a percentage.
The results were analyzed in percentage terms.

sense.definition: a share of the profits of something
examples: He gets a percentage for every car sold.

sense.definition: having everything that is necessary; complete and without faults or weaknesses
examples: in perfect condition
a perfect set of teeth
Well I'm sorry—but nobody's perfect ( = used when someone has criticized you).

sense.definition: completely correct; exact and accurate
examples: She speaks perfect English.
a perfect copy/fit/match
What perfect timing!

sense.definition: the best of its kind
examples: a perfect example of the painter's early style
the perfect crime ( = one in which the criminal is never discovered)

sense.definition: excellent; very good
examples: The weather was perfect.
The rooms are excellent value at $20 a night.

You can all come? Excellent!
an outstanding achievement
She's an outstanding dancer.
Conditions were perfect for walking.
She came up with the perfect excuse.
The facilities at the hotel are superb.

sense.definition: exactly right for someone or something
examples: It was a perfect day for a picnic.
She's the perfect candidate for the job.
“Will 2:30 be OK for you?” “Yes, that will be perfect.”

sense.definition: total; complete
examples: I don't know him—he's a perfect stranger.

sense.definition: connected with the form of a verb that consists of part of the verb have with the past participle of the main verb, used to express actions completed by the present or a particular point in the past or future
examples: “I have eaten” is the present perfect tense of the verb “to eat,” “I had eaten” is the past perfect, and “I will have eaten” is the future perfect.

sense.definition: used to say that something is what you would like to happen or what should happen, but you know it cannot
examples: In an ideal world we would be recycling and reusing everything.

sense.definition: a way of encouraging people by telling them that if you do an activity regularly and try to improve your skill, you will become very good at it
a way of encouraging people by telling them that if you do an activity regularly and try to improve your skill, you will become very good at it
completely
examples: It's perfectly normal to feel like this.
It's perfectly good as it is ( = it doesn't need changing).
You know perfectly well what I mean.

He stood perfectly still until the danger had passed.
“Do you understand?” “Perfectly.”
How perfectly awful!
They're perfectly within their rights to ask to see the report.

sense.definition: in a perfect way
examples: The TV works perfectly now.
It fits perfectly.

sense.definition: to do something, such as a piece of work, task, or duty
examples: to perform an experiment/a miracle/a ceremony

This operation has never been performed in this country.
A computer can perform many tasks at once.

sense.definition: to entertain an audience by playing a piece of music, acting in a play, etc.
examples: to perform somersaults/magic tricks

to perform on the flute
I'm looking forward to seeing you perform.

sense.definition: to work or function well or badly
examples: The engine seems to be performing well.

If he performs ( = performs well) then I believe the Cubs can win.

sense.definition: to achieve very good results
examples: Her exercise program has worked miracles for her.

sense.definition: the act of performing a play, concert, or some other form of entertainment
examples: The performance starts at seven.
an evening performance
a performance of Ravel's String Quartet
Please refrain from talking during the performance.
a series of performances by the Kirov Ballet
one of the band's rare live performances

sense.definition: the way a person performs in a play, concert, etc.
examples: She gave the greatest performance of her career.
an Oscar-winning performance from Al Pacino

sense.definition: how well or badly you do something; how well or badly something works
examples: the country's economic performance

high-performance ( = very powerful) cars
performance indicators ( = things that show how well or badly something is working)

sense.definition: the act or process of performing a task, an action, etc.
examples: She has shown enthusiasm in the performance of her duties.

sense.definition: a display of exaggerated behavior or a process involving a great deal of unnecessary time and effort
examples: He stopped to tie his shoe and seemed to be making quite a performance of it.

sense.definition: a person who performs for an audience in a show, concert, etc.
examples: a brilliant/polished/seasoned performer

sense.definition: a person or thing that behaves or works in the way mentioned
examples: He was a poor performer at school and left without graduating.
The new model is the star performer of the motor industry this year.

sense.definition: possibly
examples: “Are you going to come?” “Perhaps. I'll see how I feel.”
Perhaps he's forgotten.

sense.definition: used when you want to make a statement or an opinion less definite
examples: This is perhaps his best novel to date.

sense.definition: used when making a rough estimate
examples: a change that could affect perhaps 20% of the population

sense.definition: used when you agree or accept something unwillingly, or do not want to say strongly that you disapprove
examples: “You could do it yourself.” “Yeah, perhaps.”

sense.definition: used when making a polite request, offer, or suggestion
examples: Perhaps it would be better if you came back tomorrow.
I think perhaps you've had enough to drink tonight.
Perhaps you'd like to have a shower before the others arrive.
Perhaps you would be good enough to let him know we are on our way.

sense.definition: a particular length of time
examples: a period of consultation/mourning/uncertainty

This compares with a 4% increase for the same period last year.

The aim is to reduce traffic at peak periods.
You can have it for a trial period ( = in order to test it).
The project will run for a six-month trial period.
Tomorrow will be cold with sunny periods.

sense.definition: a length of time in the life of a particular person or in the history of a particular country
examples: What period of history would you most like to have lived in?
the post-war period
The church dates from the Norman period.
Like Picasso, she too had a blue period.
Most teenagers go through a period of rebelling.

sense.definition: a length of time that is a division of an era. A period is divided into epochs
examples: the Jurassic period

sense.definition: any of the parts that a day is divided into at a school, college, etc. for study
examples: “What do you have next period?” “French.”
a free/study period ( = for private study)

sense.definition: the flow of blood each month from the body of a woman who is not pregnant
examples: period pains
monthly periods
When did you last have a period?

sense.definition: the mark ( . ) used at the end of a sentence and in some abbreviations, for example e.g.
lasting for a long time or for all time in the future; existing all the time
examples: a permanent job
permanent staff
They are now living together on a permanent basis.
The accident has not done any permanent damage.
a permanent fixture ( = a person or an object that is always in a particular place)

The stroke left his right side permanently damaged.

This door is kept permanently locked.

sense.definition: the act of allowing someone to do something, especially when this is done by someone in a position of authority
examples: You must ask permission for all major expenditures.
The school has been refused permission to expand.
No official permission has been given for the event to take place.
She took the car without permission.
poems reprinted by kind permission of the author

sense.definition: an official written statement allowing someone to do something
examples: The publisher is responsible for obtaining the necessary permissions to reproduce illustrations.

sense.definition: to allow someone to do something or to allow something to happen
examples: Cell phones are not permitted in the library.
There are fines for exceeding permitted levels of noise pollution.
We were not permitted any contact with each other.
Jim permitted himself a wry smile.
Visitors are not permitted to take photographs.
She would not permit herself to look at them.
