sense.definition: to make something possible
examples: We hope to visit the cathedral, if time permits.
I'll come tomorrow, weather permitting ( = if the weather is fine).
The password permits access to all files on the network.
The length of the report does not permit a detailed discussion of the problems.
ATMs permit you to withdraw money at any time.

sense.definition: a human as an individual
examples: What sort of person would do a thing like that?
He's a fascinating person.
What is she like as a person?
He's just the person we need for the job.
I had a letter from the people who used to live next door.
I'm not really a city person ( = I don't really like cities).

sense.definition: a human, especially one who is not identified
examples: A certain person ( = somebody that I do not wish to name) told me about it.
The price is $40 per person.
This vehicle is licensed to carry 4 persons. ( = on a notice)
The verdict was murder by a person or persons unknown.

sense.definition: a person working in the area of business mentioned; a person concerned with the thing mentioned
examples: a salesperson
a spokesperson

sense.definition: any of the three classes of personal pronouns. The first person (I/we) refers to the person(s) speaking; the second person (you) refers to the person(s) spoken to; the third person (he/she/it/they) refers to the person(s) or thing(s) spoken about.
if you have or carry something about/on your person, you carry it about with you, for example in your pocket
examples: Relatives of the dead man were traced through an address found on his person.

sense.definition: to treat everyone in the same way, without being influenced by their importance, wealth, etc.
examples: Death is no respecter of persons.

sense.definition: if you do something in person, you go somewhere and do it yourself, instead of doing it by mail, asking someone else to do it, etc.
examples: He had to pick up his welfare check in person.

sense.definition: in the form or shape of someone
examples: Help arrived in the person of his mother.
The firm has an important asset in the person of the sales director.

sense.definition: your own; not belonging to or connected with anyone else
examples: personal effects/belongings/possessions
personal details ( = your name, age, etc.)
Of course, this is just a personal opinion.
The novel is written from personal experience.
Use stencils to add a few personal touches to walls and furniture.
All rental cars are for personal use only.

sense.definition: connected with individual people, especially their feelings, characters, and relationships
examples: Having good personal relationships is the most important thing for me.
He was popular as much for his personal qualities as for his management skills.

sense.definition: not connected with a person's job or official position
examples: The letter was marked “Personal.”
I'd like to talk to you about a personal matter.
I try not to let work interfere with my personal life.
She's a personal friend of mine ( = not just somebody I know because of my job).

sense.definition: done by a particular person rather than by someone who is acting for them
examples: The President made a personal appearance at the event.
I shall give the matter my personal attention.
She takes a personal interest in the work of the charity.
The Principal has little personal contact with the students.

sense.definition: made or done for a particular person rather than for a large group of people or people in general
examples: We offer a personal service to all our customers.
a personal pension plan ( = a pension offered by a private company to one particular person)
Will you do it for me as a personal favor?

sense.definition: referring to a particular person's character, appearance, opinions, etc. in a way that is offensive
examples: Try to avoid making personal remarks.
There's no need to get personal!
Nothing personal ( = I do not wish to offend you), but I do have to go now.

sense.definition: connected with a person's body
examples: personal cleanliness/hygiene
She's always worrying about her personal appearance.
This insurance policy covers you against personal injury or death.

sense.definition: the various aspects of a person's character that combine to make them different from other people
examples: His wife has a strong personality.
The children all have very different personalities.
He maintained order by sheer force of personality.
There are likely to be tensions and personality clashes in any social group.
People's clothes are often an expression of their personality.

sense.definition: the qualities of a person's character that make them interesting and attractive
examples: We need someone with lots of personality to head the project.
She was very beautiful but seemed to lack personality.

sense.definition: a famous person, especially one who works in entertainment or sports
examples: personalities from the world of music
a TV/sports personality

sense.definition: a person whose strong character makes them noticeable
examples: Their son is a real personality.

sense.definition: the qualities of a place or thing that make it interesting and different
examples: The problem with many modern buildings is that they lack personality.

sense.definition: used to show that you are giving your own opinion about something
examples: Personally, I prefer the second option.
“Is it worth the effort?” “Personally speaking, yes.”

sense.definition: by a particular person rather than by someone acting for them
examples: All letters will be answered personally.
Do you know him personally ( = have you met him, rather than just knowing about him from other people)?
I'll deal with the matter personally.
He's no longer personally involved in the day-to-day running of the company.

sense.definition: in a way that is connected with one particular person rather than a group of people
examples: He was personally criticized by inspectors for his incompetence.
You will be held personally responsible for any loss or breakage.

sense.definition: in a way that is intended to be offensive
examples: I'm sure she didn't mean it personally.

sense.definition: in a way that is connected with someone's personal life rather than with their job or official position
examples: Have you had any contact with any of the suspects, either personally or professionally?

sense.definition: to be offended by something
examples: I'm afraid he took your remarks personally.
Please don't take this personally, but would you mind leaving us alone for a few moments?

sense.definition: a particular attitude toward something; a way of thinking about something

sense.definition: a very fine, soft, dry substance that you can put on your face to make it look smooth and dry

sense.definition: strength or influence in a particular area of activity

sense.definition: the influence of a particular thing or group within society

sense.definition: the strength or energy contained in something

sense.definition: physical strength used in action; physical strength that someone possesses and might use

sense.definition: the people who control an organization, a country, etc.

sense.definition: to express or state something in a particular way

sense.definition: to persuade someone to believe something that is not true

sense.definition: used when comparing or contrasting someone or something with a group of other people or things to mean “combined” or “in total”

sense.definition: used to tell someone to stop just talking about something and actually do it, show it, etc.

sense.definition: if a group of people close ranks, they work closely together to defend themselves, especially when they are being criticized

sense.definition: if soldiers close ranks, they move closer together in order to defend themselves
to make use of your place or status in society or at work to make someone do what you want
happening in a short period of time

sense.definition: not done, seen, happening, etc. very often

sense.definition: existing only in small numbers and therefore valuable or interesting

sense.definition: cooked for only a short time so that the inside is still red

sense.definition: a measurement of the speed at which something happens

sense.definition: a fixed amount of money that is charged or paid for something

sense.definition: used to say that a particular fact is true despite what has happened in the past or what may happen in the future

sense.definition: used to show that what you have just said is not as important as what you are going to say

sense.definition: used to say what will happen if a particular situation continues to develop in the same way

sense.definition: the usual amount of money paid for goods or services at a particular time

sense.definition: used to mean “fairly” or “to some degree,” often when you are expressing slight criticism, disappointment, or surprise

sense.definition: used to correct something you have said, or to give more accurate information

Some poems are mnemonics;that is to say, they are designed to help you remember something.

sense.definition: used to introduce an idea that is different or opposite to the idea that you have stated previously

sense.definition: in its natural state; not yet changed, used, or made into something else

sense.definition: not yet organized into a form in which it can be easily used or understood

sense.definition: powerful and natural; not controlled or trained

sense.definition: very cold

sense.definition: honest, direct, and sometimes shocking

sense.definition: the fact of someone being treated unfairly

sense.definition: again
examples: reapply

sense.definition: to arrive at the place that you have been traveling to

sense.definition: to come to someone's attention

sense.definition: to be able to stretch your hand far enough in order to touch something, pick something up, etc.

sense.definition: to be big enough, long enough, etc. to arrive at a particular point

sense.definition: to be seen or heard by someone

sense.definition: someone hears about something, especially when other people already know about it

sense.definition: to try to be successful at something that is difficult
to change or behave in a particular way as a result of or in response to something

sense.definition: to become ill after eating, breathing, etc. a particular substance

sense.definition: to experience a chemical change when coming into contact with another substance

sense.definition: what you do, say, or think as a result of something that has happened

sense.definition: a change in people's attitudes or behavior caused by disapproval of the attitudes, etc. of the past

sense.definition: a response by the body, usually a bad one, to a drug, chemical substance, etc.

sense.definition: the ability to move, or do something, quickly in response to something, especially if in danger

sense.definition: opposition to social or political progress or change

sense.definition: a chemical change produced by two or more substances acting on each other

sense.definition: a force shown by something in response to another force, which is of equal strength and acts in the opposite direction

sense.definition: to guess what someone else is thinking

sense.definition: to have something written on it; to be written in a particular way

Eating habits formed in childhood tend to continue into adult life, hence the importance of encouraging healthy eating from an early age.

It was a relief to be able to talk to someone about it.
What a relief!

sense.definition: the act of removing or reducing pain, anxiety, etc.
examples: modern methods of pain relief
the relief of suffering
Massage can bring some relief from tension.
Volunteers provide regular help to give relief to caregivers.

sense.definition: food, money, medicine, etc. that is given to help people in places where there has been a war or natural disaster
examples: famine/disaster relief
a relief agency/organization/worker

sense.definition: financial help given by the government to people who need it

examples: relief on mortgage interest payments

sense.definition: something that is interesting or enjoyable that replaces something boring, difficult, or unpleasant for a short period of time
examples: a few moments of light relief in an otherwise dull performance
There was little comic relief in his speech.
The calm of the countryside came as a welcome relief from the hustle and bustle of city life.

sense.definition: a person or group of people that replaces another when they have finished working for the day or when they are sick
examples: The next crew relief comes on duty at 9 o'clock.
relief drivers

sense.definition: the act of freeing a town, etc. from an enemy army that has surrounded it
examples: the relief of Mafeking

sense.definition: a way of decorating wood, stone, etc. by cutting designs into the surface of it so that some parts stick out more than others; a design that is made in this way
examples: The column was decorated in high relief ( = with designs that stick out a lot) with scenes from Greek mythology.
The bronze doors are covered with sculpted reliefs.

sense.definition: the effect of colors, light, etc. that makes an object more noticeable than others around it
examples: The snow-capped mountain stood out in sharp relief against the blue sky.

sense.definition: the quality of a particular situation, problem, etc. that makes it more noticeable than before
examples: Their differences have been thrown into sharp relief by the present crisis.

sense.definition: the belief in the existence of a god or gods, and the activities that are connected with the worship of them
examples: Is there always a conflict between science and religion?

sense.definition: one of the systems of faith that are based on the belief in the existence of a particular god or gods
examples: the Jewish religion
Christianity, Islam, and other world religions
The law states that everyone has the right to practice their own religion.

sense.definition: a particular interest or influence that is very important in your life
examples: For him, football is an absolute religion.

sense.definition: to suddenly become interested in religion
connected with religion or with a particular religion
examples: religious beliefs/faith
religious education ( = education about religion)
religious instruction ( = instruction in a particular religion)
religious groups
objects that have a religious significance
a religious house ( = a monastery or convent )

sense.definition: believing strongly in the existence of a god or gods
examples: His wife is very religious.

sense.definition: to continue to be something; to be still in the same state or condition
examples: to remain silent/standing/seated/motionless
Train fares are likely to remain unchanged.
It remains true that sports are about competing well, not winning.
Despite threats of strike action, the management remains hopeful that an agreement can be reached.
In spite of their quarrel, they remain the best of friends.
He will remain (as) manager of the club until the end of his contract.

sense.definition: to still be present after the other parts have been removed, used, etc.; to continue to exist
examples: Very little of the house remained after the fire.
Only about half of the original workforce remains.
There were only ten minutes remaining.

sense.definition: to still need to be done, said, or dealt with
examples: Much remains to be done.
It remains to be seen ( = it will only be known later) whether you are right.
There remained one significant problem.
Questions remain about the President's honesty.
I feel sorry for her, but the fact remains (that) she lied to us.
While the movie is undoubtedly too long, it is nevertheless an intriguing work of art.
It can be argued that the movie is too long. It is nonetheless an intriguing work of art.
The movie is undoubtedly too long. Still, it is an intriguing work of art.
Of course, huge chunks of the book have been sacrificed in order to make a two-hour movie, but it is nevertheless a successful piece of storytelling.
Critics are wrong to argue that the movie's plot is too complicated. Certainly there are a couple of major twists, but audiences will have no difficulty following them.
It is true that you cannot make a good movie without a good script, but it is equally true that a talented director can make a good script into an excellent movie.
It remains to be seen whether these two movies herald a new era of westerns, but there is no doubt that they represent welcome additions to the genre.

sense.definition: to stay in the same place; to not leave
examples: They remained in Mexico until June.
The plane remained on the ground.
She left, but I remained behind.

sense.definition: to not become involved in something; to show no interest in people
examples: The Emperor kept himself aloof from the people.

sense.definition: still needing to be done or dealt with
examples: The remaining twenty patients were transferred to another hospital.
Any remaining tickets for the concert will be sold on the door.

sense.definition: the parts of something that are left after the other parts have been used, eaten, removed, etc.
examples: She fed the remains of her lunch to the dog.

sense.definition: the parts of ancient objects and buildings that have survived and are discovered in the present day
examples: prehistoric remains
the remains of a Roman fort

sense.definition: the body of a dead person or animal
examples: They had discovered human remains.

sense.definition: something that you say or write which expresses an opinion, a thought, etc. about someone or something
examples: to make a remark
He made a number of rude remarks about the food.
What exactly did you mean by that last remark?
a casual remark that led to a major discovery

sense.definition: the quality of being important or interesting enough to be noticed
examples: The exhibition contains nothing that is worthy of remark.

sense.definition: unusual or surprising in a way that causes people to take notice
examples: a remarkable achievement/career/talent

What is even more remarkable about the whole thing is…
The area is remarkable for its scenery.
It is remarkable that nobody noticed sooner.
The car is in remarkably good condition for its age.

The two reports are remarkably similar.

sense.definition: to have or keep an image in your memory of an event, a person, a place, etc. from the past
examples: This is Carla. Do you remember her?
I don't remember my first day at school.

As far as I can remember, this is the third time we've met.
Do you remember turning the lights off before we came out?
I vaguely remember hearing him come in.
I can still vividly remember my grandfather teaching me to play cards.
I can't remember his taking a single day off work.
I remember (that) we used to go and see them most weekends.

sense.definition: to bring back to your mind a fact, piece of information, etc. that you knew
examples: I'm sorry—I can't remember your name.
You were going to help me with this. Remember?
Can you remember how much money we spent?
Remember that we're going out tonight.

sense.definition: to keep an important fact in your mind
examples: Remember (that) you may feel sleepy after taking the pills.
It should be remembered that the majority of accidents happen in the home.

sense.definition: to not forget to do something; to actually do what you have to do
examples: Remember to call me when you arrive!
Did you remember your homework ( = to bring it)?
I remember mailing the letter
I remembered to mail the letter

sense.definition: to think about someone with respect, especially when saying a prayer
examples: a church service to remember the war dead

sense.definition: to give money, a present, etc. to someone or something
examples: My aunt always remembers my birthday ( = by sending a card or present).

sense.definition: to be famous or known for a particular thing that you have done in the past
examples: He is best remembered as the man who brought jazz to England.

sense.definition: to help someone remember something, especially something important that they must do
examples: I'm sorry, I've forgotten your name. Can you remind me?
That ( = what you have just said, done, etc.) reminds me, I must get some cash.
“You need to finish that essay.” “Don't remind me ( = I don't want to think about it).”
“Don't forget the camera.” “Remind me about it nearer the time.”
Remind me to phone Alan before I go out.
Passengers are reminded (that) no smoking is allowed on this train.
Can someone remind me what I should do next?
“You had an accident,” he reminded her.

sense.definition: far away from places where other people live
examples: a remote beach
one of the remotest areas of the world

sense.definition: far away in time
examples: in the remote past/future
a remote ancestor ( = who lived a long time ago)

sense.definition: not closely related
examples: a remote cousin

sense.definition: that you can connect to from far away, using an electronic link
examples: a remote terminal/database

sense.definition: very different from something
examples: His theories are somewhat remote from reality.
A novel should not be too remote from the experiences of its readers.

sense.definition: not very friendly or interested in other people
not very great
examples: There is still a remote chance that they will find her alive.
I don't have the remotest idea what you're talking about.
the geographical remoteness of the island

sense.definition: the act of taking someone or something away from a particular place
examples: Clearance of the site required the removal of a number of trees.
the removal of a tumor

sense.definition: the act of getting rid of something
examples: stain removal
the removal of trade barriers

sense.definition: the act of dismissing someone from their job
examples: events leading to the removal of the president from office

sense.definition: to take something or someone away from a place
examples: Illegally parked vehicles will be removed.

Three children were removed from the school for persistent bad behavior.
Remove the pan from the heat and continue to stir the sauce.

sense.definition: to take off clothing, etc. from the body
examples: She removed her glasses and rubbed her eyes.

sense.definition: to get rid of something unpleasant, dirty, etc.; to make something disappear
examples: She has had the tumor removed.
to remove problems/obstacles/objections
The news removed any doubts about the company's future from my mind.
It was impossible to remove the stain from the tablecloth.

sense.definition: to dismiss someone from their position or job
examples: The elections removed the government from power.

sense.definition: to be very different from something; to not be connected with something
examples: Many of these books are far removed from the reality of the children's lives.

sense.definition: belonging to a different generation
examples: He's my cousin's son so he's my first cousin once removed.

sense.definition: an amount of money that you regularly pay so that you can use a house, etc.
examples: How much rent do you pay for this place?

a month's rent in advance
a high/low/fair rent
a low hourly rate
interest rates
an admission charge
a rental charge
legal fees
an annual membership fee
a parking fine

sense.definition: a torn place in a piece of material or clothing
available to rent
to restore something that is broken, damaged, or torn to good condition
examples: to repair a car/roof/road/television

The human body has an amazing capacity to repair itself.

sense.definition: to say or do something in order to improve a bad or unpleasant situation
examples: It was too late to repair the damage done to their relationship.

He was the son of a watch repairer.

sense.definition: to say or write something again or more than once
examples: to repeat a question

sense.definition: to do or produce something again or more than once
examples: to repeat a mistake/a process/an exercise

sense.definition: to happen more than once in the same way
examples: History has a strange way of repeating itself.

sense.definition: to tell someone something that you have heard or been told by someone else
examples: I don't want you to repeat a word of this to anyone.

sense.definition: to say something that someone else has said, especially in order to learn it
examples: Listen and repeat each sentence after me.

sense.definition: used to emphasize something that you have already said
examples: The claims are, I repeat, totally unfounded.

sense.definition: happening, said, or done many times

sense.definition: to be used instead of something or someone else; to do something instead of someone or something else

sense.definition: to remove someone or something and put another person or thing in their place

sense.definition: to change something that is old, damaged, etc. for a similar thing that is newer or better
examples: All the old carpets need replacing.

sense.definition: to put something back in the place where it was before
examples: I replaced the cup carefully in the saucer.

sense.definition: to say or write something as an answer to someone or something
examples: to reply to a question/an advertisement

“I won't let you down,” he replied confidently.
The senator replied that he was not in a position to comment.
I’m writing to answer your questions
I’m writing to reply to your questions.
I haven't answered her e-mail yet.
I knocked on the door but no one answered.
“I won’t let you down,” he replied.
The directors refused to respond to questions.

sense.definition: to do something as a reaction to something that someone has said or done

sense.definition: to give people information about something that you have heard, seen, done, etc.

sense.definition: to present a written or spoken account of an event in a newspaper, on television, etc.

sense.definition: a person who collects and reports news for newspapers, radio, or television

sense.definition: to act or speak officially for someone and defend their interests

sense.definition: to be an example or expression of something

sense.definition: to be a symbol of something

sense.definition: to show someone or something, especially in a picture

sense.definition: to make a formal statement to someone in authority in order to make your opinions known or to protest

sense.definition: a person who has been chosen to speak or vote for someone else or on behalf of a group
examples: a representative of the U.N.
our elected representatives in government
a union representative

sense.definition: a person who works for a company and travels around selling its products
examples: a sales representative

sense.definition: a person chosen to take the place of someone else
examples: He was the principal's representative at the ceremony.

sense.definition: a person who is typical of a particular group
examples: The singer is regarded as a representative of the youth of her generation.

sense.definition: (in the U.S.) a member of the House of Representatives, the lower house of Congress; a member of the House of Representatives in the lower house of a state legislature

sense.definition: to produce something again; to make something happen again in the same way
examples: The atmosphere of the novel is successfully reproduced in the movie.

sense.definition: if people, plants, animals, etc. reproduce or reproduce themselves, they produce young
examples: Most reptiles reproduce by laying eggs on land.
cells reproducing themselves ( = making new ones)

sense.definition: the opinion that people have about what someone or something is like, based on what has happened in the past

sense.definition: the action of asking for something formally and politely

sense.definition: a thing that you formally ask for

a radio request program ( = a program of music, songs, etc. that people have asked for)

sense.definition: to make someone do or have something, especially because it is necessary according to a particular law or set of rules
examples: The wearing of seat belts is required by law.

She insisted that I go with her.

You're asking too much of him.
All candidates will be required to take a short test.

sense.definition: something that you need or want
examples: the basic requirements of life
a software package to meet your requirements

sense.definition: something that you must have in order to do something else
examples: to meet/fulfill/satisfy the requirements

sense.definition: to save someone or something from a dangerous or harmful situation

a research project/grant/student

sense.definition: an arrangement for a seat on a plane or train, a room in a hotel, etc. to be kept for you

sense.definition: a feeling of doubt about a plan or an idea

sense.definition: an area of land in the U.S. that is kept separate for Native Americans to live in
to ask for a seat, table, room, etc. to be available for you or someone else at a future time
examples: I'd like to reserve a table for three for eight o'clock.

sense.definition: to keep something for someone or something, so that it cannot be used by any other person or for any other reason

sense.definition: to have or keep a particular power

sense.definition: a person who lives in a particular place or who has their home there

sense.definition: a person who is staying in a hotel
examples: The hotel restaurant is open to nonresidents.

sense.definition: a doctor working in a hospital who is receiving special advanced training

sense.definition: to stop yourself from having something you like or doing something you very much want to do

sense.definition: the power not to be affected by something

sense.definition: a force that stops something from moving or makes it move more slowly

examples: resistance fighters

sense.definition: (to choose, etc.) the easiest way of doing something

examples: to resolve an issue/a dispute/a conflict/a crisis

sense.definition: to reach a decision by means of a formal vote

sense.definition: a place where a lot of people go on vacation

the resort town of Sea Island, Georgia

sense.definition: the act of using something, especially something bad or unpleasant, because nothing else is possible

sense.definition: the first or last course of action that you should or can take in a particular situation

sense.definition: a supply of something that a country, an organization, or a person has and can use, especially to increase their wealth

sense.definition: something that can be used to help achieve an aim, especially a book, equipment, etc. that provides information for teachers and students

a library resource center

sense.definition: personal qualities such as courage and imagination that help you deal with difficult situations

sense.definition: a feeling of admiration for someone or something because of their good qualities or achievements

sense.definition: polite behavior toward or care for someone or something that you think is important

sense.definition: in payment for something

sense.definition: used when you are going to disagree, usually quite strongly, with someone

sense.definition: concerning

sense.definition: to give a spoken or written answer to someone or something
examples: I asked him his name, but he didn't respond.

I’m writing to answer your questions

sense.definition: that prevents the waste of the thing mentioned or stops it from being necessary

sense.definition: to speak or tell someone something, using words

sense.definition: to repeat words, phrases, etc.

sense.definition: to admit that you have been defeated in a fight and want to give up

sense.definition: a set of words expressing a statement, a question, or an order, usually containing a subject and a verb. In written English sentences begin with a capital letter and end with a period (.), a question mark (?), or an exclamation point (!).

sense.definition: a small amount or number of something

sense.definition: working or performing well

sense.definition: more than usual or more than other things

This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making. / This diagram shows how paper is made.
First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips.
Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine.
Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed.
Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities. /…is bleached so that impurities can be removed.
The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt.
As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away. This causes the solid material to sink to the bottom, forming a layer of paper.
At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper. / …dry the paper at the same time.
The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls. /Finally, the paper is wound onto large rolls.

sense.definition: very exact and clearly defined

sense.definition: to make someone be afraid, etc.

sense.definition: to make use of an opportunity immediately

sense.definition: interesting and unusual enough to attract attention

sense.definition: to have an idea that something is probably true or likely to happen, especially something bad, but without having definite proof
examples: If you suspect a gas leak, do not strike a match or even turn on an electric light.
Suspecting nothing, he walked right into the trap.
I didn't want the neighbors to suspect anything.
As I had suspected all along, he was not a real policeman.
I began to suspect (that) they were trying to get rid of me.
I suspect (that) she might be lying.
It was suspected that the drugs had been brought into the country by boat.
She suspected him to be an impostor.

sense.definition: to be suspicious about something; to not trust something
examples: I suspected her motives in offering to help.

sense.definition: to have an idea that someone is guilty of something, without having definite proof
examples: He resigned after being suspected of theft.
I suspected her of damaging the equipment.
The drug is suspected of causing over 200 deaths.
Whom do the police suspect?
a suspected outbreak of smallpox
suspected tax evasion
suspected terrorists

sense.definition: that may be false and that cannot be relied on
examples: Some of the evidence they produced was highly suspect.

sense.definition: that you suspect to be dangerous or illegal
examples: a suspect package ( = one that may contain drugs, a bomb, etc.)
a controlled explosion of a suspect device ( = a bomb)

sense.definition: a feeling that someone has done something wrong, illegal, or dishonest, even though you have no proof
examples: They drove away slowly to avoid arousing suspicion.
He was arrested on suspicion of murder.
I have a sneaking suspicion that she's not telling the truth.
My suspicions were confirmed when the police raided the property.
She was reluctant to voice her suspicions.
His resignation seemed only to fuel suspicion.
It's time to confront him with our suspicions.

sense.definition: a feeling or belief that something is true, even though you have no proof
examples: I have a horrible suspicion that we got off at the wrong stop.

sense.definition: the feeling that you cannot trust someone or something
examples: Their offer was greeted with some suspicion.
Water from shallow wells should be regarded with suspicion, as it may be contaminated.

sense.definition: a small amount of something
examples: His mouth quivered in the suspicion of a smile.
Wasn't there even a suspicion of truth in what he said?

sense.definition: too good, honest, etc. to have done something wrong, illegal, or dishonest
examples: Nobody who was near the scene of the crime is above suspicion.

sense.definition: if the finger of suspicion points or is pointed at someone, they are suspected of having committed a crime, being responsible for something, etc.
suspected of doing something wrong, illegal, or dishonest
examples: The whole family is currently under suspicion of her murder.
A number of doctors came under suspicion of unethical behavior.

sense.definition: feeling that someone has done something wrong, illegal, or dishonest, without having any proof
examples: They became suspicious of his behavior and contacted the police.
a suspicious look
You have a very suspicious mind ( = you always think that people are behaving in an illegal or dishonest way).

sense.definition: making you feel that something is wrong, illegal, or dishonest
examples: Didn't you notice anything suspicious in his behavior?
She died under suspicious circumstances.
Police are not treating the fire as suspicious.
It might look suspicious if we arrived together.
It was all very suspicious.

sense.definition: not willing or able to trust someone or something
examples: I was suspicious of his motives.
Many were suspicious of reform.

sense.definition: to make food, drink, etc. go down your throat into your stomach
examples: Always chew food well before swallowing it.
I had a sore throat and it hurt to swallow.
The pills should be swallowed whole.

sense.definition: to move the muscles of your throat as if you were swallowing something, especially because you are nervous
examples: She swallowed hard and told him the bad news.

sense.definition: to take someone or something in or completely cover them, so that they cannot be seen or no longer exist separately
examples: I watched her walk down the road until she was swallowed by the darkness.
Large areas that were formerly rural have been swallowed up by towns.

sense.definition: to use up something completely, especially an amount of money
examples: Most of my salary gets swallowed (up) by the rent and bills.

sense.definition: to accept that something is true; to believe something
examples: I found her excuse very hard to swallow.
He told her a pack of lies, but she swallowed it whole.

sense.definition: to hide your feelings
examples: to swallow your doubts
You're going to have to swallow your pride and ask for your job back.

sense.definition: to accept insults, criticisms, etc. without complaining or protesting
examples: I was surprised that he just sat there and swallowed all their remarks.

sense.definition: a fact or an event that is unpleasant and difficult to accept
examples: The election defeat was a bitter pill for the party to swallow.

sense.definition: to use rude or offensive language, usually because you are angry
examples: She fell down and swore loudly.
I don't like to hear children swearing.
Why did you let him swear at you like that?

sense.definition: to make a serious promise to do something
examples: He swore revenge on the man who had killed his father.
I swear (that) I'll never leave you.
She made him swear not to tell anyone.

sense.definition: to promise that you are telling the truth
examples: She swore (that) she'd never seen him before.
I could have sworn ( = I am sure) I heard the phone ring.
I swear to God I had nothing to do with it.

sense.definition: to make a public or official promise, especially in court
examples: Witnesses were required to swear on the Bible.
Are you willing to stand up in court and swear that you don't recognize him?
Remember, you have sworn to tell the truth.
Barons had to swear an oath of allegiance to the king.

sense.definition: to make someone promise not to tell something to anyone
examples: Everyone was sworn to secrecy about what had happened.

sense.definition: drops of liquid that appear on the surface of your skin when you are hot, sick, or afraid
examples: beads of sweat
She wiped the sweat from her face.
By the end of the game, the sweat was pouring off him.
Their bodies were soaked in sweat.

sense.definition: the state of being covered with sweat
examples: I woke up in a sweat.
She completed the routine without even working up a sweat.
He breaks out in a sweat just at the thought of flying.
He started having night sweats.

sense.definition: hard work or effort
examples: She achieved success by the sweat of her brow ( = by working very hard).

sense.definition: a sweatsuit or sweatpants
examples: I hung around the house all day in my sweats.

sense.definition: to be/become anxious or frightened about something
very hard work; a lot of effort
examples: The only way to succeed is through old-fashioned blood, sweat and tears.

sense.definition: to use a lot of physical effort
examples: He hardly needed to break a sweat to reach the final.

sense.definition: used to tell someone that something is not difficult or a problem when they thank you or ask you to do something
examples: “Thanks for everything.” “Hey, no sweat!”

sense.definition: a piece of warm clothing made of wool or cotton for the upper part of the body. A sweater can have long or short sleeves and be pulled over your head or have buttons like a jacket.
to clean a room, surface, etc. using a broom ( = a type of brush on a long handle)
examples: to sweep the floor
Chimneys should be swept regularly.
The showroom had been emptied and swept clean.

sense.definition: to remove something from a surface using a brush, your hand, etc.
examples: She swept the crumbs into the wastebasket.
He swept the leaves up into a pile.
She swept the clothes onto the floor and invited him to sit down.

sense.definition: to move or push someone or something suddenly and with a lot of force
examples: The little boat was swept out to sea.
Their tent was swept away in the storm.
She let herself be swept along by the crowd.

sense.definition: to move suddenly and/or with force over an area or in a particular direction
examples: Rain swept in through the broken windows.
A fire swept through the store on Tuesday night.
Strong winds regularly sweep the islands.

sense.definition: to move quickly and/or smoothly, especially in a way that impresses or is intended to impress other people
examples: Without another word she swept out of the room.
He swept into the lead with an almost perfect performance.

sense.definition: to move something, especially your hand or arm, quickly and smoothly in a particular direction
examples: He rushed to greet her, sweeping his arms wide.

sense.definition: to suddenly affect someone strongly
examples: A wave of tiredness swept over her.
Memories came sweeping back.

sense.definition: to spread quickly
examples: Rumors of his resignation swept through the company.
the latest craze sweeping America

sense.definition: to move over an area, especially in order to look for something
examples: His eyes swept around the room.
The car headlights swept across the front of the building.
Searchlights swept the sky.
She swept the crowd with her binoculars.

sense.definition: to move, or move something, over a surface, touching it lightly
examples: Her dress swept the ground as she walked.

sense.definition: to brush, comb, etc. your hair in a particular direction
examples: Her hair was swept back from her face.

sense.definition: to form a long smooth curve
examples: The hotel lawn sweeps down to the beach.

sense.definition: to win all the games in a series of games against another team or all the parts of a contest
examples: The Blue Jays have a chance to sweep the series.
New Jersey swept Detroit last season.

sense.definition: to win all the prizes, etc. in a competition
to make someone fall suddenly and deeply in love with you
examples: She's waiting for some hero to come and sweep her off her feet.

sense.definition: to win an election by a large number of votes; to make someone win an election with a large number of votes
to win a contest easily
examples: The Democrats swept to victory in 2008.

sense.definition: to try to stop people from finding out about something wrong, illegal, embarrassing, etc. that has happened or that you have done
examples: An earlier report, implicating several top officials, was conveniently swept under the rug.

sense.definition: containing, or tasting as if it contains, a lot of sugar
examples: He likes his coffee sweet.
sweet food
I had a craving for something sweet.
sweet sherry
This apple pie is too sweet for me.

sense.definition: having a pleasant smell
examples: a sweet-smelling rose
The air was sweet with incense.

sense.definition: having a pleasant sound
examples: a sweet voice

sense.definition: pleasant and not containing any harmful substances
examples: the sweet air of a mountain village

sense.definition: making you feel happy and/or satisfied
examples: Goodnight. Sweet dreams.
I can't tell you how sweet this victory is.
He played a sweet shot onto the final green ( = in golf ).
an act of sweet revenge

sense.definition: having or showing a kind character
examples: She gave him her sweetest smile.
He's one of the sweetest people I know.
It was sweet of them to offer to help.
He's not what you'd call sweet-tempered!

sense.definition: attractive
examples: The kids look sweet in this photograph.

sense.definition: used to show that you approve of something
examples: Free tickets? Sweet!

sense.definition: to like someone very much in a romantic way
to like food that contains a lot of sugar
used to say how pleasant your home is (especially when you really mean that it is not pleasant at all)
how and when you want to, even though this might annoy other people
examples: He always does the work, but in his own sweet time.

sense.definition: pleasant but not lasting a long time
examples: We don't have much time so I'll keep it short and sweet.

sense.definition: romantic words
examples: to whisper sweet nothings in someone's ear

sense.definition: the pleasant feeling of being successful
to become bigger or rounder
examples: Her arm was beginning to swell up where the bee had stung her.
Bacteria can cause gums to swell and bleed.
Cook the lentils for 20 minutes until they swell and soften.

sense.definition: to curve out or make something curve out
examples: The sails swelled (out) in the wind.
The wind swelled (out) the sails.

sense.definition: to increase or make something increase in number or size
examples: Last year's profits were swelled by a fall in production costs.
Crowds of commuters were swelled by Christmas shoppers.
We are looking for more volunteers to swell the ranks ( = increase the number) of those already helping.
Membership has swelled to over 20,000.

sense.definition: to become louder
examples: The cheering swelled through the arena.

sense.definition: to be filled with a strong emotion
examples: to swell with pride
Her heart swelled as she turned to face him.

sense.definition: the condition of being larger or rounder than normal ( = of being swollen )
examples: Use ice to reduce the swelling.

sense.definition: a place on your body that has become larger or rounder than normal as the result of an illness or injury
examples: The fall left her with a painful swelling above her eye.

sense.definition: to move through water in a horizontal position using the arms and legs
examples: I can't swim.
The boys swam across the lake.
We swam out ( = away from land) to the yacht.
They spent the day swimming and sunbathing.
Can you swim the backstroke yet?
How long will it take her to swim the length of the lake?
Have you bathed the baby yet?
Bathe the wound and apply a clean dressing.
Let’s go for a quick swim in the pool.
She goes swimming every morning before breakfast.

sense.definition: to spend time swimming for pleasure
examples: I go swimming twice a week.

sense.definition: to move through or across water
examples: A shoal of fish swam past.
Ducks were swimming around on the river.

sense.definition: to be covered with a lot of liquid
examples: The main course was swimming in oil.
Her eyes were swimming with tears.

sense.definition: to seem to be moving around, especially when you are sick or drunk
examples: The pages swam before her eyes.

sense.definition: to feel confused and/or as if everything is spinning around
examples: His head swam and he swayed dizzily.

sense.definition: to be in a situation where you will either succeed by your own efforts or fail completely
examples: The new students were just left to sink or swim.

sense.definition: the sport or activity of swimming
examples: Swimming is a good form of exercise.

sense.definition: an area of water that has been created for people to swim in
examples: an indoor/outdoor swimming pool
a heated swimming pool
an open-air swimming pool

sense.definition: the building that contains a public swimming pool
examples: She trained five times a week at her local swimming pool.

sense.definition: to move backward or forward or from side to side while hanging from a fixed point; to make something do this
examples: His arms swung as he walked.
As he pushed her, she swung higher and higher ( = while sitting on a swing).
A set of keys swung from her belt.
He sat on the stool, swinging his legs.

sense.definition: to move from one place to another by holding something that is fixed and pulling yourself along, up, etc.
examples: The gunshot sent monkeys swinging away through the trees.
He swung himself out of the car.

sense.definition: to move or make something move with a wide, curved movement
examples: A line of cars swung out of the White House driveway.
He swung his legs over the side of the bed.
The door swung open.
She swung the door open.

sense.definition: to turn or change direction suddenly; to make something do this
examples: She swung back to face him.
The bus swung sharply to the left.
He swung the camera around to face the opposite direction.

sense.definition: to try to hit someone or something
examples: She swung at me with the iron bar.
He swung another punch in my direction.

sense.definition: to change or make someone or something change from one opinion, mood, etc. to another
examples: The state swung from Republican to Democrat in the last election.
His emotions swung between fear and curiosity.
The game could swing either way ( = either side could win it).
I managed to swing them around to my point of view.

sense.definition: to succeed in getting or achieving something, sometimes in a slightly dishonest way
examples: We're trying to swing it so that we can travel on the same flight.

sense.definition: to have a strong rhythm
if a party, etc. is swinging, there are a lot of people there having a good time
to become more intense
examples: The campaign season for this year’s elections doesn’t really kick into high gear until June.

sense.definition: when someone says there's no room to swing a cat, they mean that a room is very small and that there is not enough space
to really try to achieve something great, even when it is not reasonable to expect to be so successful
examples: entrepreneurs who think big and swing for the fences
Investors need to manage risk and not swing for the fences.

sense.definition: to start doing something quickly and with a lot of energy
examples: The ambulance crew swung into action to resuscitate the patient.
The rescue operation swung into action immediately.

sense.definition: a small device that you press or move up and down in order to turn a light or piece of electrical equipment on and off
examples: a light switch
an on-off switch
That was in the days before electricity was available at the flick of a switch.
Which switch do I press to turn it off?
to throw a switch ( = to move a large switch)

sense.definition: a change from one thing to another, especially when this is sudden and complete
examples: a switch of priorities
She made the switch from full-time to part-time work when her first child was born.
a policy switch

sense.definition: the piece of track at a place where a railroad line divides that can be moved to allow a train to change tracks
a thin stick that bends easily
examples: a riding switch

sense.definition: larger than normal, especially as a result of a disease or an injury
examples: swollen glands
Her eyes were red and swollen from crying.

sense.definition: containing more water than normal
a person, an object, an event, etc. that represents a more general quality or situation
examples: White has always been a symbol of purity in Western cultures.
Nelson Mandela became a symbol of the anti-apartheid struggle.
Headaches may be a sign of stress.
They gave no indication as to how the work should be done.
A sore throat may be a symptom of an ear infection.
The rise in inflation was just one symptom of the poor state of the economy.
The dove is a universal symbol of peace.
the economic indicators
Healthy skin is an indicator of overall well-being.
This latest decision is a signal of a major change in policy.
Reducing prison sentences would send the wrong signals to criminals.

sense.definition: a sign, number, letter, etc. that has a fixed meaning, especially in science, mathematics, and music
examples: What is the chemical symbol for copper?
A list of symbols used on the map is given in the index.

sense.definition: kind to someone who is hurt or sad; showing that you understand and care about their problems
examples: a sympathetic listener
I did not feel at all sympathetic toward Kate.
I'm here if you need a sympathetic ear ( = someone to talk to about your problems).
a sympathetic response
She was very sympathetic when I was sick.

sense.definition: showing that you approve of someone or something or that you share their views and are willing to support them
examples: to be sympathetic to youthful rebellion
Russian newspapers are largely sympathetic to the president.

sense.definition: easy to like
examples: a sympathetic character in a novel
I don't find her a very sympathetic person.
to smile at someone sympathetically
The teacher listened sympathetically to the student's problems.

sense.definition: the feeling of being sorry for someone; showing that you understand and care about someone's problems
examples: to express/feel sympathy for someone
I have no sympathy for Jen; it's all her own fault.
I wish he'd show me a little more sympathy.
Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to the victims of the war.
May we offer our deepest sympathies on the death of your wife.

sense.definition: the act of showing support for or approval of an idea, a cause, an organization, etc.
examples: The seamen went on strike in sympathy with ( = to show their support for) the dockworkers.
Her sympathies lie with the anti-vivisection lobby.

sense.definition: friendship and understanding between people who have similar opinions or interests
examples: There was no personal sympathy between them.

sense.definition: happening because something else has happened
examples: Share prices slipped in sympathy with the discouraging economic news.

sense.definition: not agreeing with or not wanting to support someone or something
an organized set of ideas or theories or a particular way of doing something
examples: the American educational system
a new system for assessing property taxes
a system of government

sense.definition: a group of things, pieces of equipment, etc. that are connected or work together
examples: a transportation system
heating systems
a stereo system
a security system

sense.definition: a human or an animal body, or a part of it, when it is being thought of as the organs and processes that make it function
examples: You have to wait until the drugs have passed out of your system.
the male reproductive system

sense.definition: the rules or people that control a country or an organization, especially when they seem to be unfair because you cannot change them
examples: You can't beat the system ( = you must accept it).
young people rebelling against the system

sense.definition: to do something so that you no longer feel a very strong emotion or have a strong desire
examples: I was very angry with him, but I think I finally got it out of my system.

sense.definition: a piece of furniture that consists of a flat top supported by legs
examples: a kitchen table
A table for two, please ( = in a restaurant).
I'd like to reserve a table for tonight ( = in a restaurant).
to set the table ( = to put the plates, knives, etc. on it for a meal)
to clear the table ( = take away the dirty plates, etc. at the end of a meal)
He questioned her next morning over the breakfast table ( = during breakfast).
a pool/billiard table

sense.definition: the people sitting at a table for a meal or to play cards, etc.
examples: He kept the whole table entertained with his jokes.

sense.definition: a list of facts or numbers arranged in a special order, usually in rows and columns
examples: a table of contents ( = a list of the main points or information in a book, usually at the front of the book)
Table 2 shows how prices and earnings have increased over the past 20 years.

sense.definition: to contribute something useful to a discussion, project, etc.
examples: What our new chairman brings to the table is real commitment and energy.

sense.definition: to drink more alcohol than someone else without becoming as drunk as they are
offered to people so that they can consider or discuss it
examples: Management has put several new proposals on the table.

sense.definition: not going to be discussed or considered until a future date
examples: We're leaving Conner's suggestion on the table until next week.

sense.definition: to change a situation so that you are now in a stronger position than the person who used to be in a stronger position than you
to work serving food to people in a restaurant
a flat piece of stone, clay, etc. that has words written on it, especially one that has been fixed to a wall in memory of an important person or event
examples: ancient clay tablets with indecipherable writing

sense.definition: a small, round, solid piece of medicine that you swallow
examples: an aspirin tablet
Take two tablets with water before meals.

sense.definition: an amount of another substance in a small, round, solid piece
examples: water purification tablets

sense.definition: a number of pieces of paper for writing or drawing on, that are fastened together at one edge
to deal with someone who is violent or threatening you by grabbing them and gaining control over them
examples: He tackled a masked intruder at his home.

sense.definition: to make an opponent fall to the ground in order to stop them from running
to try and take the ball from an opponent
examples: He was tackled just outside the penalty area.

sense.definition: to make a determined effort to deal with a difficult problem or situation
examples: The administration is determined to tackle inflation.
I think I'll tackle the repairs next weekend.
Firefighters tackled a blaze in a garage last night.

sense.definition: to speak to someone about a problem or difficult situation
examples: I tackled him about the money he owed me.

sense.definition: the part that sticks out and can be moved at the back of the body of a bird, an animal, or a fish
examples: The dog ran up, wagging its tail.
The male has beautiful tail feathers.

sense.definition: having the type of tail mentioned
examples: a white-tailed eagle

sense.definition: the back part of a plane, spacecraft, etc.
examples: the tail wing

sense.definition: a part of something that sticks out at the back like a tail
examples: the tail of a kite

sense.definition: the last part of something that is moving away from you
examples: the tail of the procession
He was wearing a top hat and tails.

sense.definition: the side of a coin that does not have a picture of the head of a person on it, used as one choice when a coin is tossed to decide something
a person who is sent to follow someone secretly and find out information about where that person goes, what they do, etc.
examples: The police have put a tail on him.
Manx cats are tailless.

sense.definition: following behind someone very closely, especially in a car
examples: That white van has been on my tail for the past ten miles.

sense.definition: used to describe a situation in which the most important aspect is being influenced and controlled by someone or something that is not as important
to run away from a fight or dangerous situation
examples: When they heard the sirens, they turned tail and ran.

sense.definition: feeling ashamed or unhappy because you have been defeated or punished
to carry or move something from one place to another
examples: I forgot to take my bag with me when I got off the bus.
Take this to the bank for me, would you?
Should I take a gift to my host family?
Should I take my host family a gift?

sense.definition: to go with someone from one place to another, especially to guide or lead them
examples: It's too far to walk—I'll take you by car.
A boy took us to our room.
I'm taking the kids swimming later.
She took the boys to see their grandparents most weekends.

sense.definition: to make someone or something go from one level, situation, etc. to another
examples: Her energy and talent took her to the top of her profession.
The new loan takes the total debt to $100,000.
I'd like to take my argument a stage further.
He believes he has the skills to take the team forward.
We'll take this matter up again at our next meeting ( = discuss it further).

sense.definition: to put your hands or arms around someone or something and hold them/it; to reach for someone or something and hold them/it
examples: I passed him the rope and he took it.
Free newspapers; please take one.
Can you take ( = hold) the baby for a minute?
He took her hand/took her by the hand ( = held her hand, for example to lead her somewhere).
She took the child in her arms and kissed him.

sense.definition: to remove something or someone from a place or a person
examples: Will you take your books off the table?
The sign must be taken down.
He took some keys out of his pocket.
My name had been taken off the list.
She was playing with a knife, so I took it away from her.
The new gym will take the pressure off the old one.

sense.definition: to remove something without permission or by mistake
examples: Someone took my scarf.
Did the burglars take anything valuable?
The storms took the lives of 50 people.

sense.definition: to get something from a particular source
examples: The scientists are taking water samples from the river.
The machine takes its name from its inventor.
Part of her article is taken straight ( = copied) out of my book.

sense.definition: to capture a place or person; to get control of something
examples: The rebels succeeded in taking the town.
The government has taken control of the company.
The rebels took him prisoner.
He was taken prisoner by the rebels.

sense.definition: to choose, buy, or rent something
examples: I'll take the gray jacket.
We took a room at the hotel for two nights.

sense.definition: to buy a newspaper or magazine regularly
examples: We take the “Chicago Tribune.”

sense.definition: to eat, drink, etc. something
examples: Do you take sugar in your coffee?
The doctor gave me some medicine to take for my cough.
He started taking drugs ( = illegal drugs) in college.

sense.definition: to reduce one number by the value of another
examples: Take 5 from 12 and you're left with 7.
80 take away 5 is 75 .

sense.definition: to find out and record something; to write something down
examples: The police officer took my name and address.
Did you take notes in the class?

sense.definition: to photograph someone or something
examples: to take a photograph/picture/snapshot of someone or something
to have your picture/photo taken

sense.definition: to test or measure something
examples: to take someone's temperature
I need to have my blood pressure taken.

sense.definition: to sit down in or use a chair, etc.
examples: Are these seats taken?
Come in; take a seat.
May I sit here?
Sit still, will you!
We sat talking for hours.
Please sit down.
She was seated at the head of the table.
Please be seated.
Please have a seat.
She perched herself on the edge of the bed.

sense.definition: used to introduce someone or something as an example
examples: Lots of couples have problems in the first year of marriage. Take Ann and Paul.

sense.definition: to accept or receive something
examples: If they offer me the job, I'll take it.
She was accused of taking bribes.
Does the hotel take credit cards?
I'll take the call in my office.
Why should I take the blame for somebody else's mistakes?
If you take my advice you won't have anything more to do with him.
Will you take $10 for the book ( = will you sell it for $10)?
The store took in ( = sold goods worth) $100,000 last week.

sense.definition: to accept someone as a customer, patient, etc.
examples: The school doesn't take boys ( = only has girls).
The dentist can't take any new patients.

sense.definition: to experience or be affected by something
examples: The school took the full force of the explosion.
Can the ropes take the strain ( = not break)?
The team took a terrible beating.

sense.definition: to be able to bear something
examples: She can't take criticism.
I don't think I can take much more of this heat.
I find his attitude a little hard to take.

sense.definition: to react to something or someone in a particular way
examples: He took the criticism surprisingly well.
These threats are not to be taken lightly.
I wish you'd take me seriously.
She took it in the spirit in which it was intended.

sense.definition: to understand or consider something in a particular way
examples: She took what he said as a compliment.
How am I supposed to take that remark?
Taken overall, the project was a success.
What did you take his comments to mean?

sense.definition: to consider someone or something to be someone or something, especially when you are wrong
examples: Even the experts took the painting for a genuine Van Gogh.
Of course I didn't do it! What do you take me for ( = what sort of person do you think I am)?
I took the man with him to be his father.

sense.definition: to have a particular feeling, opinion, or attitude
examples: My parents always took an interest in my hobbies.
Don't take offense ( = be offended) at what I said.
I took a dislike to him.
He takes the view that children are responsible for their own actions.

sense.definition: to use a particular course of action in order to deal with or achieve something
examples: The school system is taking action to combat drug abuse.

This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making. / This diagram shows how paper is made.
First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips.
Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine.
Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed.
Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities. /…is bleached so that impurities can be removed.
The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt.
As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away. This causes the solid material to sink to the bottom, forming a layer of paper.
At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper. / …dry the paper at the same time.
The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls. /Finally, the paper is wound onto large rolls.

I don't want there to be any misunderstanding.
There seemed to be no doubt about it.
There comes a point where you give up.
There remains the problem of finance.

There are only four days left.
There once was a poor farmer who had four sons.

sense.definition: in, at, or to that place or position
examples: We went on to Paris and stayed there eleven days.
I hope we get there in time.
It's there, right in front of you!
There it is—just behind the chair.

There are a lot of people back there ( = behind) waiting to get in.
I'm not going in there—it's freezing!
We're almost there ( = we have almost arrived).
Can I get there and back in a day?
I left in 2008 and I haven't been back there since.
Hello, is Bob there please? ( = used when calling someone on the phone)

sense.definition: existing or available
examples: I went to see if my old school was still there.

sense.definition: at that point (in a story, an argument, etc.)

I don't agree with you there.

sense.definition: used to attract someone's attention

sense.definition: used to attract someone's attention to a particular person, thing, or fact
examples: There's the statue I was telling you about.
That woman there is the boss's wife.

There goes the phone ( = it's ringing).

So, there you have it: that's how it all started.

sense.definition: used to show the role of a person or thing in a situation
examples: The fact is, they're there to make money.

sense.definition: used to show that you think a place or an activity is not very interesting or impressive because you have already experienced it
examples: Not New York again! Been there, done that, got the T-shirt.

sense.definition: to be available if someone wants to talk to you or if they need help
examples: You know I'll always be there for you.

sense.definition: to know all about a situation because you have experienced it
in various places
examples: Papers were scattered here and there on the floor.

sense.definition: in many different places; all around
not important
examples: What might have happened is neither here nor there.

sense.definition: not very intelligent, especially because of mental illness
used to show that you are determined not to change your attitude or opinion
examples: Well, you can't have it, so there!

sense.definition: that is the situation
examples: It's crazy, I know, but there it is.

sense.definition: used to say that something is a very good example of something
examples: She visited him every day he was in the hospital. There's devotion for you.

sense.definition: used to praise or encourage small children or animals
examples: Finish your lunch, there's a good boy.

sense.definition: used to persuade a small child to stop crying or being upset
examples: There, there! Never mind, you'll soon feel better.

sense.definition: used when giving someone a thing they want or have asked for
examples: There you are—that'll be $3.80, please.

sense.definition: used when explaining or showing something to someone
examples: You switch on, push in the DVD, and there you are!
There you are! I told you it was easy!

sense.definition: used when you are talking about something that happens in a typical way or about a situation that cannot be changed
examples: There you go—that's what they're like.
I know it's not ideal but there you go…

sense.definition: used to criticize someone when they behave in a way that is typical of them
examples: There you go again—jumping to conclusions.

sense.definition: used to introduce the logical result of something that has just been mentioned
examples: He's only 17 and therefore not eligible to vote.

sense.definition: people, animals, or things that have already been mentioned or are easily identified
examples: “Where are John and Liz?” “They went for a walk.”
They ( = the things you are carrying) go on the bottom shelf.

sense.definition: used instead of he or she to refer to a person whose sex is not mentioned or not known
examples: If anyone arrives late they'll have to wait outside.

sense.definition: people in general
examples: The rest, as they say, is history.

sense.definition: people in authority or experts
examples: They cut my water off.
They now say that red wine is good for you.

sense.definition: having a larger distance between opposite sides or surfaces than other similar objects or than normal
examples: a thick slice of bread
a thick book ( = one that has a lot of pages)
a thick coat ( = one made of heavy cloth)
thick fingers

sense.definition: used to ask about or state the distance between opposite sides or surfaces
examples: How thick are the walls?
They're two feet thick.

sense.definition: growing closely together in large numbers
examples: thick dark hair
