His eyebrows were thick and bushy.
a thick forest

sense.definition: not flowing very easily
examples: thick soup
The effect will be ruined if the paint is too thick.

sense.definition: difficult to see through; difficult to breathe in
examples: The plane crashed in thick fog.
thick smoke
Thick clouds covered the sky.
The air was thick with dust.
The atmosphere was thick with tension.

sense.definition: having a large number of people or a large amount of something in one place
examples: The beach was thick with sunbathers.

sense.definition: easily recognized as being from a particular country or area
examples: a thick Brooklyn accent

sense.definition: deep and not as clear as normal, especially because of illness or emotion
examples: His voice was thick with emotion.

sense.definition: slow to learn or understand things
examples: He's too thick to realize what's going on.

sense.definition: very friendly with someone, especially in a way that makes other people suspicious
examples: You seem to be very thick with the boss!

sense.definition: family relationships are stronger than any others
very friendly, especially in a way that makes other people suspicious
used to show that you are annoyed that someone does not understand something
examples: When will you get it into your thick head that I don't want to see you again!

sense.definition: the ability to accept criticism, insults, etc. without becoming upset
in a way that produces a wide piece or deep layer of something
examples: thickly sliced bread
Apply the paint thickly in even strokes.

sense.definition: having a lot of trees, people, etc. close together
in a deep voice that is not as clear as normal, especially because of illness or emotion
examples: “Just leave me alone,” he said thickly.

sense.definition: the size of something between opposite surfaces or sides
examples: Use wood of at least 5 in. thickness.
Cook for about 10 minutes, depending on the thickness of the steaks.
Roll out the pastry to a thickness of a half inch.
The walls are at least two feet in thickness.
The board is available in four thicknesses.

sense.definition: a layer of something
examples: The jacket was lined with a double thickness ( = two layers) of fabric.

sense.definition: a person who steals something from another person or place
examples: a car/jewel, etc. thief

sense.definition: used to say that even criminals have standards of behavior that they respect
very friendly, especially in a way that makes other people suspicious
having a smaller distance between opposite sides or surfaces than other similar objects or than normal
examples: Cut the vegetables into thin strips.
A number of thin cracks appeared in the wall.
The body was hidden beneath a thin layer of soil.
a thin blouse ( = of light cloth)

sense.definition: not covered with much flesh
examples: He was tall and thin, with dark hair.
She was looking pale and thin.
He is as thin as a rail ( = very thin).
thin legs

sense.definition: not growing closely together or in large amounts
examples: thin gray hair

sense.definition: containing more liquid than is normal or expected
examples: The sauce was thin and tasteless.

sense.definition: fairly easy to see through
examples: They fought their way through where the smoke was thinner.

sense.definition: containing less oxygen than normal
examples: Humans would not be able to survive in the thin atmosphere of the planet.

sense.definition: high and weak
examples: Her thin voice trailed off into silence.

sense.definition: not sincere or enthusiastic
examples: He gave a thin smile.

sense.definition: not very bright
examples: the thin gray light of dawn

sense.definition: of poor quality; lacking an important quality
examples: a thin excuse ( = one that people are not likely to believe)
Their arguments all sound a little thin to me.
The general standard of applicants is pretty thin this year.

sense.definition: to be taking a risk
to disappear suddenly in a mysterious way
examples: She can't just have vanished into thin air.

sense.definition: from nowhere or nothing, as if by magic
examples: Unfortunately, I can't just conjure up the money out of thin air!

sense.definition: to try to do so many different things at the same time that you do not do any of them well
without much hair on the head
examples: He's starting to get a little thin on top ( = he's losing his hair).

sense.definition: the lack of ability to accept criticism, insults, etc. without becoming upset
examples: You shouldn't be in politics if you have such a thin skin.

sense.definition: even when there are problems or difficulties
examples: He's supported the team for over ten years through thick and thin.
In marriage, you have to stick together through thick and thin.

sense.definition: to be in a difficult or dangerous situation where you could easily make a mistake
examples: He was walking a fine line between being funny and being rude.

sense.definition: to begin to become weaker or less acceptable
examples: These excuses are wearing a little thin ( = because we've heard them so many times before).
My patience is beginning to wear very thin.

sense.definition: an object whose name you do not use because you do not need to or want to, or because you do not know it
examples: Can you pass me that thing over there?
She's very fond of sweet things ( = sweet foods).
He's just bought one of those exercise things.
Turn that thing off while I'm talking to you!

sense.definition: an object that is not alive in the way that people and plants are
examples: Don't treat her like that—she's a person, not a thing!
He's good at making things with his hands.
She took no interest in the people and things around her.

sense.definition: objects, clothing, or tools that belong to someone or are used for a particular purpose
examples: Can I help you pack your things?
This box is full of camping things.
I'll just clear away the breakfast things.
Put your things ( = coat, etc.) on and let's go.

sense.definition: used with negatives to mean “anything” in order to emphasize what you are saying
examples: I don't have a thing to wear!
She hasn't had a thing to eat all day.
There wasn't a thing we could do to help.
Ignore what he said—it doesn't mean a thing.

sense.definition: a fact, an event, a situation, or an action; what someone says or thinks
examples: There are a lot of things she doesn't know about me.
There's another thing I'd like to ask you.
A terrible thing happened last night.
He found the whole thing ( = the situation) very boring.
I have loads of things to do today.
The main thing to remember is to switch off the burglar alarm.
I like camping, climbing, and that sort of thing.
She said the first thing that came into her head.
“Why did you tell her our secret?” “I did no such thing!”
Let's forget the whole thing ( = everything).

sense.definition: the general situation, as it affects someone
examples: Things haven't gone entirely to plan.
Hi, Jane! How are things?
Think things over before you decide.
As things stand at present, he seems certain to win.
All things considered ( = considering all the difficulties or problems), she's done very well.
Why do you make things so difficult for yourself?
the current economic situation
The ship sank in mysterious circumstances.
She knew that she was in a position of power.
We were forced to work outside in freezing conditions.
Hi, Jane! How are things?
Think things over before you decide.
If that is the case ( = if the situation described is true), we need more staff.
Well, this is certainly a sorry state of affairs.

sense.definition: what is needed or socially acceptable
examples: You need something to cheer you up—I know just the thing!
to say the right/wrong thing
The best thing to do is to apologize.

sense.definition: all that can be described in a particular way
examples: She loves all things Japanese.

sense.definition: a living creature
examples: All living things are composed of cells.

sense.definition: used to talk to or about a person or an animal, to show how you feel about them
examples: You silly thing!
You must be starving, you poor things.
The cat's very ill, poor old thing.

sense.definition: if the conditions stay the same; if other conditions are the same
examples: All things being equal, we should finish the job tomorrow.

sense.definition: used when you do not want to complete a list
examples: She likes nice clothes and things like that.
I've been busy shopping and things.

sense.definition: as was shown or proved by later events
examples: I didn't need my umbrella, as it turned out ( = because it didn't rain).

sense.definition: to please everyone by changing your attitudes or opinions to suit different people
to be understood or used in different ways by different people
to be lucky that…
examples: It's a good thing we got here early.

sense.definition: used to say that although something seems to be bad, it could have good results
examples: We didn't want the press to get hold of the story, but it might be no bad thing.

sense.definition: to have found a job, situation, or style of life that is pleasant or easy
to imagine that you can see or hear something that is in fact not there
the best, fastest, etc. thing of its kind currently available
examples: It’s a little expensive, but this computer is the best thing going right now.

sense.definition: to have the same result or meaning
to do what people or society expect, especially in a difficult situation
examples: He did the decent thing and resigned.

sense.definition: to do what you want to do or what interests you, without thinking about other people; to be independent
to have a powerful emotional effect on someone
examples: That song just does things to me.

sense.definition: early in the morning/late in the evening
examples: I need the report on my desk first thing Monday morning.

sense.definition: the most important matters must be dealt with first
examples: We have a lot to discuss, but, first things first, let's have a cup of coffee!

sense.definition: used to introduce one of two or more reasons for doing something
examples: “Why don't you get a car?” “Well, for one thing, I can't drive!”

sense.definition: to have what you want, especially by opposing other people
to have a strong like or dislike of someone or something in a way that seems strange or unreasonable
examples: She has a thing about men with beards.

sense.definition: in the way that things usually happen
examples: In the nature of things, young people often rebel against their parents.

sense.definition: B is very different from A, for example it is more difficult, serious, or important
examples: Romance is one thing, marriage is quite another.

sense.definition: it is not something that you really enjoy or are interested in
it is something that only a particular group understands
examples: You wouldn't know what it means—it's a girl thing.

sense.definition: to know/tell someone some useful, interesting, or surprising information about someone or something
examples: She's been married five times, so she knows a thing or two about men!

sense.definition: to make something seem more important than it really is
a situation in which you are successful, but which could also have ended badly
examples: Phew! That was a near thing! It could have been a disaster.

sense.definition: to know nothing at all about something or someone
examples: We've lived next to him for years, but we still don't know the first thing about him.

sense.definition: not considered socially acceptable
examples: It wouldn't be quite the thing to turn up in running gear.

sense.definition: not healthy or normal
used to say that you do not want to discuss or think about something bad or unpleasant that has happened, but just accept it
examples: It wasn't your fault. It was just one of those things.

sense.definition: used to complain that a lot of unpleasant things keep happening to you
used to suggest that the way one event or action leads to others is so obvious that it does not need to be stated
examples: He offered me a ride home one night, and, well, one thing led to another and now we're married!

sense.definition: used before mentioning a worry or problem you have with something
examples: I'd love to come—the only thing is I might be late.

sense.definition: to work, study, etc. too hard or for too long
examples: He's been overdoing things recently.

sense.definition: to take a risk because you have successfully avoided problems in the past
examples: You didn't get caught last time, but don't push your luck!

sense.definition: the genuine thing
examples: Are you sure it's the real thing ( = love), not just infatuation?

sense.definition: the way things seem to be organized; the way someone wants everything to be organized
examples: My personal problems are not really important in the overall scheme of things.

sense.definition: the way things are likely to develop in the future

sense.definition: used to say “yes” to a suggestion or request
examples: “Are you coming?” “Sure thing.”

sense.definition: to relax and avoid working too hard or doing too much
examples: The doctor told me to take it easy for a few weeks.

sense.definition: to not think about what will happen in the future
examples: I don't know if he'll get better. We're just taking it one day at a time.

sense.definition: there is only one possible course of action
a situation or an activity of the type mentioned
examples: She really didn't want to be involved in the whole family thing.

sense.definition: used to introduce an important fact, reason, or explanation
examples: I'm sorry my assignment isn't finished. The thing is, I've had a lot of other work this week.

sense.definition: used to introduce a problem about something or someone
examples: The thing with Karl is, he's always late.

sense.definition: used to refer to ghosts and other supernatural things that cannot be explained
examples: There are mysterious lights in the sky and things that go bump in the night.

sense.definition: used to say that, although something is pleasant, you do not want to have too much of it
because you have been busy with various problems, events, or things you had to do
examples: I completely forgot her birthday, what with one thing and another.

sense.definition: to arrange something in a particular way, especially by being smart
examples: Can you work it so that we get free tickets?

sense.definition: to have a particular idea or opinion about something or someone; to believe something
examples: Do you think (that) they'll come?

I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.

“Is he any good?” “I don't think so.”
I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.
She thought him kind and generous.
He's thought to be one of the richest men in America.
In my opinion, everyone should have some understanding of science.
Everyone should, in my opinion, have some understanding of science.
It seems to me that many people in this country have a flawed understanding of science.
This is, in my view, the result of a failure of the scientific community to get its message across.
Another reason why so many people have such a poor understanding of science is, I believe, the lack of adequate funding for science in schools.
Smith argues that science is separate from culture. My own view is that science belongs with literature, art, philosophy, and religion as an integral part of our culture.
In this writer's opinion, the more the public knows about science, the less they will fear and distrust it.

sense.definition: to use your mind to consider something, to form connected ideas, to try to solve problems, etc.
examples: Are animals able to think?
Let me think ( = give me time before I answer).
I can't tell you now—I'll have to think about it.
She had thought very deeply about this problem.
All he ever thinks about is money.
I'm sorry, I wasn't thinking ( = said when you have upset or offended someone accidentally).

sense.definition: to have ideas, words, or images in your mind
examples: You're very quiet. What are you thinking?
I was just thinking what a long way it is.
“I must be crazy,” she thought.

sense.definition: to form an idea of something; to imagine something
examples: We couldn't think where you'd gone.
Just think how nice it would be to see them again.
I can't think (that) he would be so stupid.
Just think—we'll be lying on the beach this time tomorrow.
If I'm late getting home, my mother always thinks the worst.

The house was just as she had imagined it.
I can't think of a better place for a wedding.

I can't see her changing her mind.
His colleagues see him as a future director.
They envision an equal society, free from poverty and disease.
In ten years, I envision myself running my own business.

sense.definition: to expect something
examples: I never thought (that) I'd see her again.

You'd think she'd have been grateful for my help ( = but she wasn't).

sense.definition: to think in a particular way or on a particular subject
examples: Let's think positive.

If you want to make money, you have to think money.

sense.definition: used in questions to show that you are angry or surprised
examples: What do you think you're doing?

sense.definition: used to make something you say sound less definite or more polite
examples: I thought we could go out tonight.

“You've made a mistake.” “I don't think so.”

sense.definition: to intend something; to have a plan about something
examples: I think I'll go for a swim.

sense.definition: to remember something; to have something come into your mind
examples: I didn't think ( = it did not occur to me) to tell her.

sense.definition: to behave in a very confident way that annoys other people, for example by telling them what to do
used when you suddenly remember something or realize that it might be important
examples: Come to think of it, he did mention seeing you.

sense.definition: used to say that you and another person must both be very smart because you have had the same idea or agree about something
used to say very strongly that you do not agree with something, or that something is not possible
examples: Me? Fail? I don't think so.

sense.definition: used to draw attention to a fact that is not obvious or has not previously been mentioned
examples: It was a difficult situation, when you think about it.

sense.definition: used to say that you hope or believe that something is true
examples: I like to think I'm broad-minded.

sense.definition: used to say very strongly that you believe something is not true, possible, etc.
examples: Was their meeting a coincidence? I think not.

sense.definition: that is what I expected or suspected
examples: “He said he'd forgotten.” “I thought as much.”

sense.definition: used when you are thinking or trying to remember something
examples: Now let me see—where did he say he lived?

sense.definition: to consider it right or acceptable to do something; to decide or choose to do something
examples: You must do as you think fit ( = but I don't agree with your decision).

sense.definition: to say or think bad things about someone
examples: Don't speak ill of the dead.

sense.definition: to consider a situation again and perhaps change your idea or intention
to say what your thoughts are as you have them
to have a higher opinion of someone
examples: She has behaved appallingly—I must say I thought better of her.

sense.definition: to decide not to do something after thinking further about it
examples: Rosie was about to protest but thought better of it.

sense.definition: to consider an activity to be normal and not particularly unusual or difficult
examples: She thinks nothing of walking thirty miles a day.

sense.definition: used as a polite response when someone has said sorry to you or thanked you
to be able to think and react to things very quickly and effectively without any preparation
to think about something, or how to do something, in a way that is new, different, or shows imagination
to think in a clear or logical way
to think carefully before deciding to do something
examples: You should think twice about employing someone you've never met.

sense.definition: to have a very good, poor, etc. opinion of someone or something
examples: He thinks the world of his daughter.

sense.definition: used to show that you are surprised or shocked by something
examples: To think that my mother wrote all those books and I never knew!

sense.definition: the process of thinking about something
examples: I had to do some quick thinking.

sense.definition: ideas or opinions about something
examples: What is the current thinking on this question?
She explained the thinking behind the campaign.

sense.definition: in my opinion
needing or wanting to drink
examples: We were hungry and thirsty.
Digging is thirsty work ( = makes you thirsty).

sense.definition: having a strong desire for something
examples: He is thirsty for power.

sense.definition: dry; in need of water

examples: Paul drank thirstily.

sense.definition: used to refer to a particular person, thing, or event that is close to you, especially compared with another
examples: How long have you been living in this country?
Well, make up your mind. Which do you want? This one or that one?
I think you'll find these more comfortable than those.
Is this your bag?

sense.definition: used to refer to something or someone that has already been mentioned
examples: There was a court case resulting from this incident.

What's this I hear about you getting married?

sense.definition: used for introducing someone or showing something to someone
examples: Hello, this is Maria Diaz ( = on the telephone).
Jo, this is Kate ( = when you are introducing them).
This is the captain speaking.
Listen to this.
Do it like this ( = in the way I am showing you).

sense.definition: used with periods of time related to the present
examples: this week/month/year
I saw her this morning ( = today in the morning).
Do you want me to come this Tuesday ( = Tuesday of this week) or next Tuesday?
Do it this minute ( = now).
He never comes to see me these days ( = now, as compared with the past).

sense.definition: used to refer to someone or something that is connected with a person, especially when you have a particular attitude toward it or them
examples: These new friends of hers are supposed to be very rich.

sense.definition: used when you are telling a story or telling someone about something
examples: There was this strange man sitting next to me on the plane.

sense.definition: various things or activities
examples: “What did you talk about?” “Oh, this and that.”

sense.definition: done completely; with great attention to detail
examples: a thorough knowledge of the subject

sense.definition: doing things very carefully and with great attention to detail
examples: She's very thorough and conscientious.

I admire his thoroughness.

sense.definition: very much; completely
examples: We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.

a thoroughly professional performance

sense.definition: completely and with great attention to detail
examples: Wash the fruit thoroughly before use.

sense.definition: despite the fact that
examples: Anne was fond of Tim, though he often annoyed her.

sense.definition: used to add a fact or an opinion that makes the previous statement less strong or less important
examples: They're very different, though they did seem to get on well when they met.

sense.definition: in a way that suggests something
examples: He behaved as if nothing had happened.
It sounds as though you had a good time.

sense.definition: despite the fact or belief that; no matter whether
examples: I'll get there, even if I have to walk.

sense.definition: something that you think of or remember
examples: I don't like the thought of you walking home alone.

The very thought of it makes me feel sick.
I've just had a thought ( = an idea).

“Why don't you try the other key?” “That's a thought!”

I'd like to hear your thoughts on the subject.

sense.definition: a person's mind and all the ideas that they have in it when they are thinking
examples: My thoughts turned to home.
You are always in my thoughts.

sense.definition: the power or process of thinking
examples: A good teacher encourages independence of thought.
She was lost in thought ( = concentrating so much on her thoughts that she was not aware of her surroundings).

sense.definition: the act of thinking seriously and carefully about something
examples: I've given the matter careful thought.
Not enough thought has gone into this essay.

sense.definition: a feeling of care or worry
examples: Spare a thought for those without enough to eat this winter.

sense.definition: an intention or a hope of doing something

sense.definition: ideas in politics, science, etc. connected with a particular person, group, or period of history

sense.definition: to try to control your emotions and become calm

sense.definition: to prepare yourself mentally for something

sense.definition: an idea that makes you think seriously and carefully

sense.definition: to make someone think seriously about something or hesitate before doing something

sense.definition: to change your opinion after thinking about something again

sense.definition: used to say that you have changed your opinion

sense.definition: used to ask someone what they are thinking about
used to say that you find a suggestion unacceptable or that you hope that something will never happen

sense.definition: a way of thinking that a number of people share

sense.definition: the connected series of thoughts that are in your head at a particular time

sense.definition: we believe a thing because we want it to be true
immediately; without stopping to think about something further

sense.definition: a thin string of cotton, wool, silk, etc. used for sewing or making cloth

sense.definition: an idea or a feature that is part of something greater; an idea that connects the different parts of something

sense.definition: a long thin line of something

sense.definition: a series of connected messages on a message board on the Internet which have been sent by different people
the raised line that runs around the length of a screw and that allows it to be attached by twisting
clothes

sense.definition: a person or thing that is likely to cause trouble, danger, etc.

sense.definition: to be a danger to something

sense.definition: expressing a threat of harm or violence

sense.definition: showing that bad weather is likely

sense.definition: a passage in the neck through which food and air pass on their way into the body; the front part of the neck

sense.definition: having the type of throat mentioned
examples: a deep-throated roar
a red-throated diver

sense.definition: to be fighting or arguing with each other
to cough so that you can speak clearly

sense.definition: to be difficult or impossible to accept; to make you angry
from one end or side of something or someone to the other
examples: The burglar got in through the window.

sense.definition: from the beginning to the end of an activity, a situation, or a period of time

sense.definition: past a barrier, stage, or test

sense.definition: during the whole period of time of something

sense.definition: to move something suddenly and with force

sense.definition: to make someone feel upset, confused, or surprised

sense.definition: to roll a dice or let it fall after shaking it; to obtain a particular number in this way
examples: Throw the dice!

sense.definition: to make a clay pot, dish, etc. on a potter's wheel
examples: a hand-thrown vase

sense.definition: to send light or shade onto something

sense.definition: to make your voice sound as if it is coming from another person or place
to hit, or try to hit, someone with your fist

sense.definition: to give a party

sense.definition: the short thick finger at the side of the hand, slightly apart from the other four

sense.definition: the part of a glove that covers the thumb

sense.definition: to be awkward with your hands so that you drop things or are unable to do something

sense.definition: to be very noticeable in an unpleasant way

sense.definition: used to show that something has been accepted/rejected or that it is/is not a success

sense.definition: to move your thumbs around each other with your fingers joined together
to do nothing while you are waiting for something to happen

sense.definition: the day of the week after Wednesday and before Friday

sense.definition: in this way; like this
examples: Many scholars have argued thus.

Children who grow up on a diet of junk food find it difficult to change this habit later in life. It is essential, therefore, that parents encourage healthy eating from an early age.
Children who grow up on a diet of junk food find it difficult to change this habit later in life. For this reason, /This is why it is essential that children eat healthily from an early age.
Eating habits formed in childhood tend to continue into adult life. Thus, the best way to prevent heart disease among adults is to encourage healthy eating from an early age.
Eating habits formed in childhood tend to continue into adult life, hence the importance of encouraging healthy eating from an early age.

sense.definition: until now; up to this point
examples: What do you think of the book so far?

sense.definition: to be closed or fastened with a knot, etc.

sense.definition: to get married

held or attached in position firmly; difficult to move or undo

not allowing the substance mentioned to enter

sense.definition: used to say that something should have happened before now

sense.definition: earlier/later than was expected

sense.definition: having advanced or new ideas that other people use or copy later

sense.definition: to enjoy yourself very much

sense.definition: when enough time has passed

sense.definition: when the time is appropriate, usually after a long period

sense.definition: not late; with enough time to be able to do something

sense.definition: used to say hello to someone you have not seen for a long time

sense.definition: used, especially at the beginning of stories, to mean “a long time in the past”

sense.definition: in your free time and not when you usually work or study

sense.definition: in, to, or through a position that is below something
examples: Have you looked under the bed?
She placed the ladder under ( = just lower than) the window.
The dog squeezed under the gate and ran into the road.

sense.definition: below the surface of something; covered by something
examples: The boat lay under several feet of water.

sense.definition: less than; younger than
examples: an annual income of under $10,000
It took us under an hour.
Nobody under 21 is allowed to buy alcohol.

sense.definition: used to say who or what controls, governs, or manages someone or something
examples: The country is now under martial law.
The coinage was reformed under Elizabeth I ( = when she was queen).
She has a staff of 19 working under her.
Under its new conductor, the orchestra has established an international reputation.

sense.definition: according to an agreement, a law or a system
examples: Six suspects are being held under the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.
Under the terms of the lease you had no right to sublet the property.
Is the television still under guarantee?

sense.definition: experiencing a particular process
examples: The hotel is still under construction.
The matter is under investigation.

sense.definition: affected by something
examples: The wall collapsed under the strain.
I've been feeling under stress lately.
I'm under no illusions about what hard work this will be.
You'll be under anesthetic, so you won't feel a thing.

sense.definition: using a particular name
examples: She also writes under the pseudonym of Barbara Vine.

sense.definition: found in a particular part of a book, list, etc.
examples: If it's not under “sports,” try looking under “games.”

sense.definition: under the surface of the ground
examples: underground passages/caves/streams
underground cables

sense.definition: operating secretly and often illegally, especially against a government
examples: an underground resistance movement

sense.definition: under or below something else, especially when it is hidden or covered by the thing on top
examples: The coin rolled underneath the piano.
This jacket's too big, even with a sweater underneath.

sense.definition: used to talk about someone's real feelings or character, as opposed to the way they seem to be
examples: Underneath her cool exterior she was really very frightened.
He seems grumpy, but he's very soft-hearted underneath.

sense.definition: to know or realize the meaning of words, a language, what someone says, etc.
examples: Can you understand French?
Do you understand the instructions?
She didn't understand the form she was signing.
I'm not sure that I understand. Go over it again.
I don't want you doing that again. Do you understand?
I don't understand what he's saying.

sense.definition: to know or realize how or why something happens, how it works, or why it is important
examples: Doctors still don't understand much about the disease.
No one is answering the phone — I can't understand it.
I could never understand why she was fired.
They're too young to understand what is happening.
I just can't understand him taking the money.
I just can't understand his taking the money.
He was the first to understand that we live in a knowledge economy.

sense.definition: to know someone's character, how they feel, and why they behave in the way they do
examples: Nobody understands me.
He doesn't understand women at all.
We understand each other, even if we don't always agree.
They understand what I have been through.
I understand how hard things have been for you.
I understand that you need some time alone.
If you want to leave early, I'm sure he'll understand.
I understand you needing some time alone.

sense.definition: to think or believe that something is true because you have been told that it is
examples: I understand (that) you wish to see the manager.
Am I to understand that you refuse?
The senator is understood to have been extremely angry about the report.
It is understood that the band is working on their next album.

sense.definition: to agree something with someone without it needing to be said
examples: I thought it was understood that my expenses would be paid.

sense.definition: to realize that a word in a phrase or sentence is not expressed and to supply it in your mind
examples: In the sentence “I can't drive,” the object “a car” is understood.

sense.definition: to make someone believe/understand something
examples: I was given to understand that she had resigned.

sense.definition: to make your meaning clear, especially in another language
examples: He doesn't speak much Japanese, but he can make himself understood.

sense.definition: the knowledge that someone has about a particular subject or situation
examples: The committee has little or no understanding of the problem.
The existence of God is beyond human understanding ( = humans cannot know whether God exists or not).
Most of the students have a sound understanding of English grammar.

sense.definition: an informal agreement
examples: We finally came to an understanding about what hours we would work.
We have this understanding that no one talks about work over lunch.

sense.definition: the ability to understand why people behave in a particular way and the willingness to forgive them when they do something wrong
examples: We must tackle the problem with sympathy and understanding.
We are looking for a better understanding between the two nations.
Try to show a little more understanding.

sense.definition: the particular way in which someone understands something
examples: My understanding of the situation is…
The statement is open to various understandings.

sense.definition: used to introduce a condition that must be agreed before something else can happen
examples: They agreed to the changes on the understanding that they would be introduced gradually.

sense.definition: found, used, or happening below the surface of water
examples: underwater creatures
an underwater camera
Take a deep breath and see how long you can stay underwater.

sense.definition: clothes that you wear under other clothes and next to the skin
examples: She packed one change of underwear.

sense.definition: to open something that is fastened, tied or wrapped
examples: to undo a button/knot/zip, etc.
to undo a jacket/shirt, etc.
I undid the package and took out the books.

sense.definition: to cancel the effect of something
examples: He undid most of the good work of the previous manager.
It's not too late to try and undo some of the damage.
UNDO ( = a command on a computer that cancels the previous action)

sense.definition: to make someone or something fail
examples: The team was undone by the speed and strength of their opponents.

sense.definition: without a job although able to work
examples: How long have you been unemployed?
an unemployed lawyer
an increase in the number of people registered as unemployed
a program to get the long-term unemployed back to work
I've joined the ranks of the unemployed ( = I've lost my job).

sense.definition: the fact of a number of people not having a job; the number of people without a job
examples: an area of high/low unemployment
rising/falling unemployment
It was a time of mass unemployment.
measures to help reduce/tackle unemployment
the level/rate of unemployment
unemployment benefits/statistics
a rise in both inflation and unemployment

sense.definition: the state of not having a job
examples: Thousands of young people are facing long-term unemployment.
a study of male/female unemployment
Since losing his job, Mike has been collecting unemployment.

sense.definition: if something is unexpected, it surprises you because you were not expecting it
examples: an unexpected result
an unexpected visitor
The announcement was not entirely unexpected.
Police officers must be prepared for the unexpected.
They had arrived unexpectedly.
an unexpectedly large bill
The plane was unexpectedly delayed.
Not unexpectedly, most local business depends on tourism.
She died unexpectedly of a heart attack.

sense.definition: not right or fair according to a set of rules or principles; not treating people equally
examples: unfair criticism
It seems unfair on him to make him pay for everything.
It would be unfair not to let you have a choice.
They had been given an unfair advantage.
measures to prevent unfair competition between member countries
Life seems so unfair sometimes.
It's so unfair!
She claims to have been unfairly dismissed.
The tests discriminate unfairly against older people.

sense.definition: having bad luck; caused by bad luck
examples: He was unfortunate to lose in the final round.
It was an unfortunate accident.
The unfortunate animal was locked inside the house for a week.

sense.definition: if you say that a situation is unfortunate, you wish that it had not happened or that it had been different
examples: She described the decision as “unfortunate.”
It was unfortunate that he couldn't speak English.
You're putting me in a most unfortunate position.
It is vital that more is done to prevent the illegal trade in wild animals.
(Compare: We have to do more to stop people trading wild animals illegally. )
It is clear that more needs to be done to protect biodiversity.
(Compare: We clearly need to do more to protect biodiversity. )
It is unfortunate that the practice of keeping monkeys as pets still continues.
(Compare: It's absolutely terrible that people still keep monkeys as pets. )
It is difficult for many people to understand the reasons why certain individuals choose to hunt animals for sport.
(Compare: I can't understand why anyone would want to kill animals for fun. )
Unfortunately, it would seem that not enough is being done to support tiger conservation.
(Compare: Governments aren't doing enough to help tiger conservation. )
There is no doubt that the greatest threat to polar bears comes from global warming.
(Compare: I believe that the greatest threat… )

sense.definition: embarrassing and/or offensive
examples: It was an unfortunate choice of words.

sense.definition: used to say that a particular situation or fact makes you sad or disappointed, or gets you into a difficult position
examples: Unfortunately, I won't be able to attend the meeting.
I can't make it, unfortunately.
Unfortunately for him, the police had been informed and were waiting outside.
It won't be finished for a few weeks. Unfortunately!

sense.definition: not kind or pleasant to someone
examples: an unfriendly atmosphere
There's no need to be so unfriendly toward them.
the use of environmentally unfriendly products ( = that harm the environment)

sense.definition: not happy; sad
examples: to be/look/seem/sound unhappy
an unhappy childhood
I didn't realize, but he was deeply unhappy at that time.

sense.definition: not pleased or satisfied with something
examples: They were unhappy with their hotel room.
He was unhappy at being left out of the team.
Many people are really unhappy about the way the government has handled this matter.

sense.definition: unfortunate or not suitable
examples: an unhappy coincidence
It was an unhappy choice of words.

sense.definition: the special set of clothes worn by all members of an organization or a group at work, or by children at school
examples: a military/police/nurse's uniform
soldiers in uniform
The hat is part of the school uniform.
Do you have to wear a uniform?

sense.definition: the clothes worn by the members of a sports team when they are playing
examples: a striped baseball uniform
the team's road uniform ( = that they use when playing games away from home)

sense.definition: the type of clothes that a person or group usually wears
examples: my standard teenage uniform of sweatshirt and jeans
the traditional banker's uniform

sense.definition: not important
examples: unimportant details
relatively/comparatively unimportant
They dismissed the problem as unimportant.
This consideration was not unimportant.
I was just a nobody from a small town and I felt very unimportant.

sense.definition: an organization of workers, usually in a particular industry, that exists to protect their interests, improve conditions of work, etc.
examples: I've joined the union.
a union member

sense.definition: an association or a club for people or organizations with the same interest
a group of states or countries that have the same central government or that agree to work together
examples: the former Soviet Union
the European Union

sense.definition: the U.S. (used especially at the time of the Civil War)
examples: the Union and the Confederacy
the State of the Union address by the President

sense.definition: the act of joining two or more things together; the state of being joined together; the act of two people joining together
examples: a summit to discuss economic and monetary union
a union with one of the big banks

sense.definition: a marriage
examples: Their union was blessed with six children.

sense.definition: being the only one of its kind
examples: Everyone's fingerprints are unique.

sense.definition: very special or unusual
examples: a unique talent
The preview offers a unique opportunity to see the show without the crowds.
The deal will put the company in a unique position to export goods to Asia.

sense.definition: belonging to or connected with one particular person, place, or thing
examples: an atmosphere that is unique to New York
The koala is unique to Australia.
Her past experience made her uniquely suited to lead the campaign.
The U.K., uniquely, has not had to face the problem of mass unemployment.
He was a uniquely gifted teacher.
The author stresses the uniqueness of the individual.

sense.definition: a single thing, person, or group that is complete by itself but can also form part of something larger
examples: The cell is the unit of which all living organisms are composed.
The basic unit of society is the family.

sense.definition: a single item of the type of product that a company sells
examples: The game's retail price was $15 per unit.
What's the unit cost?

sense.definition: a group of people who work or live together, especially for a particular purpose
examples: army/military/police units
Medical units were operating in the disaster area.

sense.definition: a fixed quantity, etc. that is used as a standard measurement
examples: a unit of time/length/weight
a unit of currency, such as the euro or the dollar

sense.definition: a piece of furniture, especially a cupboard, that fits with and matches others of the same type
examples: a custom kitchen with white units
floor/wall units
bedroom/kitchen/storage units

sense.definition: a small machine that has a particular purpose or is part of a larger machine
examples: a waste disposal unit
the central processing unit of a computer

sense.definition: one of the parts into which a textbook or a series of lessons is divided
examples: The present perfect is covered in Unit 8.

sense.definition: one of the parts or sections that a large building is divided into
a department, especially in a hospital, that provides a particular type of care or treatment
examples: the intensive care unit
a trauma unit

sense.definition: any whole number from 0 to 9
examples: a column for the tens and a column for the units

sense.definition: to join together with other people in order to do something as a group
examples: Local resident groups have united in opposition to the plan.
We will unite in fighting crime.
Will they unite behind the new leader?
Nationalist parties united to oppose the government's plans.

sense.definition: to make people or things join together to form a unit; to join together
examples: A special bond unites our two countries.
His aim was to unite the North and South.
The two countries united in 1887.
She unites good business skills with a charming personality.

sense.definition: joined together as a political unit or by shared aims
examples: the United States of America
efforts to build a united Europe

sense.definition: in agreement and working together
examples: We need to become a more united team.
They are united in their opposition to the plan.
We should present a united front ( = an appearance of being in agreement with each other).

sense.definition: done by or involving all the people in the world or in a particular group
examples: Such problems are a universal feature of old age.
Agreement on this issue is almost universal.
universal suffrage ( = the right of all the people in a country to vote)

sense.definition: true or right at all times and in all places
examples: universal facts about human nature
the universality of religious experience

sense.definition: the whole of space and everything in it, including the earth, the planets, and the stars
examples: theories of how the universe began

sense.definition: a system of stars, planets, etc. in space outside our own
examples: The idea of a parallel universe is hard to grasp.
He lives in a little universe of his own.

sense.definition: a set of experiences of a particular type
examples: the moral universe

sense.definition: an institution at the highest level of education where you can study for a degree or do research
examples: Penn State University
the University of Michigan
Harvard University
a university degree/professor

sense.definition: the experience of life thought of as giving someone an education, instead of the person gaining formal qualifications
unpleasant or unfriendly; slightly cruel
examples: an unkind remark
He was never actually unkind to them.
It would be unkind to go without him.
She never said anything unkind about anyone.
“That's your problem,” she remarked unkindly.
“Don't be silly,” he said, not unkindly.
I'm sure it wasn't meant unkindly.

sense.definition: not known or identified
examples: a species of insect previously unknown to science
He was trying, for some unknown reason, to count the stars.
The man's identity remains unknown.

sense.definition: not famous or well known
examples: an unknown actor
The author is virtually unknown outside Poland.

sense.definition: never happening or existing
examples: The disease is as yet unknown in Europe ( = there have been no cases there).
It was not unknown for people to have to wait several hours ( = it happened sometimes).

sense.definition: a person or thing whose qualities or abilities are not yet known
without the person mentioned being aware of it
examples: Unknown to me, he had already signed the agreement.

sense.definition: used to say that something can only happen or be true in a particular situation
examples: You won't get paid for time off unless you have a doctor's note.
I won't tell them — not unless you say I can.
Unless I'm mistaken, she was back at work yesterday.
He hasn't got any hobbies — unless you call watching TV a hobby.

sense.definition: used to give the only situation in which something will not happen or be true
examples: I sleep with the window open unless it's really cold.
Unless something unexpected happens, I'll see you tomorrow.
Have a cup of tea — unless you'd prefer a cold drink?
If you weren't always in such a hurry ( = but you are), your work would be much better.

sense.definition: different from a particular person or thing
examples: Music is quite unlike any other art form.
The sound was not unlike that of birds singing.

sense.definition: used to contrast someone or something with another person or thing
examples: Unlike most systems, this one is very easy to install.
This survey highlights a number of differences in the way that teenage boys and girls in the U.S. spend their free time.
One of the main differences between the girls and the boys who took part in the research was the way in which they use the Internet.
Unlike the girls, who use the Internet mainly to keep in touch with friends, the boys questioned in this survey tend to use the Internet for playing computer games.
The girls differ from the boys in that they tend to spend more time keeping in touch with friends on the telephone or on social networking websites.
Compared with the boys, the girls spend much more time chatting to friends on the telephone.
On average, the girls spend four hours a week chatting to friends on the phone. In contrast, very few of the boys spend more than five minutes a day talking to their friends in this way.
The boys prefer competitive sports and computer games, whereas/while the girls seem to enjoy more cooperative activities, such as shopping with friends.
When the girls go shopping, they mainly buy clothes and cosmetics. The boys, on the other hand, tend to purchase computer games or gadgets.

sense.definition: not typical of someone or something
examples: It's very unlike him to be so late.

sense.definition: not likely to happen
examples: The project seemed unlikely to succeed.
It's most ( = very) unlikely that she'll arrive before seven.
In the unlikely event of a problem arising, please contact the hotel manager.

sense.definition: not the person, thing, or place that you would normally think of or expect
examples: He seems a most unlikely candidate for the job.
They have built hotels in the most unlikely places.

sense.definition: difficult to believe
examples: She gave me an unlikely explanation for her behavior.

sense.definition: to remove things from a vehicle or ship after it has taken them somewhere
examples: Everyone helped to unload the luggage from the car.
This isn't a suitable place to unload the van.
The truck driver was waiting to unload.

sense.definition: to remove the contents of something after you have finished using it, especially the bullets from a gun or the film from a camera
to pass the responsibility for someone or something to someone else
examples: It's his problem, not something he should unload onto you.

sense.definition: to get rid of or sell something, especially something illegal or of bad quality
examples: They want to unload their shares at the right price.

sense.definition: to express strong feelings or worries
examples: Give her a chance to unload.
He's just unloading his anger on us.

sense.definition: having bad luck or happening because of bad luck; not lucky
examples: He was very unlucky not to win.
If you're unlucky enough to get trapped in an elevator, remember not to panic.
By some unlucky chance, her name was left off the list.

sense.definition: causing bad luck
examples: Some people think it's unlucky to walk under a ladder.
Thirteen is often considered an unlucky number.

sense.definition: not needed; more than is needed
examples: unnecessary expense
They were found guilty of causing unnecessary suffering to animals.
All this fuss is totally unnecessary.

sense.definition: not needed in the situation and likely to be offensive
examples: That last comment was a little unnecessary, wasn't it?
There's no point worrying him unnecessarily.
unnecessarily complicated instructions

sense.definition: not pleasant or comfortable
examples: an unpleasant experience
The minerals in the water made it unpleasant to drink.

sense.definition: not kind, friendly or polite
examples: He was very unpleasant to me.
She said some very unpleasant things about you.
The drink is very sweet, but not unpleasantly so.
He laughed unpleasantly.

sense.definition: not fair; expecting too much
examples: The job was beginning to make unreasonable demands on his free time.
The fees they charge are not unreasonable.
It would be unreasonable to expect somebody to come at such short notice.
He was being totally unreasonable about it.

sense.definition: not completely in control of your movements so that you might fall
examples: She is still a little unsteady on her feet after the operation.

sense.definition: shaking or moving in a way that is not controlled
examples: an unsteady hand
She walked unsteadily toward me.
“I had to see you,” he said unsteadily.
She swayed unsteadily as she got up from the bar.

sense.definition: not successful; not achieving what you wanted to
examples: His efforts to get a job proved unsuccessful.
They were unsuccessful in meeting their objectives for the year.
She made several unsuccessful attempts to see him.

sense.definition: up to the point in time or the event mentioned
examples: Let's wait until the rain stops.
Until she spoke I hadn't realized she wasn't American.
You're not going out until you finish this.
Until now I have always lived alone.
They moved here in 2009. Until then they'd always been in the Denver area.
He continued working up until his death.
The street is full of traffic from morning till night.
You can stay on the bus until Dallas ( = until you reach Dallas).

sense.definition: different from what is usual or normal
examples: It's unusual for the trees to flower so early.
She has a very unusual name.
It's not unusual for young doctors to work a 70-hour week ( = it happens often).

sense.definition: different from other similar things and therefore interesting and attractive
examples: an unusual color

sense.definition: used before adjectives to emphasize that a particular quality is greater than normal
examples: unusually high levels of radiation
an unusually cold winter
The turnout was unusually low.

sense.definition: used to say that a particular situation is not normal or expected
examples: Unusually for him, he wore a tie.

sense.definition: not wanting to do something and refusing to do it
examples: They are unwilling to invest any more money in the project.
She was unable, or unwilling, to give me any further details.

sense.definition: not wanting to do or be something, but forced to by other people
examples: an unwilling hero
He became the unwilling object of her attention.
The country was drawn unwillingly into the war.
She agreed to their conditions, albeit unwillingly.

sense.definition: toward or in a higher position
examples: He jumped up from his chair.
The sun was already up ( = had risen) when they set off.
They live up in the mountains.
It didn't take long to put the tent up.
I pinned the notice up on the wall.
Lay the cards face up ( = facing upward) on the table.
You look nice with your hair up ( = arranged on top of or at the back of your head).
Up you go! ( = said when lifting a child).

sense.definition: to or at a higher level
examples: She turned the volume up.
Prices are still going up ( = rising).
The Mets were 4 runs up in the top of the 7th inning.
The wind is getting up ( = blowing more strongly).
Sales are up on last year.
The number of foreign students in the U.S. increased from 622,000 in 2009 to just over 672,000 in 2010.
First-time student enrollments shot up/increased dramatically in 2010.
2010 saw a significant rise in student numbers.
The number of foreign students increased by almost 8% compared with the previous year.
The 2010 figure was 672,000, an increase of 8% from the previous year.
The 2010 figure was 672,000, up 8%from the previous year.
As the chart shows, this can partly be explained by a dramatic increase in students from China.
The number of Chinese undergraduate students rose sharply from 81,000 in 2009 to 98,000 in 2010.

sense.definition: to the place where someone or something is
examples: A car drove up and he got in.
She went straight up to the door and knocked loudly.

sense.definition: to or at an important place, especially a large city
examples: We're going up to New York for the day.

sense.definition: to a place in the north of a country
examples: They've moved up north.
We drove up to Maine to see my father.

sense.definition: into pieces or parts
examples: She tore the paper up.
How shall we divide up the work?

sense.definition: completely
examples: We ate all the food up.
The stream has dried up.

sense.definition: so as to be formed or brought together
examples: The government agreed to set up a committee of inquiry.
She gathered up her belongings.

sense.definition: so as to be finished or closed
examples: I have some paperwork to finish up.
Do your coat up; it's cold.

sense.definition: finished; over
examples: Time's up. Stop writing and hand in your papers.

sense.definition: out of bed
examples: I stayed up late ( = did not go to bed until late) last night.

sense.definition: used to say that something is happening, especially something unusual or unpleasant
examples: I could tell something was up by the looks on their faces.
What's up? ( = What is the matter?)
What's up with him? He looks furious.
Is anything up? You can tell me.

sense.definition: to be someone's duty or responsibility; to be for someone to decide
examples: It's not up to you to tell me how to do my job.
Shall we eat out or stay in? It's up to you.

sense.definition: facing problems or opposition
examples: Teachers are up against some major problems these days.
She's really up against it ( = in a difficult situation).

sense.definition: moving upward and downward
examples: The boat bobbed up and down on the water.

sense.definition: in one direction and then in the opposite direction
examples: She was pacing up and down in front of her desk.

sense.definition: sometimes good and sometimes bad
examples: My relationship with him was up and down.

sense.definition: if you swear up and down that something is true, you say that it is definitely true
working; being used
examples: By that time the new system should be up and running.

sense.definition: appearing in front of someone in authority for a judgment to be made about something that you have done
examples: He came up before the judge for speeding.

sense.definition: on offer for something
examples: The house is up for sale.

sense.definition: being considered for something, especially as a candidate
examples: Two candidates are up for election.

sense.definition: willing to take part in a particular activity
examples: We're going clubbing tonight. Are you up for it?

sense.definition: among or almost the best, worst, most important, etc.
examples: It may not have been the worst week of my life but it's up there.
OK, it's not my absolute dream, but it's up there.
These people can't live without the Internet—it's up there with air and water.

sense.definition: as far as a particular number, level, etc.
examples: I can take up to four people ( = but no more than four) in my car.
The temperature went up to 95°F.

sense.definition: not further or later than something; until something
examples: Read up to page 100.
Up to now he's been very quiet.

sense.definition: as high or as good as something
examples: Her latest book isn't up to her usual standard.

sense.definition: physically or mentally capable of something
examples: He's not up to the job.
I don't feel up to going to work today.

sense.definition: doing something, especially something bad
examples: What's she up to?
What've you been up to?
I'm sure he's up to no good ( = doing something bad).
The decision was based upon two considerations.
once upon a time
row upon row of seats.

sense.definition: used to emphasize that there is a large number or amount of something
examples: mile upon mile of dusty road
thousands upon thousands of letters

sense.definition: used, especially at the beginning of stories, to mean “a long time in the past”
examples: Once upon a time there was a beautiful princess.

sense.definition: if something in the future is almost upon you, it is going to arrive or happen very soon
examples: The summer season was almost upon them again.

sense.definition: located above something else, especially something of the same type or the other of a pair
examples: the upper lip
the upper deck

sense.definition: at or near the top of something
examples: the upper arm
the upper slopes of the mountain
a member of the upper middle class
salaries at the upper end of the pay scale
There is an upper limit of $20,000 spent on any one project.

sense.definition: located away from the coast, on high ground or toward the north of an area
examples: the upper reaches of the river

sense.definition: to get an advantage over someone so that you are in control of a particular situation
to keep calm and hide your feelings when you are in pain or in a difficult situation
examples: He was taught to keep a stiff upper lip and never to cry in public.
Their reaction contrasts sharply with the stiff upper lip of the English.

sense.definition: to make someone/yourself feel unhappy, anxious, or annoyed
examples: This decision is likely to upset a lot of people.
Try not to let him upset you.
Don't upset yourself about it — let's just forget it ever happened.
It upset him that no one had bothered to tell him about it.
It upsets me to think of her all alone in that big house.
Please don't be angry with me.
Thousands of angry demonstrators filled the square.
He got mad and walked out.
She's mad at me for being late.
He was furious at having been taken out of the game.
He was furious with her for ruining the party.
I was quite upset with him for being late.
She was very indignant at the way she had been treated.
irate customers
an irate letter

sense.definition: to make a plan, situation, etc. go wrong
examples: He arrived an hour late and upset all our arrangements.

sense.definition: to make someone feel sick after they have eaten or drunk something
to make something fall over by hitting it by accident
examples: She stood up suddenly, upsetting a glass of wine.

sense.definition: to cause problems for someone or spoil their plans, arrangements, etc.
in or into a position in which the top of something is where the bottom is normally found and the bottom is where the top is normally found
examples: The canoe floated upside down on the lake.

sense.definition: to make a place messy when looking for something
examples: The police turned the whole house upside down looking for clues.

sense.definition: to cause large changes and confusion in a person's life
examples: His sudden death turned her world upside down.

sense.definition: up the stairs; on or to a floor of a house or other building higher than the one that you are on
examples: The cat belongs to the people who live upstairs.

sense.definition: in the mind; mentally
examples: She works hard, but she doesn't have much upstairs ( = she is not intelligent).
an upstairs room

sense.definition: to move someone to a job that seems to be more important but which actually has less power or influence
pointing toward or facing a higher place
examples: an upward gaze

sense.definition: increasing in amount or price
examples: an upward movement in property prices
an upward trend in the rate of unemployment

sense.definition: connected with a town or city
examples: damage to both urban and rural environments
urban areas
urban life
urban development ( = the process of building towns and cities or making them larger)
urban renewal/regeneration ( = the process of improving the buildings, etc. in the poor parts of a town or city)
efforts to control urban sprawl ( = the spread of city buildings into the countryside)

sense.definition: connected with types of music such as rhythm and blues and reggae that are played by black musicians
examples: today's urban music scene
urban radio shows

sense.definition: to advise or try hard to persuade someone to do something
examples: She urged him to stay.
Police are urging anyone who saw the accident to contact them immediately.
The report urged that all children be taught to swim.
“Why not give it a try?” she urged (him).

a recommended price of $50

Police are advising fans without tickets to stay away.
The group does not advocate the use of violence.
The situation is dangerous, and the UN is urging caution.

sense.definition: to recommend something strongly
examples: The situation is dangerous and the UN is urging caution.

sense.definition: to make a person or an animal move more quickly and/or in a particular direction, especially by pushing or forcing them
examples: He urged his horse forward.

sense.definition: that needs to be dealt with or happen immediately
examples: an urgent appeal for information
a problem that requires urgent attention

sense.definition: showing that you think that something needs to be dealt with immediately
examples: an urgent whisper

There was a note of urgency in his voice.
New equipment is urgently needed.
I need to speak to her urgently.
“We must find him,” she said urgently.

sense.definition: used when the speaker or writer and another or others are the object of a verb or preposition, or after the verb be
examples: She gave us a picture as a wedding present.
We'll take the dog with us.
Please let us in.

sense.definition: to do something with a machine, a method, an object, etc. for a particular purpose
examples: Can I use your phone?

How often do you use ( = travel by) the bus?

sense.definition: to take a particular amount of a liquid, substance, etc. in order to achieve or make something
examples: This type of heater uses a lot of electricity.

sense.definition: to say or write particular words or a particular type of language

sense.definition: to be kind, friendly, etc. to someone with the intention of getting an advantage for yourself from them

sense.definition: to take illegal drugs
examples: Most of the inmates have used drugs at some point in their lives.

sense.definition: used to say that you would like to have something very much

sense.definition: used to tell someone to think about something, especially when they have asked for your opinion or said something stupid

sense.definition: familiar with something because you do it or experience it often
examples: I'm not used to eating so much at lunchtime.

sense.definition: that has belonged to or been used by someone else before

sense.definition: used to say that something happened continuously or frequently during a period in the past
examples: I used to live in London.

sense.definition: not very good at something; not able to do things well

sense.definition: a person or thing that uses something

a user manual

sense.definition: a person who uses illegal drugs
that happens or is done most of the time or in most cases

sense.definition: what usually happens; what you usually have, especially the drink that you usually have

sense.definition: in the same way as what happens most of the time or in most cases
examples: Steve, as usual, was the last to arrive.

sense.definition: a way of saying that things will continue as normal despite a difficult situation
in the way that is usual or normal; most often

sense.definition: a period of time spent traveling or resting away from home

sense.definition: one of the periods of time when schools, colleges, or courts of law are closed

sense.definition: that is legally or officially acceptable

sense.definition: that is accepted by the system

sense.definition: an area of low land between hills or mountains, often with a river flowing through it; the land that a river flows through

sense.definition: very useful or important

sense.definition: worth a lot of money
examples: valuable antiques

sense.definition: how much something is worth in money or other goods for which it can be exchanged
examples: to go up/rise/increase in value
to go down/fall/drop in value

house prices

sense.definition: beliefs about what is right and wrong and what is important in life

sense.definition: the amount represented by a letter or symbol
examples: Let x have the value 33.

sense.definition: a covered vehicle with no side windows in its back half, usually smaller than a truck, used for carrying goods

sense.definition: a covered vehicle with side windows, smaller than a bus, that can carry about twelve passengers

sense.definition: a change, especially in the amount or level of something

if you never waste anything, especially food or money, you will always have it when you need it
to look at someone or something for a time, paying attention to what happens

She stood and watched as the taxi drove off.
We watched to see what would happen next.
Watch what I do, then you try.

They watched the bus disappear into the distance.
Here, take a look at this.

He felt embarrassed under her steady gaze.

He caught a glimpse of her in the crowd.
She gave her questioner a hostile glare.

sense.definition: to take care of someone or something for a short time
examples: Could you watch my bags for me while I buy a paper?

sense.definition: to be careful about something

used as a warning to someone to be careful
to be careful what you say in order not to offend someone or make them angry
examples: Watch your language, young man!

sense.definition: to walk carefully
to behave in a careful and sensible way

sense.definition: used in orders, to tell someone to wait for more news about something to be announced

sense.definition: to be sure that you know what the time is, so that you finish something at the correct time, or are not late for something

sense.definition: to relax and watch people in a public place
examples: We sat outside a café, watching the world go by.

sense.definition: a liquid without color, smell, or taste that falls as rain, is in lakes, rivers, and oceans, and is used for drinking, washing, etc.

drinking water
water pollution
clean/dirty water

sense.definition: an area of water, especially a lake, river, or ocean

shallow/deep water

sense.definition: the water in a particular lake, river, or ocean

sense.definition: the surface of a mass of water
examples: She dived under the water.

sense.definition: an area of ocean belonging to a particular country
examples: We were still in American waters.
fishing in international waters

sense.definition: used to describe a situation, usually one that is difficult, dangerous, or not familiar
examples: The conversation got into the murky waters of jealousy and relationships.

sense.definition: to be in or get into trouble
family relationships are stronger than any others
to destroy someone or something completely
to show that someone or something is not good by being very much better than it/them
examples: A DVD music system plays disks that look like CDs, but blows them out of the water.

sense.definition: using a boat or ship
examples: They reached Naples by water.

sense.definition: a person or plan that is dead in the water has failed and has little hope of succeeding in the future
examples: His leadership campaign is dead in the water.

sense.definition: to start doing something very carefully to see if it will be successful or not
examples: We decided to dip a toe in the computer games market.

sense.definition: a person who feels uncomfortable or awkward because he or she is in surroundings that are not familiar
despite any difficulties
examples: I was determined to go, come hell or high water.

sense.definition: in trouble or difficulty
used to say that something happened in the past and is now forgotten or no longer important
to deal with a difficult situation, especially one in which you have financial problems, and just manage to survive
examples: I'm not sure how much longer we'll be able to keep our heads above water.

sense.definition: (to become used to something) very easily, without any problems or fears
examples: She has taken to teaching like a duck to water.

sense.definition: in large quantities
examples: He spends money like water.

sense.definition: to make a simple situation confused and more complicated than it really is
examples: She deliberately muddied the waters by constantly referring to other irrelevant cases.

sense.definition: if an argument, an excuse, a theory, etc. does not hold water, you cannot believe it
to urinate
to give reasons for not being in favor of something; to criticize something
examples: She immediately poured cold water on his plans to expand the business.

sense.definition: a person who seems to be quiet or shy may surprise you by knowing a lot or having deep feelings
to find out what the situation is before doing something or making a decision
to keep yourself vertical in deep water by moving your arms and legs
to make no progress while you are waiting for something to happen
examples: I decided to tread water until a better job came along.

sense.definition: when a pregnant woman's water breaks, the liquid in her womb passes out of her body just before the baby is born
used to say that something, especially criticism, has no effect on someone or something
examples: I can't tell my son what to do; it's water off a duck's back with him.

sense.definition: you can give someone the opportunity to do something, but you cannot force them to do it if they do not want to
a raised line of water that moves across the surface of the ocean, etc.
examples: Huge waves were breaking on the shore.
Surfers flocked to the beach to ride the waves.
the gentle sound of waves lapping
Children were playing in the waves.
Seagulls bobbed on the waves.
The wind made little waves on the pond.

sense.definition: a sudden increase in a particular activity or feeling
examples: a wave of opposition/protest/violence, etc.

sense.definition: a large number of people or things suddenly moving or appearing somewhere
examples: Wave after wave of aircraft passed overhead.

sense.definition: a movement of your arm and hand from side to side
examples: She declined the offer with a wave of her hand.

sense.definition: a continuous movement that looks like a wave on the ocean, made by a large group of people, especially people watching a sports game, when one person after another stands up, raises their arms, and then sits down again
the form that some types of energy such as heat, sound, light, etc. take as they move
examples: radio/sound/ultrasonic waves

sense.definition: if a person's hair has a wave or waves, it is not straight, but curls slightly
the ocean
examples: life on the waves ( = life at sea)

sense.definition: a situation in which someone is very successful, happy, etc.
examples: They've been on the crest of the wave ever since their election victory.

sense.definition: to be very active in a way that makes people notice you, and that may sometimes cause problems
to enjoy or be supported by the particular situation or quality mentioned
examples: Schools are riding a wave of renewed public interest.

sense.definition: a method, style, or manner of doing something
examples: That's not the right way to hold a pair of scissors.

I told you we should have done it my way!

sense.definition: a particular manner or style of behavior
examples: They grinned at her in a friendly way.

sense.definition: the typical way of behaving and living of a particular group of people

sense.definition: a route or road that you take in order to reach a place
examples: the best/quickest/shortest way from A to B

to ask someone the way

sense.definition: the route along which someone or something is moving; the route that someone or something would take if there was nothing stopping them/it
examples: Get out of my way! I'm in a hurry.

sense.definition: a road, path, or street for traveling along
examples: There's a way across the fields.

sense.definition: used in the names of streets
examples: 106 Headley Way

sense.definition: a particular direction; in a particular direction
examples: Which way did they go?

sense.definition: a means of going into or leaving a place, such as a door or gate
examples: the way in/out

sense.definition: a distance or period of time between two points
examples: A little way up on the left is the Museum of Modern Art.

sense.definition: an area, a part of a country, etc.
examples: I think he lives somewhere over Chicago way.

sense.definition: a particular aspect of something
examples: I have changed in every way.

sense.definition: a particular condition or state
examples: The economy's in a bad way.

sense.definition: on the other side of the street, etc.
examples: Music blared from the open window of the house across the way.

sense.definition: during the whole journey/period of time
examples: She didn't speak a word to me all the way back home.

sense.definition: completely; as much as it takes to achieve what you want

sense.definition: used to say that things often happen in a particular manner, especially when it is not convenient
however you choose to look at a situation

sense.definition: to be easy compared to what came before

sense.definition: to have habits or opinions that you have had for a long time and that you do not want to change

sense.definition: in all directions

sense.definition: to move along carefully, for example when it is dark, by touching walls, objects, etc.

sense.definition: to become able to act independently and with confidence

sense.definition: to discover the right route (to a place)

sense.definition: to come to a place or a situation by chance or without intending to

sense.definition: to prevent someone from doing something; to prevent something from happening

sense.definition: to die

sense.definition: to avoid someone
to be familiar with a place, subject, etc.
to make a lot of money easily and feel very pleased about it

sense.definition: to become lost

sense.definition: that is the situation and we cannot change it, so we must accept it
there are many different ways to achieve something
in my opinion

sense.definition: something that allows you to join a group of people, an industry, etc. that it is difficult to join, or to understand something that is difficult to understand

sense.definition: I and another person or other people; I and you

sense.definition: people in general

sense.definition: that cannot support a lot of weight; likely to break

sense.definition: that people are not likely to believe or be persuaded by

sense.definition: not easily seen or heard
