sense.definition: a weak verb forms the past tense and past participle by adding a regular ending and not by changing a vowel. In English this is done by adding -d, -ed or -t (for example walk, walked)
used when there is no stress on the word. For example, the weak form of and is/ən/ or/n/, as in bread and butter/brɛd n bʌt̮ər/
hardly able to stand because of emotion, fear, illness, etc.
examples: His sudden smile made her go weak in the knees.

sense.definition: the point at which a system or an organization is most likely to fail
examples: She went straight for the one weak link in the chain of his argument.

sense.definition: lack of strength, power, or determination
examples: The sudden weakness in her legs made her stumble.

sense.definition: difficulty in resisting something or someone that you like very much

sense.definition: a large amount of money, property, etc. that a person or country owns

sense.definition: the state of being rich
examples: The purpose of industry is to create wealth.

sense.definition: a large amount of something
examples: a wealth of information

sense.definition: an object such as a knife, gun, bomb, etc. that is used for fighting or attacking someone

sense.definition: something such as knowledge, words, actions, etc. that can be used to attack or fight against someone or something

sense.definition: to be something that has both advantages and disadvantages

sense.definition: to have your hair in a particular style; to have a beard or mustache
examples: She wears her hair long.
to wear a beard

sense.definition: to have a particular expression on your face
examples: He wore a puzzled look on his face.

sense.definition: to become or make something become thinner, smoother, or weaker through continuous use or rubbing
examples: The carpets are starting to wear.

sense.definition: to make a hole, path, etc. in something by continuous use or rubbing

sense.definition: to stay in good condition after being used for a long time

sense.definition: used to compare or contrast two facts
examples: Some of the studies show positive results, whereas others do not.

This survey highlights a number of differences in the way that teenage boys and girls in the U.S. spend their free time.
One of the main differences between the girls and the boys who took part in the research was the way in which they use the Internet.
Unlike the girls, who use the Internet mainly to keep in touch with friends, the boys questioned in this survey tend to use the Internet for playing computer games.
The girls differ from the boys in that they tend to spend more time keeping in touch with friends on the telephone or on social networking websites.
Compared with the boys, the girls spend much more time chatting to friends on the telephone.
On average, the girls spend four hours a week chatting to friends on the phone. In contrast, very few of the boys spend more than five minutes a day talking to their friends in this way.
The boys prefer competitive sports and computer games, whereas/while the girls seem to enjoy more cooperative activities, such as shopping with friends.
When the girls go shopping, they mainly buy clothes and cosmetics. The boys, on the other hand, tend to purchase computer games or gadgets.

sense.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence in an official document to mean “because of the fact that…”

This survey highlights a number of differences in the way that teenage boys and girls in the U.S. spend their free time.
One of the main differences between the girls and the boys who took part in the research was the way in which they use the Internet.
Unlike the girls, who use the Internet mainly to keep in touch with friends, the boys questioned in this survey tend to use the Internet for playing computer games.
The girls differ from the boys in that they tend to spend more time keeping in touch with friends on the telephone or on social networking websites.
Compared with the boys, the girls spend much more time chatting to friends on the telephone.
On average, the girls spend four hours a week chatting to friends on the phone. In contrast, very few of the boys spend more than five minutes a day talking to their friends in this way.
The boys prefer competitive sports and computer games, whereas/while the girls seem to enjoy more cooperative activities, such as shopping with friends.
When the girls go shopping, they mainly buy clothes and cosmetics. The boys, on the other hand, tend to purchase computer games or gadgets.

sense.definition: although; despite the fact that…
examples: While I am willing to help, I do not have much time available.
While the movie is undoubtedly too long, it is nevertheless an intriguing work of art.
It can be argued that the movie is too long. It is nonetheless an intriguing work of art.
The movie is undoubtedly too long. Still, it is an intriguing work of art.
Of course, huge chunks of the book have been sacrificed in order to make a two-hour movie, but it is nevertheless a successful piece of storytelling.
Critics are wrong to argue that the movie's plot is too complicated. Certainly there are a couple of major twists, but audiences will have no difficulty following them.
It is true that you cannot make a good movie without a good script, but it is equally true that a talented director can make a good script into an excellent movie.
It remains to be seen whether these two movies herald a new era of westerns, but there is no doubt that they represent welcome additions to the genre.

sense.definition: a large number or amount

sense.definition: everything; all of something

sense.definition: used instead of “who” as the object of a verb or preposition

sense.definition: used in questions to ask who something belongs to

sense.definition: used to say which person or thing you mean

sense.definition: used to give more information about a person or thing

sense.definition: used in questions to suggest that it is not necessary to do something

sense.definition: used to give or talk about a reason

sense.definition: used in questions to mean “why,” expressing surprise

sense.definition: used to make or agree to a suggestion

examples: He spent the evening wrapping up the Christmas presents.
individually wrapped chocolates

sense.definition: to cover something or someone in material, for example in order to protect it/them
examples: Wrap the meat in foil before you cook it.
He tossed her a towel. “Wrap yourself in that.”
I wrapped the baby (up) in a blanket.
I wrapped a blanket around the baby.

sense.definition: to put something firmly around something or someone
examples: A scarf was wrapped around his neck.
His arms were wrapped around her waist.
The nurse wrapped a bandage tightly around my ankle.

sense.definition: to cause text to be carried over to a new line automatically as you reach the end of the previous line; to be carried over in this way
examples: How can I wrap the text?
The text wraps around if it is too long to fit the screen.

sense.definition: to be so involved with someone or something that you do not pay enough attention to other people or things
examples: They are completely wrapped up in their children.
She was so wrapped up in her work that she didn't realize how late it was.

sense.definition: to persuade someone to do anything that you want
examples: She has always been able to twist her parents around her little finger.

sense.definition: the joint between the hand and the arm
examples: She broke her wrist.
He wore a copper bracelet on his wrist.

sense.definition: a warning or mild punishment
to make letters or numbers on a surface, especially using a pen or a pencil
examples: In some countries children don't start learning to read and write until they are six.
Please write in pen on both sides of the paper.
I haven't got anything to write with.
Write your name at the top of the paper.
The teacher wrote the answers on the board.
The “b” had been wrongly written as a “d.”

sense.definition: to produce something in written form so that people can read, perform, or use it, etc.
examples: to write a novel/a song/an essay/a computer program, etc.
Who was “The Grapes of Wrath” written by?
Which opera did Verdi write first?
He hopes to write a book about his experiences one day.
She had to write a report on the project.
I wanted to travel and then write about it.
He writes for the “The New Yorker.” ( = works as a writer)
No decision has been made at the time of writing.
She wrote him several poems.

sense.definition: to put information, a message of good wishes, etc. in a letter and send it to someone
examples: Bye! Don't forget to write.
Can you write and confirm your reservation?
I'm writing to inquire about language classes
She wrote to him in France.
I wrote a letter to the Publicity Department.
I wrote the Publicity Department a letter.
She wrote that they were all fine.
Write me while you're away.
He wrote me that he would be arriving Monday.
They wrote thanking us for the present.

sense.definition: to state the information or the words mentioned
examples: In his latest book he writes that the theory has since been disproved.
Ancient historians wrote of a lost continent beneath the ocean.
“Of all my books,” wrote Dickens, “I like this the best.”

sense.definition: to put information in the appropriate places on a check or other form
examples: to write out a check
I'll write you a receipt.
The doctor wrote her a prescription for more antibiotics.

sense.definition: to record data in the memory of a computer
examples: An error was reported when he tried to write data to the file for the first time.

sense.definition: to work correctly or in the way mentioned
examples: This pen won't write.

sense.definition: to be very obvious to other people from the expression on someone's face
examples: Guilt was written all over his face.

sense.definition: to show clearly the quality mentioned or the influence of the person mentioned
examples: It was a performance with star quality written all over it.
This essay has got Mike written all over it.

sense.definition: not especially good; ordinary
examples: The team's performance was nothing to write home about.

sense.definition: having no value, especially legally, or because one of the people involved has no intention of doing what they said they would
used when you are stating that there is nothing more that can be said about something or that something is completely finished
examples: We were doing well but we ran out of money and that's all she wrote.

sense.definition: a person whose job is writing books, stories, articles, etc.
examples: writers of poetry
a travel/food, etc. writer

sense.definition: a person who has written a particular thing
examples: the writer of this letter

sense.definition: a person who forms letters in a particular way when they are writing
examples: a messy writer

sense.definition: the activity of writing, in contrast to reading, speaking, etc.
examples: Our son's having problems with his reading and writing ( = at school)

sense.definition: the activity of writing books, articles, etc., especially as a job
examples: Only later did she discover a talent for writing.
He is leaving the band to concentrate on his writing.
creative writing
feminist/travel, etc. writing

sense.definition: books, articles, etc. in general
examples: The review is a brilliant piece of writing.

sense.definition: a group of pieces of writing, especially by a particular person or on a particular subject
examples: His experiences in India influenced his later writings.
the writings of Hegel

sense.definition: words that have been written or painted on something
examples: There was writing all over the desk.

sense.definition: the particular way in which someone forms letters when they write
examples: Who's this from? I don't recognize the writing.

sense.definition: in the form of a letter, document, etc. (that gives proof of something)
examples: All telephone reservations must be confirmed in writing.
Could you put your complaint in writing?
You must get it in writing.

sense.definition: used when you are describing a situation in which there are signs that something is going to have problems or that it is going to be a failure
examples: It is amazing that not one of them saw the writing on the wall.

sense.definition: expressed in writing rather than in speech
examples: written instructions

sense.definition: involving writing rather than speaking or practical skills
examples: a written test
written communication skills

sense.definition: in the form of a letter, document, etc. and therefore official
examples: a written apology
a written contract

sense.definition: language expressed in writing rather than in speech
examples: the permanence of the written word

sense.definition: not right or correct
examples: I got all the answers wrong.
He was driving on the wrong side of the road.
Sorry, I must have dialed the wrong number.
You're holding the camera the wrong way up!
That picture is the wrong way around.

sense.definition: not right about something or someone synonym mistaken
examples: I think she lives at number 44, but I could be wrong.
You were wrong about Tom; he's not married after all.
We were wrong to assume that she'd agree.
She would prove him wrong ( = prove that he was wrong) whatever happened.
You think you've beaten me but that's where you're wrong.
Correct me if I'm wrong ( = I may be wrong) but didn't you say you two knew each other?

sense.definition: causing problems or difficulties; not as it should be
examples: Is anything wrong? You look worried.
“What's wrong?” “Oh, nothing.”
There's something wrong with the printer.
The doctor could find nothing wrong with him.
I have something wrong with my foot.

sense.definition: not suitable, right or what you need
examples: He's the wrong person for the job.
I realized that it was the wrong thing to say.
We don't want this document falling into the wrong hands.
It was his bad luck to be in the wrong place at the wrong time ( = so that he got involved in trouble without intending to).

sense.definition: not morally right or honest
examples: This man has done nothing wrong.
It is wrong to tell lies.
It was wrong of me to get so angry.
What's wrong with eating meat?
It is wrong that he should not be punished for what he did.

sense.definition: to have the wrong idea about how to get or achieve something
examples: You're barking up the wrong tree if you think we'd lend you money again.

sense.definition: from or living in a poor area or part of town
to make someone pleased with you/annoyed with you
to be in a bad mood for the whole day for no particular reason
to do, say, or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion
examples: It is a bizarre tale and the author hits just the right note of horror and disbelief.

sense.definition: almost correct
examples: Your guess wasn't far off at all.

sense.definition: thinking or behaving in the right/wrong way
examples: We haven't found a cure yet—but we are on the right track.

sense.definition: in trouble with the police
to make someone annoyed or angry, often without intending to, by doing or saying something that offends them
examples: She tends to rub people the wrong way.

sense.definition: to be offended by a remark that was not intended to be offensive
examples: She always takes things the wrong way.

sense.definition: in a way that is unfair, immoral, or not correct
examples: She was wrongly accused of stealing.
He assumed, wrongly, that she did not care.
The sentence had been wrongly translated.
They knew they had acted wrongly.
Rightly or wrongly, they felt they should have been better informed ( = I do not know whether they were right to feel this way).
She was wrongly diagnosed as having skin cancer.
My name was spelled wrong.
I’m afraid you guessed wrong.
He was wrongly targeted by the media.
She guessed wrongly that he was a teacher.

sense.definition: a piece of land next to or around your house where you can grow flowers, fruit, vegetables, etc., usually with an area of grass (called alawn)
a unit for measuring length, equal to 3 feet (36 inches) or 0.9144 of a meter
an area outside a building, usually with a hard surface and a surrounding wall
examples: the prison yard
The children were playing in the yard at the front of the school.

sense.definition: an area of land used for a special purpose or business
examples: a boat yard
a chocolate/cigarette/clothing factory
a nuclear power plant
a manufacturing plant
a bottling plant
a steel/cotton/paper/textile/woolen mill
a brickworks
a steelworks
Raw materials were carried to the works by rail.
a shipyard
a car repair shop
a sheet metal workshop
an iron foundry

sense.definition: a long piece of wood fastened to a mast that supports a sail on a boat or ship
everything, or a situation that includes everything
examples: When Dan cooks dinner he always goes the whole nine yards, with three courses and a choice of dessert.

sense.definition: to open your mouth wide and breathe in deeply through it, usually because you are tired or bored
examples: He stood up, stretched and yawned.
We couldn't help yawning during the speech.

sense.definition: to be very wide and often frightening and difficult to get across
examples: A crevasse yawned at their feet.
There's a yawning gap between rich and poor.

sense.definition: yes
used when you are commenting on what someone has just said
examples: “We're off to France soon.” “Oh yeah? When's that?”
“I'm going to be rich one day.” “Oh yeah?” ( = I don't believe you.)

sense.definition: used to say that you do not believe what someone has just said, disagree with it, or are not interested in it
examples: “You'll be fine.” “Yeah, right.”

sense.definition: the period from January 1 to December 31, that is 365 or 366 days, divided into 12 months
examples: in the year 1865
I lost my job earlier this year.
Elections take place every year.
The museum is open all year round ( = during the whole year).

sense.definition: a period of 12 months, measured from any particular time
examples: It's exactly a year since I started working here.
She gave up teaching three years ago.
in the first year of their marriage
the prewar/war/postwar years ( = the period before/during/after the war)
I have happy memories of my years in Paris ( = the time I spent there).

sense.definition: a period of 12 months connected with a particular activity
examples: the academic/school year
the tax year

sense.definition: age; time of life
examples: He was 14 years old when it happened.
She looks young for her years.
They were both only 20 years of age.
a twenty-year-old man
He died in his sixtieth year.
She's getting on in years ( = is no longer young).

sense.definition: a long time
examples: It's years since we last met.
They haven't seen each other for years.
That's the best movie I've seen in years.
We've had a lot of fun over the years.

sense.definition: the last years of someone's life
a person or thing that people decide is the best in a particular field in a particular year
examples: She was chosen as mother of the year.

sense.definition: used to emphasize that you will/would never do something
examples: I'd never have thought of that in a million years.

sense.definition: used in polite expressions to describe someone as “very old”
examples: He was a man of advanced years.
Even at my advanced age, I still know how to enjoy myself!

sense.definition: to make someone feel or look older
examples: The illness put years on him.

sense.definition: to make someone feel or look younger
examples: That haircut takes years off her.

sense.definition: the time when a new century/year starts
examples: It was built at the turn of the century.

sense.definition: every year for many years
examples: People return year after year.

sense.definition: as the years pass; each year
examples: Year by year their affection for each other grew stronger.

sense.definition: every year
any particular year after the birth of Christ
a very long time ago
examples: I've been going there every summer since the year one.

sense.definition: each year, compared with the last year
examples: Spending has increased year on year.
a year-on-year increase in spending

sense.definition: having the color of lemons or butter
examples: pale yellow flowers
a bright yellow rain jacket

sense.definition: easily frightened
used to answer a question and say that something is correct or true
examples: “Is this your car?” “Yes, it is.”
“Are you coming? Yes or no?”

sense.definition: used to show that you agree with what has been said
examples: “I enjoyed her latest novel.” “Yes, me too.”
“It's an excellent hotel.” “Yes, but ( = I don't completely agree) it's too expensive.”

sense.definition: used to disagree with something negative that someone has just said
examples: “I've never met her before.” “Yes, you have.”

sense.definition: used to agree to a request or to give permission
examples: “Dad, can I borrow the car?” “Yes, but be careful.”
We're hoping that they will say yes to our proposals.

sense.definition: used to accept an offer or invitation
examples: “Would you like a drink?” “Yes, please/thanks.”

sense.definition: used for asking someone what they want
examples: Yes? How can I help you?

sense.definition: used for replying politely when someone calls you
examples: “Waiter!” “Yes, sir?”

sense.definition: used to show that you have just remembered something
examples: Where did I put the keys? Oh, yes—in my pocket!

sense.definition: used to encourage someone to continue speaking
examples: “I'm going to Paris this weekend.” “Yes…”

sense.definition: used to show that you do not believe what someone has said
examples: “Sorry I'm late—the bus didn't come.” “Oh yes?”

sense.definition: used to emphasize what you have just said
examples: Mrs. Smith has just won $2 million—yes!—$2 million!

sense.definition: used to show that you are excited or extremely pleased about something that you have done or something that has happened
examples: “They've scored another goal.” “Yes!!”

sense.definition: used to show that you are impatient or irritated about something
examples: “Hurry up—it's late.” “Yes, yes—I'm coming.”

sense.definition: used when you cannot give a clear answer to a question
examples: “Are you enjoying it?” “Yes and no.”

sense.definition: on the day before today
examples: They arrived yesterday.
I can remember our wedding as if it were yesterday.
Where were you yesterday morning?
To think I was lying on a beach only the day before yesterday.

sense.definition: used to say that you are not stupid enough to believe what someone is telling you
examples: Oh yeah? I wasn't born yesterday, you know.

sense.definition: used in negative sentences and questions to talk about something that has not happened but that you expect to happen
examples: I haven't received a letter from him yet.
I didn't receive a letter from him yet.
“Are you ready?” “No, not yet.”
We have yet to decide what action to take ( = We have not decided what action to take).

sense.definition: now; as soon as this
examples: Don't go yet.
We don't need to start yet.

sense.definition: from now until the period of time mentioned has passed
examples: He'll be busy for ages yet.
They won't arrive for at least two hours yet.

sense.definition: used to say that something could, might, etc. happen in the future, even though it seems unlikely
examples: We may win yet.
She could yet surprise us all.

sense.definition: the best, longest, etc. thing of its kind made, produced, written, etc. until now/then
examples: the most comprehensive study yet of his music
It was the highest building yet constructed.

sense.definition: used to emphasize an increase in number or amount or the number of times something happens
examples: snow, snow and yet more snow
yet another diet book
Prices were cut yet again ( = once more, after many other times).

sense.definition: used to emphasize an increase in the degree of something ( = how bad, important, etc. it is)
examples: a recent and yet more improbable theory

sense.definition: until now or until a particular time in the past
examples: an as yet unpublished report
As yet little was known of the causes of the disease.

sense.definition: used as the subject or object of a verb or after a preposition to refer to the person or people being spoken or written to
examples: You said you knew the way.
I thought she told you.
Can I sit next to you?
I don't think that hairstyle is you ( = it doesn't suit your appearance or personality).

sense.definition: used with nouns and adjectives to speak to someone directly
examples: You girls, stop talking!
You stupid idiot!

sense.definition: used for referring to people in general
examples: You learn a language better if you visit the country where it is spoken.
It's a friendly place — people come up to you in the street and start talking.

sense.definition: having lived or existed for only a short time; not fully developed
examples: young babies
a young country
Caterpillars eat the young leaves of this plant.
a young wine
The night is still young ( = it has only just started).

sense.definition: not yet old; not as old as others
examples: young people
talented young football players
I am the youngest of four sisters.
In his younger days he played baseball for the Mets.
I met the young Bill Clinton at Georgetown.
Her grandchildren keep her young.
My son is thirteen, but he's young for his age ( = not as developed as other boys of the same age).
They married young ( = at an early age).
My mother died young.

sense.definition: suitable or appropriate for young people
examples: young fashion
The clothes she wears are much too young for her.

sense.definition: consisting of young people or young children; with a low average age
examples: They have a young family.
a young audience

sense.definition: used to show that you are angry or annoyed with a particular young person
examples: I think you owe me an apology, young lady!

sense.definition: used before or after a person's name to distinguish them from an older relative
examples: the younger Kennedy
William Pitt the Younger

sense.definition: used to say that people seem to be doing something at a younger age than they used to, or that they seem younger because you are now older
examples: The band's fans are getting younger.
Why do police officers seem to be getting younger?

sense.definition: used when you are commenting that time is passing and that you, or someone else, is growing older
thinking and behaving like a young person even when you are old
examples: My father is 76 but he's still young at heart.

sense.definition: young people should enjoy themselves as much as possible, because they will have to work and worry later in their lives
of or belonging to the person or people being spoken or written to
examples: I like your dress.
Excuse me, is this your seat?
The bank is on your right.

sense.definition: of or belonging to people in general
examples: Dentists advise you to have your teeth checked every six months.
In Japan you are taught great respect for your elders.

sense.definition: used to show that someone or something is well known or often talked about
examples: This is your typical dive bar.
You and your bright ideas!

sense.definition: used in some titles, especially those of royal people
examples: Your Majesty
Your Excellency

sense.definition: of or belonging to you
examples: Is that book yours?
Is she a friend of yours?
My hair is very fine. Yours is much thicker.

sense.definition: used at the end of a letter before signing your name
examples: Sincerely Yours
Yours Truly

sense.definition: used when the person or people being spoken to both cause and are affected by an action
examples: Did you hurt yourself?
You don't seem like yourself today ( = you do not seem well or do not seem as happy as usual).
Enjoy yourselves!

sense.definition: used to emphasize the fact that the person who is being spoken to is doing something
examples: Do it yourself—I don't have time.
You can try it out for yourselves.

sense.definition: you
examples: We sell a lot of these to people like yourself.
“And yourself,” he replied, “How are you?”

sense.definition: to act naturally
examples: Don't try to act sophisticated—just be yourself.

sense.definition: alone; without anyone else
examples: How long were you by yourself in the house?

sense.definition: without help
examples: Are you sure you did this work by yourself?

sense.definition: for only you to have, use, etc.
examples: I'm going to be away next week, so you'll have the office to yourself.

sense.definition: the time of life when a person is young, especially the time before a child becomes an adult
examples: He had been a talented musician in his youth.
She regrets that she spent her youth traveling and not studying.

sense.definition: the quality or state of being young
examples: She brings to the job a rare combination of youth and experience.
His youth gives him an advantage over the other runners.

sense.definition: a young man
examples: The fight was started by a gang of youths.

sense.definition: young people considered as a group
examples: the nation's youth
the youth of today
youth culture
youth unemployment
Five, four, three, two, one, zero… We have liftoff.

sense.definition: a temperature, pressure, etc. that is equal to zero on a scale
examples: It was ten degrees below zero last night ( = −10°C).
The thermometer had fallen to zero.

sense.definition: the lowest possible amount or level; nothing at all
examples: I rated my chances as zero.
zero inflation

sense.definition: an area or a region with a particular feature or use
examples: a security/demilitarized, etc. zone
an earthquake/danger, etc. zone
a pedestrian zone ( = where vehicles may not go)

sense.definition: one of the areas that a larger area is divided into for the purpose of organization
examples: postal charges to countries in zone 2

sense.definition: an area or a part of an object, especially one that is different from its surroundings
examples: When the needle enters the red zone, the engine is too hot.
the erogenous zones of the body

sense.definition: one of the parts that the earth's surface is divided into by imaginary lines that are parallel to the equator
examples: the northern/southern temperate zone

sense.definition: in a state in which you feel confident and are performing at your best
examples: When I'm in the zone, writing is the most satisfying thing in the world.
